PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received through His Excellency the Governor-General, from the Governor of the State of New South Wales, a certificate of the choice by the Houses of Parliament of New South Wales of Senator Tierney to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Peter Baume. I table a copy of the certificate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a former distinguished senator, Senator Bernie Kilgariff. On behalf of all senators I wish him well on this visit to Canberra.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable Senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the situation in Iraqi Kurdistan where up to two million people are reported to be fleeing from Saddam Hussein's army, and I ask why did not the Australian Government lobby members of the United Nations (UN) Security Council to include a clause for the protection of minorities in Iraq in the cease-fire resolution as approved by the Security Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation in Iraq with the Kurds is distressing in the extreme at the moment. I think all honourable senators will be aware, from the news coverage, of the Iraqi assault upon the Kurdish minority and the flight of refugees that has occurred subsequently. I guess the full dimensions of the tragedy that we are now seeing unfold have only become apparent over the course of the last week.

ANSWER.PARA: The terms of the cease-fire resolution were bedded down formally by the Security Council certainly by 2 April and, in fact, largely resolved before Easter. Some attempts were made at that stage by the French and others to raise specifically the question of either sanctions provisions or some other provisions in the cease-fire resolution, bearing specifically on the position of minorities and, in particular, the Kurdish minority within Iraq. But, as I understand it, the reaction of other countries prominent in the drafting of that resolution was that it was better to focus on the already tremendously complex array of issues that they were then focussing on in that cease-fire resolution, rather than open up the matter further in that way.

In the event, the sanctions language of UN Security Council resolution 687 was left open enough and general enough-in particular, in operative clause 21-to enable further consideration to be given to the internal developments, including those in relation to the Kurdish minority, as they occurred. That is the provision which says that the Security Council should review the provisions of the sanctions clause every 60 days in the light of the policies and practices of the Government of Iraq, including the implementation of all relevant resolutions of the Security Council.

As I understand it, that language has been subsequently construed as broad enough to encompass an ongoing consideration of the Iraqi Government's behaviour with respect to the Kurds, and is being regarded as a sufficiently precise peg on which to hang, in particular, the continuation of economic sanctions until such time as the situation improves.

Australia is well aware of all of these developments as they are occurring in the United Nations, and it is simply a matter of making a judgment as to whether or not there is anything more we can usefully do than is already happening as these things are negotiated to fruition. We made the judgment that, particularly given our status as not being a current member of the Security Council, there was little we could add to a very lively debate on these issues that was already proceeding. That is the view that we continue to hold.

Resolution 688 of the Security Council, passed last week, deals quite specifically with the humanitarian issues confronting the present plight of the Kurdish people. That is now being used as the basis for the suggestion from, among others, the United Kingdom Prime Minister, John Major-endorsed earlier today, I believe, by the European Community-that some safe haven concept should be developed pursuant to the open-ended terms of that resolution which would make it possible for the UN to get involved in oversighting the present very unhappy position of the Kurds within Iraq. That issue opens up another very complex series of jurisdictional and legalistic questions about what the precise capacity of the United Nations is, and should be, to act in these areas when one is dealing with internal matters rather than external aggression. Certainly, the UN charter is very clear that military authority does not extend to matters of this kind. But, equally clearly, under UN practice and tradition there is no doubt at all that the international community can apply a great weight of influence, both directly and through the United Nations, in relation to internal humanitarian tragedies and problems of this kind. I go into this detail, Mr President, because it is an extremely complex issue as to just how to handle this.

Might I say for the record that Australia supports the continuation of sanctions until such time as the human rights of the Kurdish people are guaranteed to the international community's reasonable satisfaction. We support in principle the concept of some kind of safe enclave if that could be made to work consistently with the United Nations charter and with the assessment of the international community of its practicability.

We do, of course, support the question of international humanitarian relief for the Kurdish people in this situation, and I may have the opportunity to say something more about that later. We do, of course, support in any other appropriate way the maximum pressure being placed upon Iraq to do the right thing in relation to the Kurdish people-something that it has not been very good at doing over the past decades of that country's existence. We have made our voice perfectly plain in this respect whenever it has become necessary to do so, and certainly in the next few days we will continue to pursue very actively any avenue of the resolution of this matter that we see is not already being actively pursued by current members of the Security Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister raised the question of humanitarian assistance and I ask: what humanitarian assistance has the Australian Government offered? If it has not made any formal offer yet, what does it intend to offer?

—I was going to leave that matter for a later occasion, but let me say that the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett, is today announcing an Australian contribution of another $1m to the international relief efforts for the Iraqi post-war situation, to be divided between the United Nations High Commission for Refugees and the International Committee of the Red Cross. It is the case, of course, that this donation follows an earlier donation of $1m each to the Red Cross and to the UNDRO, the United Nations Disaster Relief Organisation, specifically focused on assistance for the victims of the Gulf crisis, including refugees. It is also the case that, in addition to that, another $3m was donated earlier on for humanitarian purposes-including to non-government organisations active in the region and to UNRWA, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees in the Middle East-thereby making, together with today's additional contribution, a total of $6m-worth of Australian humanitarian contributions to the area since the Gulf crisis began.
—My question has been taken over by the supplementary question asked by Senator Hill on humanitarian aid for the Kurds.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Prime Minister's March industry statement. What will be the impact of the duty reductions for capital equipment announced in the industry statement, both on the developers of major projects and also on Australia's engineering industry in general?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The key changes announced on 12 March will have the effect of reducing input costs for industry by removing duty on certain capital equipment in the mineral processing, shipbuilding and ship repair industries. Split consignment arrangements will also be extended to cover additional items of capital equipment.

ANSWER.PARA: The rationale for these and similar measures is the reduction of capital equipment costs for the efficient mining and agricultural export industries. This has been a key objective of the Government, certainly since May 1988. Making this cost-saving opportunity available to the minerals processing and shipbuilding sectors is a logical extension of the objective which has previously been worked towards, for example, in the May 1988 statement.

In addition, the measures encourage participation of competitive Australian supplier industries in major industrial projects. This is particularly beneficial to key engineering enterprises in Australia. Under the split consignment provisions, the ability to import parts of a machine at the duty rate applying to the total machine, while having the balance of the machine made in Australia, encourages the involvement of competitive Australian companies. It no longer means that importing the complete plant and equipment is the favoured option. Indeed, the combination of imports under item 45 of the tariff-mining equipment-and item 43, which deals with split consignments, has assisted Australian industry to play a major part in the North West Shelf Goodwin A platform project which was announced last year.

A further related measure in the industry statement referred to state-of-the-art equipment. While details have not been considered by the Government at this stage, the proposed state-of-the-art equipment by-law will enable Australian industry to import high performance equipment where equivalent goods are not produced in Australia. This will be important in introducing more flexibility into the commercial tariff concession and by-law system.

Overall, the measures will have a beneficial effect in assisting Australian industry to be more competitive in major local projects, which is an essential prerequisite for a successful export industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to remarks of his colleague Mr Dawkins over the weekend that the Government should adopt new instruments to influence the level of the exchange rate and to the Treasurer's vehement rejection yesterday of this proposal. I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the Treasurer or with Mr Dawkins on this vital aspect of economic policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the Treasurer in relation to the exchange rate and the regime that this Government has had in place for some years relating to the exchange rate. There is no difference of opinion about the exchange rate policy that the Government is running.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —All sorts of people have made very strenuous efforts to read all sorts of things into what Mr Dawkins said. It has to be said that we are all aware of the relevance of the exchange rate to a competitive economy. This is constantly under the attention of the Government and the Reserve Bank. The Government never regarded the 12 March statement as the end of discussion on decision making in the area of increasing the competitiveness of the Australian economy. The Government will continue to consider these issues of competitiveness and trade performance in the future.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As a result of the Minister's quite unbelievable reply I ask whether the Minister, given his reported defence of Mr Dawkins in Cabinet, agrees with Mr Dawkins's right to speak out publicly on this matter. If not, can he explain to the Senate why the Prime Minister has refused to take the only responsible course of action open to him, namely, to sack Mr Dawkins?

—Senator Short's remarks are predicated on the assumption of some information which apparently appeared in the press that claimed I supported Mr Dawkins in relation to the substance of what was allegedly said in his speech. That is incorrect.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer him to recent media reports of comments made by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Tim Fischer, suggesting that the joint Australian-United States (US) defence facilities should be used as bargaining chips in retaliation for American farm subsidies. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's position on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports of Mr Fischer's comment that he would be prepared to use the joint facilities as a last resort bargaining chip if American farm subsidies became more destructive. I also note, with some disappointment, reports that in Western Australia a group of farmers vandalised a tracking station in the belief that that is in some way a US military installation. Whilst I acknowledge that Mr Fischer or indeed anyone else has the right to seek a change in United States policies affecting rural interests, it is simply ludicrous to suggest that the joint facilities should be linked in any way to the trade negotiations.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, I emphasise that these defence facilities have been established as joint Australian and United States defence facilities. Our two governments share in the management and operation of the facilities and both have access to the product. Importantly, the operations of these facilities serve Australian interests as well as those of the United States. The facilities make an important contribution to maintaining international stability and deterring international conflict. It would be contrary to our own interests as well as those of the wider international community to discontinue our cooperation over these joint facilities.

In conclusion, I endorse the comments made by the Prime Minister yesterday that this Government rejects totally any suggestion that the joint Australian-US defence facilities should be linked to trade issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer him to the Government's proposal to ban all political advertising, at all times by all Australians, on radio and television. Will he advise the Senate of his definition of the word `political'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer raises the question of the definition of the term--
—Don't you know? Do you have to look it up?
—You cannot even answer this one without reading it.

—I would probably have a bigger chance of answering this question if Opposition members were as keenly interested in receiving an answer as in creating havoc in this place. I ask them to hold on for a few seconds. The question that Senator Parer raises is one that obviously has had some publicity in recent days. The Government has decided to ban political advertising on radio and television. It is a decision that we have taken after due consideration.

ANSWER.PARA: The particular part of Senator Parer's question goes to the definition of the word `political'. There have been definitions of political advertising on electoral matters in the Broadcasting Act 1942 for something like 40 years now and they have not excited much attention during that period.

The Government is drafting legislation and the Opposition, like everyone else, will have to await the final drafting and presentation of that legislation to this place to enable them to understand the definition in the context in which we are talking about it. I indicate to Senator Parer, as I have indicated to others in recent weeks, that we are using definitions currently existing in the Broadcasting Act as a basis for our definition. As I say, those provisions have applied in one way or another for the best part of four decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the Minister obviously does not know what the word `political' means and he tells us to wait for the legislation, I wonder whether he can advise the Senate of the Australian Electoral Commissioner's interpretation of `electoral matter' as defined in the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, I think it is fair to say that my first answer made it very clear that I was talking about `political' and `electoral' matter in the Electoral Act, to which Senator Parer has referred. Those definitions are the ones which will form the basis of the Government's decision. In all fairness and in all comprehensiveness, the Opposition will have to wait for the draft legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: The point has been made that I do not know the answer or that I will not tell the Senate what it is. It is the normal course in the preparation of legislation that definitions are worked on. We have indicated that there are a number of provisions in existing legislation upon which we will draw to specify the definition that will apply. Without going into repetition to any great extent, the Opposition, like everyone else, will have to await the presentation of the legislation. At that stage Opposition members will see the precise details of the definition of `political' matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that last week the Australian Information Industry Association (AIIA) released a paper outlining 55 recommendations for the future development of the information technology (IT) industries in Australia? The paper contained many suggestions for government action. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government plans to act on any of these suggestions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very much aware of that statement because a lot of discussion took place during its preparation. Clearly, a good deal of thought and effort have gone into that document. It is a very comprehensive treatment of the problems and opportunities in the information technology industries today. However, most of the matters raised by the Australian Information Industry Association were addressed in the industry statement of 12 March.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very pleased with the Association's positive response to the measures that were announced. The industry statement announced a number of measures concerning government procurement of information technology goods and services, which is an area of great concern to the industry. Last month, Senator Bolkus and I released a joint statement on the Government's IT purchasing policy, a statement welcomed by the industry with one or two minor difficulties which are still under discussion.

The Federal Government is now committed to open systems, to using outside data processing sources where they are cost effective and in line with public policy, to a more open tendering process and to greater accountability by agency heads. A working party is presently working out detailed guidelines about the implementation of these policies. Some of the other issues raised by the AIIA, such as micro-economic reform, are high on the Government's agenda.

I make the point, however, that it is clear from the report that not all the solutions lie within the public sector or within the Government's province. Many of the problems can be solved by the industry and by individual users through the more efficient use of information technology and through greater emphasis on the benefits of the technology rather than just on the technology itself.

I conclude by mentioning the importance of these industries to Australia. Information technology is an enabling industry which runs right across all industry sectors in this country. The importance and understanding of the industry's strengths and problems cannot be overestimated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I noted with great interest his answer earlier today to the question of Senator Hill on the Kurds. Following on from that, will Australia advocate the maintenance of sanctions against Iraq until the Iraqi regime ceases all human rights abuses including, but not only, the waging of an internal war against its own Kurdish minority? Will Australia advocate in the United Nations, not just a Kurdish haven but an autonomous Kurdish state in the north of Iraq? What will the Government do to guarantee that our humanitarian aid will reach the Kurds, unlike most of the international aid meant for the Kurds after the chemical weapons were used against them previously by Saddam Hussein?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of the question about the maintenance of sanctions, I think I have said really about as much as I can about our general support for the principle that has been enunciated in recent days that sanctions should be maintained at least until the amnesty against them is made permanent by the Iraqi Government and the persecution stops, which is the language that the United Kingdom Prime Minister used a few hours ago. Whether or not it would be appropriate to think in terms of maintaining sanctions until a whole range of human rights abuses which that regime has been guilty of over the years against its own citizens, not just the Kurds, ceases, raises some rather more difficult questions about the scope and the capacity of the international community to maintain a sanctions regime of that kind. I will certainly take on board what Senator Bourne has said and give consideration to what Australia's position should be about that.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the last part of the question about guaranteeing the delivery of humanitarian aid that Australia will supply, distribution can always be a problem in exercises of this kind. All we can hope is that the particular agencies through which we are primarily working, namely the Red Cross, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the United Nations Disaster Relief Organisation, will have the capacity-they certainly have the skill and expertise-in terms of what they are allowed to do on the ground to get the material through. We will simply be hoping that that happens. We are obviously not in a position ourselves to influence the distribution arrangements.

The most substantial part of the question was about whether or not the Australian Government should support calls for a Kurdish homeland and an independent state. That raises very difficult questions for the entire international community. Historically, the area referred to as Kurdistan was part of the Ottoman Empire. It was not an internationally recognised separate entity. It cannot be said, accordingly, that the Kurds were ever actually displaced from a state of their own; nor is it the case, on my understanding, that the Kurds were actually displaced from the particular land area that they physically occupied. On both counts, I guess their situation is a little different from that of the Palestinian people.

Rather, the Kurds were, and are, an ethic minority in five countries of the Middle East and central Asia and, as such, are citizens of those countries. In Iraq they comprise three million out of a population of 17 million; in Turkey about 10 million out of 55 million; in Iran about six million out of 56 million; in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics about half a million out of 290 million-a very small minority there; and in Syria about half a million out of 13 million.

It also needs to be borne in mind that the areas in which the Kurds live in those respective countries are not exclusively Kurdish; many other ethnic groups live there as well. To contemplate the creation of a new state in this region out of sections of five other sovereign states, or even out of just a proportion of those, is really unrealistic in our judgment since it would be resisted by the states concerned and, moreover, it would also establish an international precedent that few other United Nations (UN) member states would accept. Obviously, there are many countries around the world within which very substantial minority groups are resident and they might be minded from time to time to do as the Kurds have done and take up arms against their host country. What then is the international community to do in response to those similarly historically based claims of minority ethnic identity?

Australia does very strongly support current international moves, of course, to tackle generally the problems of the Middle East region, taking advantage of the consensus that has developed over the Gulf crises. While the focus of those post- war efforts is to guarantee military security for the region as a whole, and also to focus particularly on Arab, Israeli and Palestinian issues, it will be necessary to look at a range of related issues-we have always acknowledged this-including human rights and the protection of minorities generally within the region, if stability is to be brought to the region.

In that context, I see every likelihood of the particular problem of the Kurds being addressed, and certainly Australia will take a strong position internationally that it should be addressed. I believe that that will have widespread support, given the way this situation has evolved. We have taken strong stances on this issue over the years in a variety of forums, including in particular the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in Geneva just in the last few months. It would be entirely consistent with that for us to follow the issue through in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign affairs and Trade. In view of the fact that Australia was part of an international coalition which fought to free Kuwait from Iraq's occupation, what assurance do we have that democratic freedoms and in particular the rights of women will be respected in the liberated state?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The political structure and government of Kuwait are, of course, matters for the Kuwaitis themselves now, I am delighted to be able to say. Kuwait's national development before the Iraqi invasion, including its political and its social evolution, was extraordinarily rapid. The invasion and its aftermath have complicated that situation, but there is evident commitment by the Kuwaitis to proceed down the path of modernisation and development.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case that in October last year the Government-in-exile organised a Kuwaiti people's conference in Jeddah in Saudi Arabia, in which the final communique promised adherence to the principle of consultation with the people and popular participation under the 1962 constitution. It was the case that the Crown Prince and the then Prime Minister-the Government has since been in the process of being reconstituted-promised that elections would be held as soon as the situation in Kuwait allowed it. Again, there have been subsequent reaffirmations by the Emir of Kuwait of his commitment to restore a parliamentary system under the 1962 constitution.

Regarding the specific question about votes for women, many of whom played a very active role in the Kuwaiti opposition to Iraq's invasion, the Emir has said that, although this was not in the constitution of 1962, on which they are presently hanging these promises, it would be possible to think about it in the future. Again in February we had the Crown Prince indicating that the question of broadening the electoral franchise could be addressed at an appropriate time.

Australia for its part takes the view that there should be no obstacles in the way of women playing an absolutely full and complete role in the totality of the life of their country. We simply hope that, with the increasingly strong voice that is becoming apparent from opposition groups within the Kuwaiti policy and with the obvious very widespread international view that, as I have said on previous occasions, the Gulf war was not conducted in order to make the world safe for feudalism, under those circumstances those pressures will combine to produce a situation where the rights of women, including the franchise, are fully respected in the not too distant future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services and follows Senator Parer's comments on his attempts to limit freedom of speech. What provisions does the Minister envisage for the enforcement of the proposed ban on political advertising on the electronic media? Are fines envisaged? If a person refuses to pay the fine, will Australia see the emergence of the first political prisoners since its convict days?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering this question, I think it is best to proceed by going very much to the heart of what the Government is doing in this area and why it is doing it. Senator Kemp makes an allegation that what we are about is limiting freedom of speech.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say a couple of things about that point. The most basic premise of our democratic system is that we have one person one vote, one vote one value. Here we are talking about redressing a situation which impacts very much on that principle. It has not been recognised only in Australia; it has been recognised internationally.

We are talking about addressing problems which have been recognised continually, not only on this level but also on a State level. I refer to the costs of advertising, the costs of campaigning and the lack of adequate disclosure provisions on both State and Federal levels. These are issues that governments have had to address. It is all very well for Senator Hill to sit there smiling. The reality is that this Government is prepared to tackle those issues and we are doing so by these decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Other countries also take this view.

—My colleague interjects to make a very valid point. It is amazing how many countries throughout the world do not allow paid political advertising. I think that is a very important point to start off with on this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that one can expect this sort of reaction from the Opposition-an Opposition which has consistently opposed adequate disclosure provisions and any measure on State and Federal levels to clean up the political process. We are also getting this concern about freedoms from an Opposition which over the past eight years has opposed time and again measures by this Government to enshrine, either in the Constitution or by legislation, provisions to protect freedoms in this society. Senator Hill may be sombre now because he sat with me on a parliamentary committee assessing the Bill of Rights. He took a positive approach then but got rolled by his backbenchers-rolled by those of the likes of Senator Walters-time and time again. That has happened whenever this Government has gone to the people either with constitutional amendments or has come to this place--
—I raise a point of order. The question I asked was quite specific: are fines envisaged under this Bill? I would ask the Minister to address that particular question.

—Order! In reply to the point of order, I think that the Bill that the Minister is in charge of is being attacked. He is entitled to take some time to defend it. But I would ask him to answer specifically the questions that were asked by Senator Kemp.

—Mr President, in asking his question, Senator Kemp made some reflection on this Government, claiming it was attacking freedom of speech. I started off by making the point that we are used to those on the other side making claims about concerns as to the freedom of individuals but never pursuing those claims. Let me also say that what we are talking about here is not freedom of speech. We are talking about a capacity to advertise. We are not talking about free speech; we are talking about bought speech.
—Very expensive.

—And, as Senator Collins rightly says, very expensive speech. We are talking about speech that costs up to $13,000 a minute to exercise. As I will keep on saying, we are talking about an inherently undemocratic medium. It is not free speech, as I have said. It is an avenue which costs people $13,000 a minute to exercise.
—On radio? Come on, start telling the truth for a change.
—I was talking of television. As for radio--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from the Opposition.
—Let me canvass the point about radio. If one looks at the rate of increase--

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. You have on a number of occasions ruled that, once a Minister elects to answer a question, he is required to answer it in the terms in which it is asked and not use extraneous material, as he is doing now. I ask you to rule him out of order and to address his remarks to the specific questions asked by Senator Kemp, namely: are there fines envisaged and are people to be sent to gaol for not paying them?
—Senator Bolkus, I believe that you are beginning to debate the substance of the Bill. I would ask you to answer the questions you were asked.

—Mr President, questions were asked and allegations made. I think that any honest response to the questions has to cover both. The point I make is that we are not talking about free speech. We are talking about advertising and about the Government attacking an issue which goes very much to the heart of our democratic system.

ANSWER.PARA: Through advertising we really undermine our democratic system. That has been recognised by conservatives in the United States. We are not talking about free speech. Mr President, if we are talking about freedom of speech, I believe I should be given a chance to respond to the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.
—It is a simple question which requires a simple answer.
—Order, Senator Alston!

—In respect to this allegation that we are attacking free speech and, as a consequence, creating political prisoners, which obviously I reject totally, let me just remind Opposition senators of their view of the value of advertising. In the minority report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which is a committee of both Houses, the Opposition said--
—Order! Senator Bolkus was asked a specific question and I ask him to answer it or to resume his seat.
—Mr President, I am getting towards the end of my answer.
—Mr President, on a point of order--
—Order! I am giving Senator Bolkus the opportunity to answer the question.
—As I said, it is not an attack on free speech. There will not be political prisoners. We, like Opposition senators, believe that what we are talking about here--
—Order! Senator Bolkus will answer the question or resume his seat.
—Mr President, if you give me 60 seconds and if we take the interjections out of this--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The interjections have not stopped.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I put to you that any comprehensive response to Senator Kemp's question has to go to the issues that I have raised. Secondly, no person can answer those questions given the barrage of bickering from Opposition senators. I ask you, Mr President, to call them to order for 60 seconds so that I can answer the question.

—Order! In reply to the point of order: I have given Senator Bolkus well over 4 minutes to deal with matters not relating specifically to the question he was asked, and I ask him to answer those questions now or I will sit him down.

—In short, let me just say to the specific questions that we are not talking about freedom of speech; we are talking about freedom of advertising. We are not talking about political prisoners and in that respect any fines, any sanctions, will be addressed through the legislation. But let me also say that the broadcasting legislation already has sanctions, codes and provisions to cover breaches of that Act. They are the sorts of regime of provisions that will apply in this particular case.

—I have a supplementary question. I wonder whether Senator Bolkus could answer specifically, yes or no, the question of whether there will be fines and, if there are fines, how will those fines be enforced if people refuse to pay those fines.

—I have answered the first part of the question. If Opposition senators want it spelt out even more succinctly, they should wait for the legislation. Provisions already apply in the legislation to cover these sorts of areas. This is nothing new. In respect of the second part of the question in terms of how they will be enforced, they will be enforced in the normal way.
—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of recent reports or claims that Australia risks missing out on reaping the benefits of gene shears technology?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody, I think, is fairly aware of this issue because of a program which was conducted on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. In fact, I even heard some people talking about it at the Boy Charlton swimming pool at lunchtime last week, and it seems to have got itself into the popular psyche. The commercialisation of gene shears and the various reports and comments relating to the recent announcement that Johnson and Johnson would be investing in the technology have received a lot of public comment. Some of the reports, however, have claimed that the participation of Johnson and Johnson and the French company, Limograin, would mean that Australia would miss out on the benefits of the technology, and these claims are exaggerated and wide of the mark.

ANSWER.PARA: Many Ministers-particularly the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Crean, and I-have expressed regret at the lack of a private Australian partner in Gene Shears Ltd, which is the company commercialising the technology. However, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)-a major shareholder in Gene Shears-is still ensuring that Australia will be a major beneficiary. In the absence of local interest and expertise, foreign investment is essential in order to maximise the return to Australia.

International developments in genetic technologies are proceeding at such a pace that if Australia were to wait for a local investor to come forward it would risk missing the boat entirely with the technology. Instead, Australia is already profiting from the multi-million dollar investment in research by Johnson and Johnson and Limograin. Much of this investment will go to research in Australian laboratories, giving us a return many times over the cost of the original research that led to the technology. However, a condition of the investment by both Johnson and Johnson and Limograin is that manufacture of any commercial products based on the technology should take place in Australia, wherever commercially feasible.

Finally, through CSIRO's considerable equity in Gene Shears, the possibility remains for an Australian company to invest in this company. The problem of a lack of investment in research and development by Australian companies has received considerable attention from the Government and was most recently addressed in the industry statement. Similarly, CSIRO has just completed an exhaustive study of national research priorities and is also seeking to bring Australian industry into fields of promising research earlier in the research process than previously. I am very hopeful that these measures will, over time, increase Australia's ability to profit from innovations of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services who I notice has been on the phone taking instructions perhaps on how to answer questions. The Minister has claimed that banning political electronic advertising is necessary to contain electoral spending. How is this reconciled with the associated plan to increase the taxpayer subsidy to political parties for election campaigning by $5m; that is, from $13m to $18m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the question, I hope I will not have to put up with the same barrage from the Opposition that I have had to put up with in answering the last three questions. The Opposition claims to be concerned about freedom of speech. The Opposition's behaviour this afternoon in not allowing me to get one word out puts the lie to any concern it might really have.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I remind the Senate that it was the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which reported both to this place and to the House of Representatives, that made the point that the Government had to address both the costs of campaigning and disclosure. These are the two major issues confronting our democratic system and confronting democratic systems throughout the world. That is why only three or four other countries throughout the world allow paid political advertising. These countries have recognised the corruptive influence of the need for the corporate dollar to fund campaigns and have done something about it.

In respect of electronic advertising, the rate of increase in that advertising has increased far in excess of public funding. I can understand the Liberal Party having absolutely no concern for public spending, until it has to put its hand in the till, but public funding has been introduced to ensure that the process of campaigning does not have to depend on outside influences as much as it has done in the past. If one looks at the rate of increase of advertising rates on radio and television, one will see that over the initial three or four years of application of public funding advertising rates have increased somewhere like three to five times the increase in public funding. Advertising rates are massive. At the last election campaign they exploded to somewhere near $20m for the four major political parties.

As I say, my information is that television rates have increased at something like three times the rate of public funding, and radio rates have increased at something like five times the rate of public funding.

This Government is concerned to ensure that not only do we have adequate disclosure, which is something that the Opposition has always objected to and complained about, apart from Dr Hewson, of course, who really does not know where he stands on this issue at the moment, but we are also keen to address an issue that was raised by Commissioner Fitzgerald, the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales and a joint standing committee of this Parliament, and that is the costs of campaigning. We have done that. We are doing that by addressing the costs of electronic advertising rates and, as a consequence, we have adopted the position of banning advertising in this medium.

At the same time, however, we recognise that public funding has in no way kept up with the rate of increase of public office campaigning. As I say, in those two avenues the rate of increase has been somewhere between three and five times the rate of public funding increase. The Government justifies its decision on those grounds.

I accept that if you come from a position, as the Opposition does, where you do not believe in public funding-it has opposed it consistently-if you come from a position where you do not believe in disclosure, and the Opposition has opposed that consistently at State and Federal level, and if you come from a position directly emanating from that, that is you do not believe in keeping the electoral system clean, honest and open, then you may raise these sorts of issues, but our position is sustainable in the context of increasing campaigning costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that that answer could best be described as circuitous bumph. I ask the Minister specifically whether the additional $5m is to be added to the formerly paid $3m that the Australian Labor Party brought in for direct mail campaigning prior to the last election, so that it may finalise its direct mail campaign and, indeed, further put its snout in the public trough for its direct mail campaign?
—Senator Bishop should know-and if she does not know, she does not have the IQ to be in this place-that what the Government is talking about applies prospectively.
—That is sex discrimination.

—I would have thought that on this particular issue Senator Boswell of all people would have kept quiet. Coming from Queensland, the only role I see for him on this particular issue in this debate is to give expert evidence to us as we draft our legislation. I would not put my head up too highly if I were him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware that the Queensland Electricity Commission has been offering cut price services to Queensland land developers in return for undertakings to install all-electric services, in short, artificially stimulating demand for electricity by distorting the playing field? Is the Minister also aware that the penetration of solar hot water services in Queensland-a State which advertises itself as the Sunshine State-is less than one-fifth of what it is in Western Australia and that, accordingly, there is very considerable scope for reductions in electricity use in Queensland, thus avoiding the claimed necessity to build further power stations? Is the Minister aware that the Tully River presently serves a rafting tourist industry which sees 50,000 people a year enjoy the thrill of white water rafting, employs 100 people and generates $4m a year in revenue for the local economy and that this industry will disappear if the proposed Tully-Millstream hydroelectric scheme is built? Accordingly, will the Minister, as a matter of urgency, exercise her powers under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act to proclaim regulations which effectively proscribe all activities in the Wet Tropics World Heritage area which would be required to build the proposed Tully-Millstream hydroelectric scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter provided some notice of this question but, I am afraid, not in sufficient time for me to get a full response to each part of it. Therefore, I am unable to confirm that the Queensland Electricity Commission has been making special offers to developers for cut price services. I just do not know.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that Queensland advertises itself as the Sunshine State. Having just spent a week there, I think truth in advertising applies.
Senator Coulter says that penetration of solar in Queensland is only one-fifth of what it is in Western Australia. Again, I have not had time to confirm that. I will attempt to.

The honourable senator asked whether I was aware of the rafting industry on the Tully River. Yes, I am. I was not aware that it employs 100 people and generates $4m a year, but I will take his word for it. I think the last part of the question is the meat of the question: whether the Minister, as a matter of urgency, will exercise her powers to proclaim regulations which proscribe all activities that would be required for the building of the Tully-Millstream hydroelectric scheme. The situation is that the Queensland Government may well have received a report on this question, but as yet the Commonwealth has not received it. Until the Commonwealth receives that report, no investigation of the matter can possibly proceed.

I had indicated to the Premier of Queensland prior to the last election-it was early last year when I was environment Minister, but I cannot remember the date-that there was no preclusion of this kind of activity under the World Heritage Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 27 June 1989.

—I think it happened several times. I pointed out to the Premier the fairly obvious point that the Commonwealth would be prepared to consider the Tully-Millstream dam if and when it had been demonstrated to us that there was a real need for the power. At the time the Queensland Electricity Commission could point to a number of blackouts that had occurred-particularly in south-east Queensland-as a result of there not being enough power in the grid. It must be remembered that this dam is not a dam to supply power only to north Queensland, but one to supply power to the whole of the Queensland grid.

ANSWER.PARA: Until we get this report I am not sure how the Queensland Government investigated this matter, and I am sure that Mrs Kelly is not either. Obviously, the Commonwealth will keenly await the receipt of the report so that we can look at those questions to see whether it has indeed been demonstrated that there is a need for the power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. While the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is seeking that information from the Minister, will he also ask her-he may be able to inform us now-whether when Mrs Kelly appeared on the Couchman program almost a fortnight ago and, speaking about the World Heritage area and the wet tropics, said, `There is no logging in World Heritage areas' and said again, `No logging in those areas, full stop, amen', she in fact meant that there would be no logging; in other words, that the 1,400 hectares which will need to be logged for the main dam will not be logged and the dams will not be built? Is that what she meant?

—I am not certain of what Mrs Kelly said on the Couchman program. She is correct when she says that there is no logging in World Heritage areas-there is not. That is a pretty self-evident fact. As I said, however, the Convention itself does not preclude acts of economic necessity, as I think they are termed, although I would have to check on the words.
—It is like giving people a job that you took off them.

—Senator Bos- well is being very unfair. It is not big in the way that he is. I will certainly ask Mrs Kelly what she meant when she made those remarks on the Couchman program and will attempt to provide the honourable senator with an answer tomorrow.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services, is related to the attempt to ban freedom of speech in Australia. Will the Minister indicate what discussions he or any other member of the Government has had with the Australian Democrats about the proposed broadcasting ban? Was the proposal to increase the taxpayer subsidy to political parties for Senate elections to the same level as for House of Representatives elections always included in the Government's package, or did it arise during these discussions with the Democrats?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have spoken to and consulted with a number of people. The details of those discussions obviously, as in any normal decision-making process, have been wide ranging. There is nothing inherently bad about discussions with any part of the political process. I have had discussions with the Democrats and some other members of the Australian Labor Party have also had discussions with members of the Opposition. There have been two sorts of responses.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition Leader, for instance, wrote to us earlier this year making it very clear he would have absolutely no bar of any proposals in this area. I have been asked, `Where do you take a brick wall?', and that is precisely the sort of response we have had from the Opposition. In comparison with that, the discussions with the Democrats have proceeded fruitfully because of one premise-that is, a common understanding of the issues, a common concern to ensure that the political process is sanitised against political corruption, both currently and in the future, and an understanding of the issues that go to the heart of the democratic system. So we have had discussions; I do not shy away from that. But there is nothing in those discussions that would allude to any inference that Senator Macdonald would like to draw.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The second part of my question related to whether those decisions to increase the taxpayers' funds to political parties arose as part of those discussions with the Democrats, or were they part of the original proposal?

—The proposals have been developed over some months. Specifically in response to the question, the Senate should draw absolutely no inference as to how that particular part of the proposal came up. I have been concerned to ensure that this package addresses the problem forever. If matters arise-and matters do arise; they arise continually, daily-they are taken into account. That was one of the matters that were taken into account; a number of others were as well.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TREASURY
SENATE
(Question No. 165)
Senator Watson asked the Treasurer, upon notice on 11 September 1990:
(1) Has there been a recent ruling by the Taxation Commissioner following a Federal Court decision which will adversely affect the timber industry.

(2) Has the Taxation Commissioner ruled that the sale of free-standing timber is subject to capital gains tax and, therefore, are farmers holding pre-capital gains tax land now reluctant to sell their standing timber to logging companies as money received will be subject to tax.
(3) Is this ruling in direct contradiction of assurances given by the Treasurer in November 1986 that these sales would not face tax.
(4) Is this ruling legally and environmentally sound.
(5) Following this ruling has there been pressure to increase logging in national estate forests to compensate for the shortage of timber coming off private land.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation issued Taxation Ruling No. IT 2561 on 21 September 1989, following the decision of the Full Court of the Federal Court of Australia in Gray and Anor v. F.C. of T 89 ATC 4640. The effect of the Ruling is that the Commissioner considers the grant of a profit a prendre such as the grant of a right to remove standing timber (as opposed to the sale of the timber), constitutes the creation and disposal of an asset separate from the land affected by that right. The owner of the land may be liable to capital gains tax on any amount received in respect of the grant, irrespective of when the land was acquired.

The view differs from that conveyed by the Treasurer in November 1986 in reply to a parliamentary question. The Commissioner of Taxation then considered that such grants constituted a part disposal of the land, and so would not be brought to tax under the capital gains and losses provisions where the land was acquired before 20 September 1985. This opinion was based on the Commissioner's interpretation of the law at that time. The decision in Gray's case has caused the Commissioner to re-evaluate his previously stated position, and this is reflected in the Taxation Ruling.

As the honourable Senator will be aware, the Commissioner is required to apply the law as enacted by Parliament and interpreted by the courts. In recognition of the fact that the Commissioner had revised his previous interpretation in light of the court's decision, the application of the views contained in the Ruling was properly made prospective from the date of its release.

Whether the decision in Gray's case and the Commissioner's subsequent ruling has resulted in a reluctance by farmers to grant rights to take standing timber, with a corresponding long term increase in demand on national estate forests, cannot be concluded from the information presently available to the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 February and again on 6 March, Senator Harradine asked me several questions relating to the provision of child-care and the Government's policy in relation to that. I undertook to seek further information from the Minister. I have received further information and I seek leave to incorporate the answer I received in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Response:
1. The Government's primary objective in funding child care is to assist families with dependent children to participate in the workforce.

Nevertheless, the Government believes that all families should receive support and encouragement and provides them with considerable financial assistance. Most one income and many two income families receive family allowance, while low income working families may be eligible to receive the family allowance supplement. The dependent spouse rebate, which is not means tested, is also available in respect of a spouse who remains at home.

2. Child care is also available for non working families through the Government's child care strategies, particularly for needy families. Under the national child care strategy (NCCS) the Commonwealth is providing 2 000 new places dedicated to occasional care (non work related care), increasing the number of places dedicated to that form of care to around 7 000 by the end of 1992.

The 1990 election promise to further increase the supply of child care does not include any dedicated occasional care places. However, it does include 20 000 additional places in long day care centres and family day care schemes.
Non work related care is also available in long day care centres and in family day care
- the 1989 census of government-funded child care centres indicates that approximately 16% of care provided in long day care centres and 9% in family day care is for non-work related purposes;
accordingly, the provision of non work related care will continue to grow as the Government increases the supply of child care.

Senator Harradine's calculations of 6% of expenditure on occasional care in 1989-90 and 4.1% in 1990-91, relate only to expenditure on dedicated places. They do not therefore accurately reflect government outlays on this care type. His figures do not take account of expenditure on non work related care through long day care centres, both commercial and non profit, and family day care schemes.

3. Senator Harradine has asked if the Government has considered a voucher system for occasional care. The Government has considered and rejected this approach to funding child care on the grounds that it would not increase supply of care without a significant inflationary effect on fees and thus price low income families out of the market.

Existing government policy aims at improving supply through growth strategies funded jointly with the States/Territories and at providing fee relief through eligible service providers. Fee relief is available to non work related and work related users of eligible services and makes care affordable for families on low and middle incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 March, Senator Alston asked a question about the youth homeless allowance (YHA), which I have an answer to. In March 1991, 3,900 young people were receiving YHA from the Department. Over the 12-month period from February 1990 to February 1991, the number of homeless young people receiving YHA from the Department of Social Security increased from 2,300 to that figure, an increase of 72 per cent. Since mid-1989, the numbers have almost doubled. In the 1990 academic year, some 5,500 young people aged under 18 years were granted Austudy at the homeless rate. The figures are encouraging because they show that more young people now receive the payments to which they are entitled. We have also improved the service they get from my Department.

ANSWER.PARA: I acknowledge, however, that there are many young people whom we are not yet reaching. Because we know many homeless youth have trouble dealing with bureaucracies, my Department has taken a number of steps in conjunction with other Commonwealth departments to develop information better tailored to meet their needs. We intend to do even more to help them understand and deal with our procedures, particularly when they have to establish proof of identity, which is often raised as a major barrier to responding quickly to their needs.

Further, we are undertaking some pilot projects. In Victoria, for example, specialist youth officers have been appointed in four regional offices. In Sydney we are experimenting with getting out of the office and providing services to young people in hostels and drop-in centres. Since the Burdekin report, we have reduced waiting periods, increased rates and introduced an independent rate of job search allowance. However, the Government acknowledges that there is still much more to be done so that the lives of homeless youth can be made less difficult. I regard that area as a priority in my portfolio.
