DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF Rt Hon. SIR JOHN KERR, AK, GCMG, GCVO, QC

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 24 March 1991, of the Right Honourable Sir John Kerr, AK GCMG GCVO QC, Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia from 1974 to 1977. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 24 March 1991, of the Rt Hon. Sir John Robert Kerr, former Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia from 1974 to 1977, and Chief Justice of New South Wales from 1972 to 1974, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

John Robert Kerr was born on 24 September 1914 at Balmain, New South Wales, and educated at Fort Street High School. He studied law at Sydney University and had a brilliant academic record. He was admitted to the New South Wales bar in 1938, but temporarily suspended his legal career in 1942 when he joined the army. Until 1945 he was involved in intelligence work with the wartime Directorate of Research and Civil Affairs. Nineteen forty-six saw him appointed first Principal of the Australian School of Pacific Administration and then Organising Secretary of the South Pacific Commission.

He resumed his legal career in Sydney in 1948, specialising in industrial law. His career continued to prosper and he took silk in 1953. During the 1960s he held several public offices, including President of the New South Wales Bar Association, President of the Law Council of Australia and President of the Law Association for Asia and the Western Pacific.

He transferred to Canberra in 1966 and until 1972 was a judge in the Commonwealth Industrial Court and the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory. He was also a judge in the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory from 1970 to 1972. His distinguished tenure as Chief Justice of New South Wales from 1972 to 1974 included a review and update of the New South Wales court structure. In 1973 he was appointed Lieutenant-Governor of New South Wales and on 27 February 1974 he was appointed Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia.

Sir John Kerr was an active and energetic Governor-General who took a genuine interest in people from all walks of life. He travelled widely throughout the country and promoted vigorously Australia's interests abroad. His dismissal of the Whitlam Government in 1975 will remain a matter of debate in this country for as long as politics is discussed. Sir John was a prominent Australian whose interests were diverse and varied. Outside the legal profession he was involved with organisations dealing with subjects such as copyright, medicine and the armed services. He also took a personal interest in, and had a strong concern for, Aboriginal issues.

Throughout his public life Sir John maintained an active interest and involvement in the Asia-Pacific region, especially in Papua New Guinea. He made a contribution towards enhancing Australia's role in the region and will be missed by his many friends in the region. He received a number of overseas distinctions, including honorary life membership of the Law Society of England and Wales and honorary membership of the American Bar Association.

The high regard in which he was held was also reflected in the many honours bestowed upon him throughout his long career in public service. He was made a Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George in 1966, a Knight Commander of that Order in 1974 and a Knight Grand Cross in 1976. He was also made a Knight of the Order of Australia in 1976.
Mr President, on behalf of the Gov- ernment, I extend sincere sympathy to his wife and to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Opposition senators, I support the motion of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) to express our sincere regret at the death of Sir John Kerr on 24 March at the age of 76. He is entitled to be remembered for his lifetime of public service. Senator Button has outlined to the chamber today some of that long and meritorious service.

SPEECH.PARA: In any review of the life of Sir John Kerr it would be easy to focus on the constitutional crisis of 1975 but this was a small part of a life marked by many outstanding achievements, both academic and professional. Sir John Kerr was a man of distinction in many fields. As was mentioned by Senator Button, he was an outstanding student academically, first at Fort Street Boys High School and later at the University of Sydney.

In 1942, already a brilliant lawyer, having been admitted to the Bar of New South Wales four years earlier, he joined the Army as Private Kerr. Almost immediately he went to work for the Directorate of Research and Civil Affairs and, once again, was outstandingly successful. He eventually rose to the rank of lieutenant-colonel. He became the first Principal of the Australian School of Pacific Administration when he left the Army in 1945. In 1948 he became Organising Secretary of the South Pacific Commission. In 1948 he returned to the legal profession and within five years was made a King's Counsel. John Kerr had always been deeply involved in politics and was widely known as a Labor lawyer until he resigned from the Australian Labor Party in 1956.

Thereafter, he was involved with an extraordinarily diverse range of activities in the 1950s and 1960s: President of the New South Wales Bar Association; Vice-President of the Law Council of Australia and subsequently its President; foundation President of Lawasia, the Law Association for Asia and the Western Pacific; President of the Industrial Relations Society, which I think he helped found; and a high office-bearer in organisations dealing with an amazingly diverse range of subjects. After six years as a judge with the Commonwealth Industrial Court and the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory, in 1972 he was appointed the Chief Justice of New South Wales. His knighthood was conferred in January 1974. He was appointed Governor-General in 1974 by the Whitlam Government.

Of course, this period in Australia's history was extraordinary, culminating in the use by Sir John Kerr of the reserve powers of the Crown to dismiss the Whitlam Government in 1975. His actions in that decision-making process are, and remain, the focus of much debate today. However, it should be remembered that this was not a constitutional crisis of Sir John Kerr's making. He had a function under the Constitution to make certain decisions to preserve constitutional government at that time, which decisions he made to dismiss the Prime Minister, who could not get Supply but who was not in those circumstances prepared to put himself before the people and go to an election.

The dismissal was on the basis that the new Prime Minister would immediately call an election, which duly occurred, and the people clearly vindicated the decision of Sir John Kerr. There is no doubt that the reserve powers of the Crown are a difficult area of constitutional law. There will always remain room for debate on their interpretation and their exercise. However, as we look back at the career of Sir John Kerr, it is important to remember that in that very difficult circumstance he was one who did his duty-a duty that the high office of Governor-General imposed a responsibility to fulfil.

He behaved thereafter, I might say, with immeasurable dignity in the face of a most vicious and unrelenting campaign of personal vilification. That vilification is something that I, as an Australian, and my Party very much regret.

Sir John Kerr's many exceptional qualities were spoken of by his friends at his memorial service last weekend. He will be remembered privately as a warm and gentle man who was devoted to his family. Publicly, we should remember him as an outstanding Australian whose achievements throughout his lifetime are worthy of our deepest admiration and respect. On behalf of the Opposition senators, I extend to Sir John's widow and his children our most sincere condolences in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia in the Senate, I wish to express our deepest sympathy on the death of Sir John Kerr. Sir John had a distinguished career in both the law and public administration. The list of his contributions to Australian public life covers a wide range. During and after the Second World War he was active in shaping Australia's policy in the Pacific. In 1948 he returned to the legal profession, becoming a Queen's Counsel-in those days it was a King's Counsel-in 1953. He held many executive positions in Australian legal associations, including President of the New South Wales Bar Association, President of the Law Council of Australia and foundation President of the Law Association for Asia and the Western Pacific.

SPEECH.PARA: As a judge he served on the Commonwealth Industrial Court and the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory, having been appointed in 1966. He also served as a judge of the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory. In 1972 he was appointed Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of New South Wales and he is credited with bringing many reforms into its administration. Sir John was appointed a Commander of St Michael and St George in 1966 and a Knight of St Michael and St George in 1974.

His appointment as Governor-General on 27 February 1974, although unknown to him at the time, was to see his involvement in an era that became a difficult period in Australia's constitutional history. It was in the Senate chamber, on 11 July 1974, that Sir John Kerr was sworn in as Governor-General. As history now records, it was in the Senate where the constitutional power was implemented which led to the events that were to surround Sir John Kerr with controversy for the rest of his life. In this unprecedented time in Federal political history, Sir John Kerr was duty-bound in the circumstances-and he was a man of duty. To do what the Governor-General was appointed to do-to uphold the Australian Constitution-must have involved a gigantic personal struggle for Sir John, with his Labor background. To make the decision in the exercise of his reserve power as Her Majesty's representative must have required enormous personal courage, as later events have revealed.

Sir John Kerr did not create the situation which he felt duty-bound to resolve. The principle of the preservation of the powers of the Parliament over the executive arm of government will always be the basis of our parliamentary democracy. Sir John Kerr always acted with great dignity. His book on the controversial times, Matters for Judgment, published in 1978, as time passes and history assesses, will no doubt form a valuable account of this major event in Australian parliamentary and constitutional history.

On the passing of Sir John Kerr it would only be fitting to refer to his interest in and contributions to law reform, his skills in advocacy and his positive achievements in relation to the Australia-Pacific region. To have achieved so much in a lifetime is his testimony. On behalf of the National Party in the Senate, I extend my sympathy to Lady Kerr and his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). Sir John Kerr was Governor-General of this country from 1974 to 1977. His distinguished career in the law and his receipt of many honours throughout his life have been outlined by earlier speakers. He is remembered by many. In particular he is remembered in New South Wales for his significant contribution as Chief Justice of that State in the years preceding his appointment to the governor-generalship.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to look at that career as it was outlined in the editorial of the Melbourne Age upon his appointment, because in the case of Sir John Kerr all too often it is clear that events in his life post-1975 achieved greater prominence than events before that time. It is worth remembering what was said in the Age:
His career has been remarkable, at times even controversial-
that was in 1974-

. . . a brilliant student, a youthful colonel on Blamey's staff in New Guinea, first principal of the School of Pacific Studies, adviser to Australia's first United Nations delegation, organising secretary of the South Pacific Commission, prominent industrial advocate at the NSW Bar, Federal judge, member of the Trade Practices Tribunal and in charge of several Federal committees of inquiry. His other interests and offices have spanned professional associations, marriage guidance, the theatre, industrial relations and cultural freedom.

The Age in its editorial expected Sir John to serve in his new post with distinction and flair. Then we may look at the comments of Sir John himself upon his resignation in 1977. He described his period as Governor-General as the most stimulating and challenging in his life and pointed out that he felt that the first three years of his Governor-Generalship had crowded in such action and experience as would be exceptional if spread over a much longer period of tenure. That was his comment on his resignation.

As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said, and as Senator Button has said in this place, his actions in dismissing the Whitlam Government will remain a matter of debate for as long as politics are discussed in this country. This was a man who found his role stimulating and challenging, a man who had a distinguished career, as I have said, in the law and who received many honours. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I express our condolences to the family of the late Sir John Kerr.

TALK.START.PARA: —The best that I can say about John Kerr is that he was probably less culpable than either Malcolm Fraser or Garfield Barwick. When he resigned as Governor-General, he did not backdate the letter seven years as Barwick did when he resigned from the board of Mundroola Pty Ltd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pay tribute to the life and work of Sir John Kerr. Sir John could be fairly called, in my view, a great Australian. Through no fault of his own, he was at the centre of the most dramatic constitutional crisis in our history. Sir John Kerr is entitled to the epithet `great' because of his courage and judgment. By the application of proper constitutional principles, he brought about a resolution of the serious crisis in which we found ourselves in 1975. Sir John Kerr would not be intimidated either by the bullying of a Prime Minister or the braying of the mob. On leaving public office, Sir John was subjected to unprecedented venom and rancour, which were heaped on him by those who were incapable of understanding the real essence of 1975. The restraint with which he conducted himself in the years since, despite immense provocation, revealed a man of great inner strength and dignity.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent days I have had the opportunity to read about the 1975 crisis again, including commentaries by Manning Clark, Donald Horne's Death of the Lucky Country and, of course, Sir John Kerr's own book, Matters for Judgment. All of those who lived through those dramatic times of October and November 1975 will have formed strong views on the issues and individuals directly involved in the crisis. The decade and a half which has passed has allowed us all to develop a clearer perspective on the significance of those events. For example, I think there is widespread acceptance now that Sir John Kerr's actions were soundly based on constitutional principles.
It is of some significance that a former Whitlam Minister, John Wheeldon, has also argued:
Any government functioning under the Westminster system that tries to hold on to office without having its Budget accepted by Parliament for as long as we did ought to have been dismissed.

John Wheeldon in the same article pointed out that Senator Ken Wriedt, Australian Labor Party Leader in the Senate, also believed that rather than following Whitlam's course of `toughing it out', the Government should have sought a double dissolution as soon as possible.

The debate over the crisis in 1975 now seems to focus on whether Sir John should have given some prior warning to Mr Whitlam. Sir John Kerr in his book Matters for Judgment looks closely at this issue and, in my view, correctly argues that such an action would not only have been improper but, given the then Prime Minister's attitudes, would have led to a further deepening of the crisis.

I believe that Sir John Kerr strengthened our democracy by ensuring that the people were called upon to determine a deadlock between the Houses. He reaffirmed a vital principle of responsible government-that no government can carry on without supply where supply is denied by an elected House with the constitutional power to do so. As a result, he ensured that no executive government in Australia will now ever again assume that it is above the Parliament. To my mind, he showed the strength rather than the weakness of our system of government. The reserve powers of the Governor-General can be a great force for democracy. As the great Canadian constitutional expert, Dr Eugene Forsey, has observed:
The reserve power is indeed, under our Constitution, an absolutely essential safeguard of democracy.
He went on:

It is the rubber stamp theory which is undemocratic. It makes existing governments irremovable, except by their own consent. Such a doctrine is a travesty of democracy. It delivers every Opposition gagged and bound into the hands of its opponents.

In paying tribute to Sir John Kerr there are two particular observations I would like to make to the Senate today. The first is that Sir John Kerr's decision in November 1975 was not only correct legally but it has also stood the test of time. How often were we told in the months, indeed years, following the 1975 crisis that Australian democracy had been irretrievably damaged. A number of our prominent academics and lawyers made comments which bordered on the hysterical. We were on the point of revolution; Australia would become a polarised society; our political institutions had been damaged beyond repair. These were typical of the arguments that were widely canvassed.

From the perspective of 1991, we can see how foolish these predictions were, and how wrong. Were our institutions damaged? The standing of the Senate, if anything, has risen in public esteem. Most people continue to support its role, as evidenced by the electoral rejection of constitutional proposals which may have diminished it. Was the office of Governor-General damaged? Was the monarchy damaged? Donald Horne argued that Australia had become a `Governor-Generalate'. The office of Governor-General holds the respect and affection of our people. One of the major participants in the 1975 crisis, Bill Hayden, was honoured to accept this position. There was probably more discussion about republicanism in 1890 than in 1990. Was the Labor Party destroyed? Let us recall that Donald Horne told us:
It was not only the Labor Party that was being destroyed but the sense of trust of hundreds of thousands of Australians.

The Australian Labor Party itself quickly recovered and within eight years of the dismissal returned to government. In the 1980s it achieved a political dominance in both the Federal and State arenas that it had never accomplished before and, we hope, will never accomplish again.
Were the people alienated from our system? Donald Horne spoke of the `extreme alienation of many Australians from their own political system'. Manning Clark told us:
December 13 1975 will go down in history as the day which converted the radicals from the ballot box to industrial action, from Parliament to direct action.

If anything, those who like to call themselves progressives have spent much of the last decade bemoaning the lack of radical activity among our youth in the 1980s compared with the 1960s. Sir John Kerr understood far more clearly what was at stake in 1975 than the Manning Clarks and the Donald Hornes. He made the point in his book:

A significant point about 1975 is that we were confronted by the prospect of a disaster which did not occur. The very real dangers that threatened were avoided at the last moment. In the result it is now difficult to remember how truly threatening that crisis was. We can remember terrible tragedies, depressions and wars which actually happened but it is harder to remember crises which would have been disastrous had they happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: there is ample opportunity on the adjournment debate for Senator Kemp to give his views on the whole range of constitutional and political issues. It is not appropriate in a condolence motion; it is not appropriate at all.
—Order! There is no point of order. There is no restriction on what Senator Kemp can say during this debate.

—I thank you, Mr President, and I think it is appalling that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, knowing that there was not a point of order, chose to rise on this particular occasion. Sir John continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The blade may pass within a millimetre, but we will not remember it, because it did not strike. It now requires a positive act of imagination as well as of memory to appreciate how frightening the crisis would have been had things gone really wrong in 1975. The ultimate reason why our stability was not undermined is that the disaster was not allowed to happen.
It has to be said that the behaviour of some of our leading people and academics during and after 1975 shows once again how wise the Australian people are to hold their views so lightly.

The second and concluding observation I wish to make relates to the behaviour of Sir John Kerr's detractors in the last decade and a half. Interestingly, in the same article by John Wheeldon which I quoted, he commences with a comment about another famous dismissal-that of Lord Melbourne by King William in 1834. He pointed out that Lord Melbourne and his colleagues were clearly annoyed with the King's actions but accepted their fate with little fuss, and John Wheeldon said:
It seems that they assumed, rightly, that the Tories who took their place would not last forever.

`I hate to be considered ill-used', Melbourne told one of his women friends. `I have always thought complaints of ill-usage contemptible, whether from a seduced, disappointed girl or a turned-out prime minister'.

Coming from a former Whitlam Minister, John Wheeldon's comments are particularly interesting and no doubt are causing great embarrassment to Senator Schacht. Mr Whitlam clearly felt ill used. Along with former Senator Jim McClelland, he led one of the most contemptible attacks on an individual in Australian political history.

I can think of no other public figure who has been subjected to such long lasting and malicious abuse. I invite honourable senators to read Hansard of early 1978, which records for posterity the bitterness, meanness and viciousness of the attacks on Sir John Kerr. It was interesting that Manning Clark on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation 7.30 Report last week suggested that members of the Labor movement:
. . . were very vindictive with him and, whether they were right and morally justified in doing that it is for them to decide. It was not a very pleasant sight the way they hounded him.

While we welcome his more moderate statements today, it has to be said that Manning Clark's own extravagant pamphleteering on behalf of Whitlam helped encourage the vindictive attitudes shown towards Sir John Kerr.

Debate about great public events will inevitably continue but this is different from hounding the participants in those events. It has generally been the practice in Australia and indeed in all great democracies that our leaders, once they retire from public office, should be allowed to resume their lives free of persecution and hounding by their opponents.

Let it be said that all of us in this chamber have a great personal interest in this convention. It is a sad fact of political life that few, if any, politicians leave high office without having offended at least some powerful interest groups or individuals. One of the costs of 1975 was that any future Governor-General, Governor, Prime Minister or High Court judge who is faced with a public issue of great controversy may well have in his mind not only the clear arguments in favour or against a particular action but must now weigh them against the nagging thought that the behaviour meted out to Sir John Kerr may well be his lot as well. We can only hope that he or she will have the strength of character of Sir John Kerr.

Sir John Kerr never stooped to the level of his detractors. The article written by a former judge, Kenneth Gee, and published in the Weekend Australian recently, showed the real qualities of the man who will go down in history as a great Governor-General. At Sir John Kerr's greatest test, the words of Martin Luther in 1521 seem appropriate:
On this I take my stand, I can do no other.

Jim McClelland and the others who followed his example could not understand this simple principle. The principle is this: given the choice between duty to a political party and duty to the nation, there are men who recognise the higher loyalty. Sir John Kerr was such a man. It is therefore appropriate that we honour his memory today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to associate myself with this motion of condolence. I support the words of my colleague from Victoria, Senator Kemp. He has put the case extraordinarily well. There is no doubt that in 1975 Sir John Kerr was faced with an extraordinarily difficult task; one which few Governor-Generals have had to face. He acted constitutionally and took what is now acknowledged-by most of those who understand what the subject is all about-to be the only course that was then open to him. However, for doing that, he was hounded by such people as former Senator McClelland and a number of others. I remember the way they spoke in 1978 in this chamber and it was shameful to hear them talking about someone who had been a former colleague. As I understand it, the major problem with Senator McClelland-he had his other own personal problems-was that he recommended the appointment of Sir John to Mr Whitlam and he certainly spoke foully about Sir John Kerr.

SPEECH.PARA: But then that haranguing continued, and the media had much to do with that. The media, which was brought up under their university socialist lecturers of the 1950s and 1960s to believe all was good, right and proper on the side of the Australian Labor Party and all was wrong with anyone who opposed in any way any of the actions of the Australian Labor Party, continued to hound Sir John. I would like to say to his family that it is my firm belief that the silent majority was strongly in favour of what he had done, as they proved in the election of 1975. The silent majority remained in support of his actions then and the silent majority have had sympathy for him ever since then. I am sure that many of them, like me, were upset and distressed to read and see in some of the newspapers and television productions the media continuing, even after his death, to harangue this fine Australian.

Today, the debate on this constitutional matter is not whether or not a Governor-General should have the powers that he had and exercised, because that is acknowledged on all sides, but how to ensure that a Governor-General, who has these reserve powers and who retains all the powers that he has today-whether that be under a system such as it is at the present moment with a monarchy, or whether it be under an independent republic of Australia-in the future is able to retain his independence from the Prime Minister of the day. Of course, that is the crucial factor that will occur in any debate about future constitutional alterations in relation to the position of Governor-General of Australia.

One of the interesting points I wish to raise is that my leader today mentioned Sir John's lifetime of public service. I was told that Sir John wanted to continue to serve Australia and had asked for an appointment that would enable him to continue to serve Australians and his nation. He was offered the appointment at UNESCO and that same group of people-that same media-hounded him so much in this country that ultimately he felt that he had to decline the offer. What a tragedy that was because he did not really understand, in my view, that there were just so many people in the community who felt that he was a fine person who was being unfairly hounded. I certainly wish to offer my sympathy to his widow and his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate myself with this condolence motion and speak in support of other remarks that have been made by my colleagues on this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button read the curriculum vitae of Sir John Kerr which showed what a fine man of the law Sir John was. In addition to the contribution that he made to the legal profession, he was an Australian who was called upon to serve his nation in a way that most lawyers are not. He was asked to make the decision which showed that our Constitution worked. He made a decision that was correct in law and right for Australia. When he ended the loans affair scandal and sacked the Government and sent the politicians to the electorate-which concurred with Sir John Kerr's decision-there was a landslide victory for Malcolm Fraser. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in this condolence motion. On Saturday I attended the memorial service for Sir John Kerr at St James Church in Sydney. I was heartened to see a considerable number of present and former parliamentary colleagues attending that service. In particular, I was heartened to see the Governor-General, Mr Hayden; the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke; and the Deputy President, Senator Colston-all members of the Australian Labour Party-attending that service and I commend them for their attendance.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the pleasure of meeting Sir John on several occasions in recent years, particularly when attending dinners organised by the Australian Association for Cultural Freedom. At those dinners I certainly had the opportunity to recognise his intellect and, of course, become aware of his deep integrity.

What must be remembered at this time of remembrance of Sir John Kerr is that the constitutional crisis was created by politicians but, particularly, by two political leaders. The rights and wrongs of their actions rest with them. The issue was created by them. What had to be resolved lawfully and constitutionally by the Governor-General was, in fact, resolved with courage and integrity, and resolved totally correctly. To seek to divert any animus about the outcome of that disagreement and to try to divert responsibility for the perceived wrongs of that event to the person who resolved the problem is, of course, disgraceful.

Creating a figure of hatred is an ancient political device used cynically to remove intellectual effort and honest debate. Hitler used it to effect against the Jews in pre-war Germany. Sir John Kerr's death has removed such a cynically created hate figure from the Australian scene and, hopefully, political debate will now proceed at a higher intellectual level, free of the sort of animus that was disgracefully and deliberately created around the figure of Sir John Kerr, the man who acted with proprietary and decency. My hopes are that political debate can now proceed free of that animus. At times today I fear that that may not be so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak on this condolence motion. I have had only a limited time in the Senate. Therefore, I had a particular view of what a condolence motion was meant to be. After hearing the condolence speeches of the leaders of the various parties I thought that that would be about it, but after hearing the speech of Senator Kemp--
—How about Walsh's speech? Did you hear that too?

—I heard Senator Walsh's speech, and if Senator Kemp had listened to it very carefully he would have heard that it was extremely brief, and he did not blame Sir John Kerr for being the person mainly culpable for the events of 1975. Senator Kemp may not agree with his remarks about the Chief Justice, but his remarks were extremely brief.

SPEECH.PARA: What I found interesting was that Senator Kemp read from a very long speech. Clearly, irrespective of what Senator Walsh had said, Senator Kemp was going to say what he did in fact say, and had prepared to say it many hours beforehand. I heard his speech, in which he used a condolence motion as the basis to vent his spleen against politicians formerly serving in this Parliament, and I believe that he is the one who went way beyond the bounds of what is normally a condolence motion and was starting to debate the events of 1975. Therefore, I do not believe that some of those remarks can go unanswered on the record.

I agree with Senator Walsh that Sir John Kerr did not make the crisis in 1975. That was made by the conservative senators in this chamber who chose to follow the direction of Malcolm Fraser not in defeating or blocking supply, but in deferring it. They did not have enough votes to actually block it. All they could do was adjourn the debate, and that is certainly on the record. To say that the Parliament blocked supply is factually incorrect.

Former Senator Jessop made it quite clear on the public record that if the matter had gone on for another week before the Governor-General had intervened, he would have changed his vote, and the Australian Labour Party Government only needed one Opposition senator to change the vote for the Budget to be carried. One could argue that Sir John's intervention-at a time before Supply had actually run out, even though it had been deferred-was precipitant but that is a matter of judgment, to use the title of Sir John's own book. I agree with some of the remarks made by senators opposite that the blame resides with the politicians, and resides overwhelmingly with the members of the Senate who chose to defer the Budget.

I would also say that there is one area where I think Sir John can be criticised with considerable merit. I understand that in the House of Representatives today a former independent Liberal senator in this chamber, Mr Steele Hall, now the Liberal member for Boothby, pointed this out. In fact, Sir John's error as the vice-regal representative was that he did not warn and counsel the Prime Minister of the action he might take.

Some people have said in this debate that Sir John was afraid that Mr Whitlam would take other action. But whatever action he was afraid of, it is quite clear that according to an all constitutional convention-if one goes back to Bagehot and other British constitutional experts who have been quoted, and the 1834 example of Lord Melbourne-the power of the vice regal representative is to warn and counsel the Prime Minister, or the leader of the government represented in the Parliament. That is something Sir John did not do. I think that is the major error that can clearly be seen in his actions; but that is only after the blame must be sheeted to where it resides absolutely-and that is on the Opposition side of the chamber in 1975.

I think that the debates that will take place in the 1990s-and there is some indication that even conservative members of this Parliament, such as Mr John Howard and Dr Hewson, are now willing to think, for the first time, about constitutional change-leading to the centenary of our Federation, will look at the issue of how our Constitution works and at the role and responsibility of the Governor- General. As Senator Austin Lewis quite rightly points out, even if we had a republic and a president, the president's powers would have to be defined. In my view, they would have to be made explicit so that everybody knew exactly what the ground rules were. In my view, that would be a very sensible constitutional amendment that we should all consider, because the events of 1975 may occur again. Who knows-the next time around Senator Kemp's side may be on the receiving end of the powers of the Senate against the democratically elected majority in the lower House. As some people say quite cynically, the only time at which conservatives in Australia will be willing to consider appropriate amendments to the operation of this Constitution may be when those opposite pay the penalty, as the Whitlam Government did in 1975.

I believe that the events of 1975 will not be repeated because enough conservatives got a shock at the reaction in the community to realise that ripping up the conventions is just not worth the risk. I do not think those events will occur again, but I do not believe we should say to the Australian community that we should ignore the need for constitutional change in this country. I believe that the centenary of Federation, 1 January 2001, is the date that we should aim at for having achieved major reform of our Constitution-100 years on from its establishment. I make no bones about the fact that I would like to see a republic declared on that day, with a president, with codified and clearly defined powers which will ensure, above all else, that the Senate does not have the irresponsible power to bring down a democratically elected government in the lower House.

I was not aiming to speak on this condolence motion but others on the other side have used the opportunity to go on at some length. In conclusion, I take this opportunity to say that the family of Sir John Kerr has my sympathy. In a country such as Australia, which is a democracy, despite any number of events, I do not believe that people on any side of politics relish or welcome the death of anybody as a resolution of a political difficulty or a way of getting even for a previous political event. I am certainly not one of those and, therefore, I pass my sympathy to the family of Sir John Kerr. The leaders of the various parties who spoke to this condolence motion spoke appropriately, but it is unfortunate that after that-led by Senator Kemp and his ilk-the debate degenerated into a rehash of 1975.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join my colleagues in expressing my condolences to Lady Kerr on the death of Sir John Kerr. There can be no greater accolade given to any man than for it to be said of him that he was a great and courageous Australian and a loving and much loved father and husband. This he certainly was. Lady Kerr must be very proud of her husband, knowing full well that, although his decision in the 1975 crisis was a controversial one, no-one-I repeat no-one-has ever challenged the validity of his actions. Sir John knew that the course he took was correct, as did every other Australian. If this was not so his actions would have been challenged in the courts: they never were.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir John Kerr's credentials for his appointment as Governor-General were impeccable, as the then Prime Minister's statement prior to Sir John's appointment showed. That statement outlined Sir John's career until 1974. It read:

It is announced today from Government House, Canberra, that Her Majesty the Queen has graciously approved the appointment of the Hon. Sir John Kerr, k.c.m.g., to be Governor-General of Australia. He will take up office at the end of June this year when the present Governor-General, Sir Paul Hasluck, relinquishes his appointment.

Sir John has been Chief Justice of New South Wales and Lieutenant-Governor since 1972. He has had a distinguished career in both the law and public administration. After war service with the Second A.I.F., Sir John was the first Principal of the Australian School of Pacific Administration. He then followed a distinguished career at the Bar in New South Wales, becoming a Queen's Counsel in 1953. In 1966 he was appointed a Judge of the Commonwealth Industrial Court and a Judge of the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory. He has also served as a Judge of the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory and has held other Australian judicial commissions.

Sir John has held a number of executive positions in the legal profession, including President of the New South Wales Bar Association, President of the Law Council of Australia and foundation President of the Law Association of Asia and the Western Pacific. He has also served on a number of Government bodies, including, in 1968 as Chairman of the Committee on Review of Administration Decisions, and in 1970 as Chairman of the Committee on Review of Pay for the Armed Services. In 1971 he conducted an inquiry into the salaries and allowances of Members of the Australian Parliament.

Sir John was appointed c.m.g. in 1966 and k.c.m.g. this year. Sir John's significant attainments in the field of law and administration have given him a familiarity with Australian Government and State Government affairs and he is of course, well known throughout Australia. All Australians will join me in congratulating Sir John and welcoming him and Lady Kerr to their high appointments.

It is extremely disappointing to me that the Australian media has focused on, and indeed distorted, the private family fune- ral held prior to the memorial service last Saturday and claimed that Sir John was lonely, friendless and a recluse. A close friend of Sir John, Mr Donald Markwell, in his eulogy, laid that claim to rest when he said:

The man I knew was a man who enjoyed life; one whose seriousness was balanced by a buoyant sense of humour and fun-a man who rejoiced in the joy of life. He was no exile, no embittered recluse. In a crisis not of his making he had done his duty as he saw it, conscientiously and courageously, even though he knew he would suffer for it.

That was the description from a very close friend. His son, Phillip, told of a loving father who had given his children a love of history. Phillip said, `It is history that will ultimately pass judgment on his life'. History, of course, will relate that the Australian people overwhelmingly supported his action on that day in forcing a Government which had no respect for the Constitution of the land to behave according to that Constitution. He did this, as we all know, by dismissing the Government and sending it to the people for judgment. That judgment was made in such overwhelming numbers that the Fraser Government was elected with a greater majority than had occurred at any other time in our history. That was the judgment of the people. My deepest sympathies are with Lady Kerr and her family in their tragic loss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to briefly associate myself with the motion of condolence on the death of Sir John Kerr and to extend to his widow and family my deep sympathy at this time of sadness for them and for countless other Australians. I think it is unfortunate that most of the concentration of attention on Sir John Kerr has been on the events of 1975. To focus attention on those is to lose the perspective of Sir John's extraordinarily rich, diverse and notable career for many years before that. His career has been chronicled very well here today and I do not propose to go over it again.

SPEECH.PARA: The events of 1975 occurred at a time when I first came into this Parliament, as did Senator Baume and some other colleagues. The events preceding and following 1975 were of considerable trauma in Australian history and Australian political processes. At that time we had a situation where the Government of the day was a government which, when in Opposition, led by the Prime Minister of 1975, had tried to block supply in this place in 1970. In 1975 the Government placed the Governor-General-who had, of course, been appointed by Prime Minister Whit- lam-in a precarious situation by refusing to call an election.

It is now a matter of historical record and fact that there is no doubt at all that the action of the Governor-General in 1975 was taken to enable him to protect the Australian democratic system of government. There can be no doubt that the action taken at that time was constitutionally and legally correct. It was extreme, but it was the only possible action that Sir John could have taken in the circumstances, given the responsibilities of his position. He took that action only after great personal consideration and agony. He did the only thing that he and the great majority of other Australians believed to be correct and possible, although not popular. Subsequently, the Australian electors, when given the opportunity to exercise their democratic vote, confirmed the correctness of his decision by electing the Liberal and National Party coalition in a record landslide.

There are four words or phrases that have been used already in this debate that I have always seen as epitomising Sir John Kerr. The first is `intellect'; the second is `integrity'; the third is `courage'; and the fourth is `correctness of approach and action taken'. Sir John acted at all times in the true spirit of a great Governor-General. He acted for the good of all Australians. He acted to protect our cherished democratic freedoms. He did so at great personal cost and under great pressure at the time. He will, of course, be remembered in an indifferent light by some, but I really do believe that history will record his actions and his life in a much more favourable light.

I hope I am never again faced with the situation which I experienced in the House of Representatives in the post-1975 years of seeing a man so wrongly vilified and attacked, particularly in 1978, as was referred to earlier today. It was an ongoing attack that lasted for many years and it was a great blight on those who perpetrated it.

My hope is that no government will ever again act to attempt to bypass the due processes of parliament and our Constitution, that no government will again act to force the Senate to use its considerable powers to trigger a constitutional crisis, as the Government at that time did, compelling the Governor-General to dismiss that Government. Any person in such a position should not be forced into that situation in order to allow the Australian people to have their democratic say. The fact that the Governor-General was forced to exercise that responsibility and the way in which he exercised it showed a very great action of a very cour- ageous man. I join all those on both sides of this chamber in extending my deep sympathy to Sir John's family at this sad time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to speak to this motion of condolence on the death of Sir John Kerr. I observe that Sir John was required to resolve, in my view, what was a political crisis, not a constitutional crisis. There was never a constitutional crisis. There was always an obvious solution. The solution that was not immediately available to the Governor-General, of course, was of the political crisis and that was caused by the nature of a vain and arrogant Prime Minister leading a government that did not understand that it could not govern without supply.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect that there is not a contemporary, objective commentator who would sensibly take the view that Sir John Kerr did not have the power to do that which he was ultimately required to do. The problem for the Government of that day was that it either did not understand or it ignored the role of the Senate. Perhaps that was manifested by the fact that when the Prime Minister was returning from Government House having been dismissed, he even forgot to tell the Leader of the Government in the Senate at the time, Senator Ken Wriedt, that he had been sacked. Of course, that led to the passing of supply. But it was an example of the contemptuous attitude that the Government had to the bicameral system of government. That arrogance was reflected in the Government's conduct during and subsequent to that time.

It has never been made clear to me what this Government would have had the Governor-General do. Presumably it would have had him do absolutely nothing and it would have allowed this country to sink inexorably into a political and social imbroglio, the pain of which we would still be feeling now. The Governor-General was obliged to resolve the political crisis by resorting-as he properly did-to the constitutional provisions, which were simply to appoint a Prime Minister who could guarantee supply and then promptly call an election.

The problem for the Government of the day was that it thought that because Sir John Kerr was its appointment, that made him its person and that because he was its person, he would have compromised his principles and his position and he would do as it wanted, irrespective of whether it was right or wrong. Of course, he showed enormous courage and the integrity which caused him to be appointed in the first place and he did what had to be done with a great deal of dignity.

The political emotions that ran from the Australian Labor Party following that event sadly showed, in a naked sense, the real nature of some of the members of that Party. I suspect-with the exception of one person who spoke today-that there would not be anyone who would be properly proud of that Government's response and its conduct following that decision when its members reflected the way they did on the Governor-General and not on their own shortcomings.

Of course, we all know that there are those in the Labor Party who are great haters. They demonstrated that well from the point of their dismissal to the day of the death of Sir John Kerr. I offer my condolence to his family.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF Rt Hon. VISCOUNT DE L'ISLE, VC, KG, GCMG, GCVO

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 5 April 1991, of the Right Honourable Viscount De L'Isle, VC, KG, GCMG, GCVO, Governor-General for the Commonwealth of Australia from 1961 to 1965. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death of the Rt Hon. Viscount De L'Isle, former Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia from 1961 to 1965, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

First Viscount De L'Isle was born William Philip Sidney on 23 May 1909 in England, son of the fifth Baron De L'Isle and Dudley. He was educated at Eton and at Cambridge University and became a chartered accountant after graduating from university. At around the same time he joined the Grenadier Guards Reserve of Officers. During World War II, Major Sidney, as he then was, led a handful of men in the defence of the Anzio beachhead in Italy, for which he was awarded the Victoria Cross.

Eight months after Anzio and while still in the Army, he was elected unopposed to the House of Commons as Conservative member for Chelsea. It was not until after his father's death the following year that he took his seat in the House of Lords as the sixth Baron De L'Isle. In 1951 he was appointed Secretary of State for Air under Prime Minister Churchill and held office until 1955. Viscount De L'Isle then turned increasingly to business interests. He held several appointments, among them managing director of Schweppes (Home) Ltd and director of Lloyds Bank. In 1961 he came to Canberra as the fifteenth Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia. He was an enthusiastic and active Governor-General who travelled widely within Australia.

On a personal note I remember being in London on one occasion and being told the story of the rather exclusive Brooks Club, where members sit at large tables. On one occasion at lunch someone was laying down the law about Australia. Another person who was sitting at the end of the table said, `I do not think you have got that right'. The first person said, `Well, what would you know about Australia?', to which the reply was, `My name is De L'Isle. I was Governor-General for some years'. That response was true not only of his position but also of the way he carried out his duties as Governor-General in Australia. He was the last Governor-General who was non-resident on his appointment.

It must also be said that his fondness for Australia was apparent when he returned to Australia for a visit in the late 1960s and again in 1988 when he demonstrated his affection for Australia by presenting a bronze statue for the bicentenary, which stands in the grounds of Government House here in Canberra. On behalf of the Government, I extend our most sincere sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Opposition senators I support the motion of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) expressing our deep regret at the recent death of former Governor-General Viscount De L'Isle.

SPEECH.PARA: Viscount De L'Isle was the last British Governor-General of Australia. He was appointed Governor-General in April 1961 by the Menzies Government. Although at the time there was some criticism from those who felt that an Australian-born appointee would have been more appropriate, he proved to be a worthy choice.

Viscount De L'Isle was educated at Eton and Cambridge, and then became a chartered accountant. His war service record in World War II was most distinguished. Then Major Sidney of the Grenadier Guards, he was awarded the Victoria Cross in 1944 for bravery during the allied landings at Anzio in Italy. Only eight months later he was elected to the House of Commons as the Conservative member for Chelsea. As Senator Button said, when his father died the following year, he took his seat in the House of Lords. He served for four years as the Secretary of State for Air from 1951 to 1955. This time in parliament was followed by a period during which he was managing director of a number of boards, including Schweppes (Home) Ltd. He also served on the boards of a number of community organisations.

Viscount De L'Isle was a man of great integrity with a strong sense of public duty who did not shrink from controversial issues. After the war he argued that it was wrong to put German officers on trial for war crimes, a most unpopular contention at the time. He later supported a British Labour Party proposal to abolish the House of Lords, saying that he was in favour of an elected senate.

He served as Governor-General of Australia from 1961 to 1965 and brought to the office great enthusiasm and warmth, and a deep affection for Australia and its people. He travelled widely during his time in office and returned to visit after he relinquished the position in 1965.
Viscount De L'Isle died last week in England at the age of 81. On behalf of Opposition senators, I extend our sincere sympathy to his wife and family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia in the Senate, I join with the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) in expressing deep regret and sympathy at the death last Saturday of Lord De L'Isle, the fifteenth Governor-General of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: William Sidney, first Viscount De L'Isle, was appointed Governor-General of Australia in 1961 by the Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, a post which he served with distinction until 1965. He was appointed at a time when public opinion was being expressed that vice-regal positions should only be held by Australians. By all accounts, his love of Australia was enormous and he returned to Australia on visits after the completion of his term of office.

Viscount De L'Isle shared a role similar to that of senators here today in that he was an elected politician, having been elected to the House of Commons where he quickly received a ministry. After taking his hereditary seat in the House of Lords as the sixth Baron De L'Isle, he spent four years as the Secretary of State for Air.

The viscount was also a prominent businessman, both before and after his term as Governor-General. Lord De L'Isle was one of two Australian Governors-General to hold the Victoria Cross, which he won in 1944. He took many stands on social issues during his public career. The active role he played in Australian life seemed to have gained him immense popularity with most Australians. I extend the sympathy of the National Party in the Senate to the widow and family of Lord De L'Isle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I support the condolence motion put by the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) today.

SPEECH.PARA: Viscount De L'Isle, serving as Governor-General of this country from 1961 to 1965, had a varied career during his lifetime, including his military service, where his bravery during the Second World War earned him the Victoria Cross. Politically, he served with distinction in both Houses of the Mother of Parliaments. Of course it is of interest to senators in this place, as has already been mentioned, that it was a surprise that he, as a Conservative-although he had been described as a middle-of-the-road Tory-did support a British Labour Party proposal to abolish the House of Lords, saying that he was in favour of an elected senate.

He was also distinguished in business, notably with the Schweppes organisation, and in the vice-regal component of his life when he served here as our Governor-General. He was, as has been stated, the last British Governor-General, and is remembered with affection by Australians. I recall in my young adulthood thinking of Lord and Lady De L'Isle as a travelling Governor-General and his Lady. Living in rural Australia, as I did at the time, it seemed to me that they travelled more than I was conscious of other vice-regal couples having done. Of course, as time has passed, travelling has become easier for public figures to undertake. As the capacity to travel with speed and comfort increased, this Governor-General took advantage of it.

He was well known and I believe is remembered with affection by many Australians. Upon his appointment, he met the growing public opinion, which was favouring a move towards Australian-born Governors-General, with good spirit. Despite that growing mood, he became a popular figure. Part of that popularity was due to his genuine affection of this country and its people which was demonstrated by his many return visits.

In common with Sir John Kerr, whose death has also been marked with a condolence motion today, Viscount De L'Isle lost his wife during his term of office as Governor-General. In that context, those two very different Governors-General come to our minds similarly on this occasion. As I say, as the last of the British Governors-General, he is remembered with affection by many Australians. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I also offer our condolences to his family.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Durack (from 31 citizens) and Zakharov (from 135 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney Airport: Third Runway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth that the Federal Labor Government is procrastinating over the decision on the third runway at Sydney Airport. An immediate decision to construct the third runway is essential to ensure that regional air links are maintained to Sydney Airport. Continued access by rural airlines to Sydney Airport is essential for business purposes in the Sydney Central Business District (CBD), to connect with interstate and international flights, for essential legal, health and welfare services, and to encourage decentralisation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Directory: Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Since the introduction of three (3) regional West Australian telephone directories there has been a constant demand from users to revert to a consolidated country directory which is convenient to all users.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled urge the Minister for Communications to direct Telecom to recognise the requirement of rural West Australians and revert to a single consolidated country telephone directory.

PETITION.TITLE: Middle East
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The hasty deployment of Australian military personnel to the Middle East at the request of the President of the United States has involved Australia in an undeclared war with potentially disastrous consequences for Australia and the people of the Middle East.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Immediately withdraw all Australian military personnel from the Middle East and pursue a foreign policy designed to secure justice and human rights for all the people of the Middle East.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Report on Higher Education: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the Chubb Report on Higher Education for the A.C.T. which proposes that the Institute of Advanced Studies be separated from the Faculties of the Australian National University and the Faculties be amalgamated with the University of Canberra. We believe that the implementation of these proposals would mean the destruction of the Australian National University's national and international high standing and firmly established reputation as a centre of excellence in research and scholarship. The dismemberment of the ANU would severely effect the ability of both the Institute and the Faculties to attract, or even retain, high quality academic staff, funding and support. It would also adversely affect the recruitment of top students. The maintenance of the Australian National University, as it is now constituted,-a national university with an international, national and local role-is of vital importance to the A.C.T. and Australia.
2. We call on the Senate to reject the recommendations of the Chubb report and to support the integrity of the ANU and the existing relationship between the Institute and the Faculties.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia, do humbly pray that:
In light of the many reviews of the Family Law Act, 1975, already undertaken, and the high level of support in the community for the general principles enunciated in the Family Law Act, 1975, i.e.
1. No fault divorce.
2. Issues relating to children are decided on the basis of the best interests of the children involved.
3. Division of property is based on the past contributions and future needs and resources of the parties involved.
We consider a further review of the Family Law Act, 1975, by the Senate and House of Representatives at this time, is an unnecessary waste of public monies.

We call upon the Senate to consider the many reviews and proposals already made to improve the operation of the Family Law Act, 1975, e.g. The Australian Law Reform Commission Report on matrimonial property and reports of the Family Law Council, and not to proceed with the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, 1975.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Senate will, as a matter of urgency, establish a Committee of enquiry into
a) the export of Australian military hardware and services;
b) the adequacy of existing controls over Australian arms exports;
c) the implications of the international arms trade and ways in which it might be reduced.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) deplores and condemns the genocidal attack on the Kurds of Iraq mounted by the Saddam Hussein regime, the latest in a long line of such attacks on the existence and rights of these long suffering people;

(b) supports every possible form of international action consistent with the United Nations Charter to force the Iraqi regime to halt its actions and restore the capacity of the Kurdish people to live in peace and with their human rights respected; and
(c) notes and supports the Government's speedy response to the call from international relief agencies for the urgent contribution of relief funds to alleviate the plight of Kurdish refugees.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING: STATEMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes:

(i) the statement made by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) on 6 April 1991, criticising current Government policy on the exchange rate, tariff reductions, inflation, the current account and foreign debt, wages policy, and the role and extent of Government intervention in the economy,
(ii) that this statement represents a major rift in Cabinet over the Government's stated economic policy aims,
(iii) that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have publicly repudiated Mr Dawkins' statement, and

(iv) the report in the Australian on 9 April 1991 that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) had come to Mr Dawkins' defence;
(b) condemns the Government for its economic policy paralysis; and
(c) calls on:
(i) the Government to make a clear and unequivocal statement on the role it sees for exchange rate policy and anti-inflation policy, and to state unequivocally its economic policy priorities,
(ii) the Prime Minister to exert leadership and dismiss Mr Dawkins for repeatedly speaking outside his portfolio responsibilities and contradicting stated Government policy, and

(iii) the Prime Minister to make an unequivocal statement on the role of Cabinet solidarity and the extent to which it is permissible for Ministers to make policy comments on issues outside their portfolios.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL ADVERTISING; INTERNATIONAL CONVENANT ON CIVIL AND POLITICAL RIGHTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) condemns the Hawke Government for its outrageous attack on freedom of speech by its announced proposal to ban all political advertising at all times by all Australians on radio and television;
(b) condemns the Hawke Government for its breach of Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights of which it is a signatory.

DEBATE.TITLE: VOLUNTEER WORKERS: ENTITLEMENT TO UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFIT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes:
(i) that this week is National Volunteer Week and acknowledges the important social and economic contribution made by volunteer workers throughout Australia,

(ii) that the most recent survey on volunteering carried out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in South Australia in 1988 showed that the total dollar value of volunteer effort throughout Australia was in the vicinity of $8.4 billion per annum, and

(iii) that the Volunteer Centre of South Australia's Volunteer Referral Service regularly interviews unemployed people wishing to volunteer and that in the first three months of 1990, 27.6 per cent of those interviewed were unemployed, while in the first three months of this year 41.2 per cent were unemployed; and

(b) recognises the contribution being made by way of voluntary work by many unemployed people and calls on the Government to ensure that persons receiving unemployment benefits can undertake volunteer work on a regular basis without the fear of having their benefits terminated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:

(i) the independent Task Force commissioned by the Queensland Government to assess the Tully Millstream Hydro-Electricity extension, has submitted a report to State Cabinet which found that the project was greenhouse-friendly, cost effective and should proceed as the State's next power station, and
(ii) the Queensland Government has referred a copy of the report to the Federal Government and the Wet Tropics Management Authority;

(b) expresses its concern at pressure now being put on the Prime Minister and the Environment Minister from parts of the conservation movement to reject the Tully Millstream extension as a price for re-gaining green support lost in the recent Resource Security decision;
(c) notes that:

(i) the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) accepted the possibility of the Tully Millstream extension in its original recommendation for World Heritage Listing of the Wet Tropics, and

(ii) contrary to some claims, the Tully Millstream project will affect only 135 hectares of well over half a million hectares of rainforest within World Heritage boundaries, that is 0.02%, and river flows will continue to be released at dry season levels or higher, and wherever necessary to satisfy environmental and tourism; and
(d) recognises that claims by Tasmanian Green Independent MP Mr Bob Brown that the local people don't support the project are demonstrably false.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) recognises that the Queensland Electricity Commission (QEC) has been pursuing a policy of deliberately stimulating demand for electricity rather than seeking to limit demand by end use efficiency improvements and the substitution of renewable energy alternatives such as solar hot water;
(b) notes that the QEC nonetheless has an excess of generating capacity compared with demand and has accumulated a debt of over $4 billion;

(c) recognises that the proposed Tully-Millstream hydroelectric scheme is unnecessary but in addition, if built, would have serious impacts on the Wet Tropics World Heritage area including the demise of a flourishing and environmentally benign tourist industry based on white water rafting on the Tully River; and

(d) accordingly urges the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, as a matter of urgency, to proclaim regulations under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 which will proscribe all activities in the Wet Tropics World Heritage area which would be necessary for the building of the proposed Tully-Millstream hydroelectric scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes:
(i) that the collapse of the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust has resulted in the loss of an estimated $600 000 in donations intended for Australian arts organisations,

(ii) the Government's requirement that the Trust be used as a conduit for donations to the arts, and that the stated election policy of the Liberal-National coalition for years has been to end this arrangement,
(iii) that until two days before the Trust's collapse, the Government had continually rejected demands from arts organisations to end this arrangement, and

(b) reports that the Treasurer agreed to long-standing pressure from successive Labor Ministers for the Arts to allow direct tax deductable donations only after he was recently advised of the Trust's disastrous financial situation;
(c) considers that the Hawke Government was a party to concealing the insolvency of the Trust which continued, on behalf of arts bodies, to accept donations that have now been lost;

(d) rejects the Government's claim that it can do nothing to assist arts bodies suffering what are, in some instances, disastrous losses, because it says there was no legal requirement for donations to be passed on; and
(e) calls on the Government to make good these losses by Australian arts bodies for which the Hawke Government is directly responsible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) condemns the statements by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training on 20 March 1991, in an address to the OECD Conference on Education and Cultural and Linguistic Pluralism, that Australia is a monolingual nation and that new training opportunities, including basic health and safety training, will only be available in English;

(b) notes that these statements contravene the national agenda for a multicultural Australia and constitute a breach of the Prime Minister's election promise to continue and expand the National Policy on Languages;

(c) recognises that Australia is a multicultural and multilingual nation, that English is the common and national language and that community languages are an intellectual, cultural, social and economic resource of value to individuals and society;

(d) calls on the Prime Minister to reaffirm the Government's commitment to the principles and spirit of the current National Policy on Languages and the National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia; and
