SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, 10 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 460, and made under the Customs Act 1901, be disallowed.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief explanation of this, not in any way to anticipate debate but because my notice of motion is very much in the spirit of the holding operations that sometimes are used by the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in order that further negotiations might take place with the relevant Minister, Senator Tate. It is our hope that, in fact, a vote on the disallowance may not be necessary but rather that the Government itself might amend the regulations to meet our concerns. I might say that that discussion has been taking place for some time but we believe that further negotiation might be fruitful.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
NOTICE OF MOTION TO DISALLOW CUSTOMS (PROHIBITED IMPORTS) REGULATIONS
Whilst the Opposition supports the aims underlying these Regulations, which seek to restrict the importation of firearms, we have strong concerns with a number of aspects of their drafting.
Time does not permit me to mention all of those concerns; therefore I will simply refer briefly to the more important ones.

Firstly, there is uncertainty surrounding the law relevant to the offence of possessing a prohibited import of the type proscribed by the Regulations. It has been argued, for example by New South Wales Police Minister, Mr Pickering, that the Regulations could apply to firearms which were legally imported prior to the commencement of the Regulations; although the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, has argued that the Regulations will not have any retrospective operation.
We believe that this uncertainty should be resolved and the matter put beyond doubt by the inclusion of an express statement making it clear that they will not have any retrospective effect.

Secondly, the Regulations depart from the text of the statement approved at the Police Ministers' Council in November 1990. The statement approved by the Police Ministers (with the exception of New South Wales) provided that it would be lawful to import rifles and shotguns for competitive use in shooting competitions endorsed by certain recognised organisations such as the Sporting Shooters' Association of Australia Incorporated.

The Regulations, in contrast to the Police Ministers' statement, do not make provision for allowing the importation of firearms for competitive use. The Regulations do, however, provide that competitors from other countries may bring in such firearms. This may disadvantage Australian sporting shooters and may well have a detrimental impact on the viability of Australia hosting international shooting competitions. In turn, this may impede the development of shooting as a legitimate and internationally recognised competitive sport.
Thirdly, we are concerned that the Regulations may have an unwarranted adverse effect on legitimate collectors of firearms as military paraphernalia.

Finally, in our discussions with shooting organisations, it became clear that the Government did not undertake adequate consultations to ensure that the views of shooters were properly taken into account.
It is a matter of disappointment to the Opposition that the Government has failed to address community concerns in these Regulations as presently drafted.
We are obviously not in a position to promulgate Regulations ourselves; nor can we amend these Regulations. The only course of action open to us is to move for their disallowance.

I take this opportunity to foreshadow that the Opposition intends to present an alternative set of regulations for the Government to consider. This represents a sincere attempt on the part of the Opposition to create a common ground in order to work out an acceptable solution.

I emphasise that the Opposition supports the Government's aims in proposing these Regulations; we simply have concerns with their present drafting. Those concerns are of such magnitude that we are compelled to seek disallowance of the Regulations.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received the following letter, dated 9 April, from Senator Parer:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 75 I propose that, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
`The necessity for this Senate to condemn the proposal of the Hawke Labor Government to restrict the freedom of Australians to impart political information through any media of their choice.'
Yours faithfully,
Warwick Parer
Senator for Queensland
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The necessity for this Senate to condemn the proposal of the Hawke Labor Government to restrict the freedom of Australians to impart political information through any media of their choice.

It never occurred to me that in my lifetime I would see the necessity to propose in this Senate a matter of urgency such as the one I have just moved. Very regrettably, that is the position in which we find ourselves today.

Never did I imagine either that any Australian government would propose laws to gag discussion and debate on political issues by banning anyone in this country-whether it be a politician, a businessman, a unionist, an environmentalist, a charity, a community group or a concerned individual-from ever advertising his views on radio or television. There is an immediate danger that, unless the Senate acts to condemn this proposal, the Government will introduce severe restrictions on the rights of the Australian people, attacking rights in a way which I have never seen in my lifetime.

The Hawke Labor Government professes a concern for human rights, yet the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, and the Government have the arrogance and the effrontery to deprive us of a right we have all taken for granted-the freedom to express our opinions through any medium of our choice. This Government has failed the Australian people, and it is a sign of its desperation that it is seeking to limit criticisms of its actions. The approach adopted is simple: ban all political advertising on radio and television and introduce political censorship, a policy beloved of all totalitarians in the history of man. Chris Gilbert, Professor of Law at the Queensland University of Technology, said:
All modern dictators place the control of television stations among their top priorities. The Saddam Husseins of this world know the power of the box.
So, apparently, does Mr Hawke.

The Australian Civil Liberties Union makes a similar point, saying that the ban reflects `the ALP's distaste for public participation in the political process' and is due to `an unpleasant authoritarian streak in many of its leaders'. It is ironic that at this time, when there is a tide of freedom sweeping the old Eastern bloc countries, the Hawke Labor Government should seek to erect in Australia an `iron curtain' chaining the airwaves. Let us look at what the Federal Government's own watchdog, Human Rights Commissioner Brian Burdekin, says about the proposal. He is:

. . . concerned that aspects of the . . . ban . . . may be inconsistent with certain fundamental human rights. These rights are contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which Australia ratified in 1980 and which are incorporated in federal legislation in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Act.
For the benefit of the Senate, I quote from article 19 of the Covenant:

Everyone shall have the right to hold opinions without interference. Everyone shall have the right to freedom of expression; this right shall include the freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print, in the form of art, or through any other media of his choice.

The Government claims that there are precedents in other Western democracies for the banning of political advertisements. This is totally deceptive, as the Government and Senator Bolkus know. Let me point out that the following countries allow political advertising or political party free time on radio and television: New Zealand, the United States, Canada, West Germany, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom.

The Minister for Administrative Services, with his gift for Orwellian newspeak, describes the move as sanitising the political process. Under the same logic, would the Minister describe locking up people who disagree with his Government as purifying public discourse? Where will this proposal end? As the editorial in the Canberra Times on 19 March notes:

Freedom of speech can certainly be abused, but not by overuse. Once a society begins to regulate who has the right to spread a political message it has strayed dangerously close to regulating the opinions considered suitable.

I might add that the Government's initiative has been condemned by virtually every other editorialist, columnist and commentator in this nation. It cannot be claimed by the cynics that this is purely self-interest because, as a result of media cross-ownership rules, newspaper groups can no longer own broadcasting outlets. In fact, a ban on television and radio advertising would help newspapers by directing more political campaigning to the print media.

The move to restrict the freedom of political speech has brought forth angry protests across the spectrum in Australia, for example, from the Law Council of Australia, the Media Council of Australia, the St Vincent de Paul Society, the Australian Council of Social Service, business and farmer groups and so on. I could go on and on. The list is endless. In the interest of balance, I wanted to list those who support the Government's move, but try as I might I could not find anyone willing to say so publicly, apart from Mr Bob Hogg-surprise, surprise-and, guess who else, the union bosses in the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

Let us be clear about what this Government's proposals would mean. The Minister has announced that he will amend the Broadcasting Act to ban totally any advertisement at any time that contains electoral matter as defined in the Electoral Act. During Question Time I asked the Minister what that meant and he could not answer me, so I thought I would give him a bit of a hint. I said to him, `How does the Electoral Commissioner interpret electoral matters in the Electoral Act?'. Again there was no answer. I thought it would be a good idea to help the Minister by giving him the interpretation used by the Electoral Commission. I refer him to volume 6 of the Australian Electoral Commission's 1990 election handbook, where it defines `electoral matter'. It is worth listening to this carefully because it shows us the extent of the gag. The Electoral Commission's definition of `electoral matter' is as follows:
Any express or implicit reference to, or comment on:
-an election;
-the Government, the Opposition, a previous Government or a previous Opposition of the Commonwealth;
-the Government or Opposition, or a previous Government or Opposition of a State or Territory;
-a local authority or previous members of a local authority;
-a member or former member of the Parliament of the Commonwealth or a state, or of the legislature of a territory, or of a local authority;
-a political party, a branch or division of a political party or a candidate or group of candidates in an election; or
-an issue submitted to or otherwise before the electors in connection with an election . . .

In simple terms, it will be illegal to express political dissent by way of advertisements on radio or television. Many of us were incredulous that the Minister actually meant what he said, and average Australians could not believe that a government would set out to achieve the results I have described above.

Just to make things crystal clear, the Minister for Administrative Services, whose name will soon become Big Brother, put out a clarifying statement on 25 March. It is worth quoting from the Minister, this leading light of the socialist Left. The statement reads:

Despite reports to the contrary, the Government has made no decisions in relation to the effect of the proposed political advertising ban on charitable organisations; this includes that no decisions have been made to exempt such organisations from the ban . . . The Government will not allow a situation to arise where bogus or legitimate charitable organisations could be used as `front' organisations for political entities to advertise through.
I thought it was important to quote the words exactly, with all the grammatical errors.

What is so pernicious about this scheme is that the Government envisages that its own taxpayer-funded political advertisements will be unaffected by the ban. Apparently, outside election campaigns there will be no restrictions on the Government's monopoly of the airwaves. So much for the level playing field! Taxpayers are already footing the bill for the Hawke Government's propaganda machine. Already more than $232m a year is being spent promoting the incumbent Administration. Probably with the ban in mind, earlier this year the Government also established a special ministerial committee called the Government Advertising Service-or GAS which is no doubt gearing up for massive `information' campaigns once all other voices have been gagged by this sort of legislation. From these signs it is clear that the ban will not affect the amount of political advertising on television and radio, just the type.

Whereas now there are advertisements produced and funded by political parties and other interest groups, in future there will only be the Government's propaganda, paid for by the long-suffering taxpayer. Under the Minister's scheme, for all but one month of a three-year term governments could spend our money on television and radio blockbuster campaigns telling us what a great job they are doing. No other views or opinions could be presented in this way, and the only time the Government's advertising would be partly restricted is during the actual period of an election campaign.

During the election campaign proper, the Minister says that the Government will still be able to continue with `government advertising necessary to cope with national emergencies, advertising by electoral authorities and commercial advertising by government business enterprises'. Given this Government's track record, what is to stop it from abusing those provisions in the same way that it has misused taxpayers' money for self-promotion and partisan campaigning? There are instances I can quote. What if the government business enterprises in question are those intended for privatisation, for example, by a coalition government, and their `commercial' advertising consists of subtle-or not so subtle-messages implying that they should remain in state ownership. There are also precedents where this Government has sought unfair advantage from electoral `information' advertisements. I instance the 1988 referendum campaign where it took a High Court judgment to stop this Labor Government from broadcasting misleading and biased advertisements.

I referred earlier to the Minister's press release expressly confirming that charities would not be exempt from the ban. Therefore, it is obvious that there will be unprecedented and draconian results from this Government's proposal. However, they cannot be excused as `unintended consequences', because the Government has been told exactly where the ban will lead. For example, the all-party Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters recommended against `a complete ban on political advertising'. I am interested to see on the list of speakers the name of Senator Schacht who was a member of that Committee, every member of which-Labor, Liberal, Democrat, independent-recommended against a complete ban. I think that it is worth quoting some of the paragraphs of the Committee's report. It said it recommended against a ban because it:
. . . would have a direct effect on freedom of speech by reducing opportunities for discussion during election periods when voters are determining the candidate or party they wish to support.
The Committee also pointed out that:

. . . most witnesses disagreed with a complete ban on political advertising, claiming that it would have an adverse effect on freedom of speech and . . . would disadvantage citizens and groups who wished to bring issues before the electorate.

The report of the Committee was received in August 1989 and at that time the Government displayed no sense of urgency whatever about dealing with this matter. Now suddenly it argues that corruption in Federal politics is a major problem. Eight years since it came to power-in the aftermath of a Federal election where the Australian Labor Party spent considerably more than its opponents on television advertising-we are told that it is imperative that there be a complete ban on the broadcast of political advertising.

The Government is on notice that its proposal-and this has been stated by many commentators-would further enhance the ability of an incumbent government to exploit the spoils of office and cling to power. These are the signs of a desperate government, taking desperate measures at the expense of the freedom of every Australian. It would prevent individuals and interest groups from taking their message directly to the people and prevent charities from appealing for funds if they are deemed to be `political'. It would also deny Australians in rural and provincial areas, where people rely on radio and television rather than on newspapers which often are received only weekly and are very expensive. I see Senator Schacht shaking his head. He should go out to the public and have a look; he should go to provincial Queensland or to provincial Western Australia. He will discover that people do not buy newspapers. This proposal would also limit the freedoms of 110,000 blind or sight-impaired Australians, and the one million plus people who are classified as illiterate. These are the people whom the Labor Party purports to support. It would limit their freedom to receive political information in the most direct and meaningful way, and this would also apply to the many Aborigines in the Northern Territory and in north and far north Queensland who rely entirely on radio and television. Further, the Minister has noted that:
. . . journalists will be more powerful shapers of public opinion after the ban on political advertising comes into effect.
That is a direct quote from the Minister who then said:
. . . the ban would allow reporters more power to get political assessments across.

This reflects the fact that the ban will deprive all Australians who are dissatisfied with the coverage they receive in the media or who think it is biased the right to present their views to the public direct and uncensored. The only way to put political argument to the public is through the newspapers and through the news and current affairs programs of the broadcast media. Enormous power is placed in the hands of those who control the programs.
Senator Schacht interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht had his chance in the Committee, but he opposed a ban on political advertising. As with other changes to the political process introduced by this Government, it is necessary to look at the Labor Party's own hidden agenda. As the Daily Mirror stated on 5 April last year, just one year ago:

SPEECH.PARA: This plan to limit the appearance of politicians on our television screens is not really an attempt at magnanimity on the part of the government. It is a part of the desperate effort to save the party machine from going bankrupt. Labor's money problems . . . are partly the result of its poor performance . . . in the last election.

There is a clear-cut principle involved here, and it is urgent for this Senate to put its position on record before the Government goes down the track of destroying freedom of speech. The ban legislation will stand or fall on whether senators genuinely believe in freedom. I thought that Senator Schacht was a civil libertarian. This is a black and white issue; it should not be confused with any other issues or be the subject of any deals or compromises. It is a stand-alone matter.

I am confident that the Australian Democrats, whose attitude will be crucial in this place, will not succumb to the temptations offered to them by the Government. They profess to share our concern with safeguarding individual freedom, and making the political process as open and accessible as possible. When governments call for restrictions on our freedoms `in the national interest', it is time to worry. When they propose the most draconian and far reaching limitations on freedom of speech and expression without advancing one convincing justification for this move, Australians should be justly outraged. There is still a lot of force in the warning by Thomas Jefferson, which appears under the editorial of the Brisbane Courier-Mail every day. It says:
Our liberty depends on the Freedom of the Press, and that cannot be limited without being lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is something inevitable about this debate. I have sat on the Government side of the Senate for some time-over the last eight years or so-and at every turn when the Government has tried to do things to address the problems inherent in our electoral system Opposition senators have opposed them. Not only have they opposed them but they have done so with misleading, fictitious arguments.
—You are so transparent.

—Once again this afternoon, we have similar fact evidence. We have a case, once again, of the same sort of contribution from the same side of politics. We have seen it not only just now in Senator Parer's contribution but also, a little while ago during Question Time, innuendo was raised in a very unfair way about the Australian Democrats and whether they in fact raised the question of increasing public funding in a way that could benefit themselves. Let me put it very clearly on the record that they have not. They never raised the matter, but it did not stop Senator Macdonald, in his own insidious way, from raising the point and then trying to draw something out of it, or Senator Parer, just a few seconds ago, when he made the same sort of implication.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the same sort of Opposition, with the same lack of recognition, understanding, or keenness to address the issues that we find, once again, dominating this debate from the Opposition side. We are told, for instance, that the Government will be free to advertise as it wishes and, at the same time as government advertising is allowed, public interest and other groups will not be able to. The reality-and it has been made clear a number of times-is that government advertising will be subject to the same criteria.

We have been told that country people and the blind will have lack of access to political information. In reality country people will still get the same commentary and news review programs on radio and television as they get now. What they will be denied is access to political advertising. Let us bell the problems right from the start. There is a major difference between freedom of the press, freedom of speech, and a commercial right, a political right, to advertise-a right which, though not political, is one which is based very much on the level of one's bank account.

For eight years I have sat on this side and watched the Opposition. This Government has acknowledged from day one that there are problems inherent in our system, such as the rising costs of campaigning and the lack of adequate disclosure provisions-both interwoven, both presenting a great challenge not only to our democratic system but also to democratic countries internationally. But we have seen, at every turn in here and at every turn in every relevant State legislature-every relevant State parliament-where the conservatives have majorities in the upper House they have resisted moves to ensure, for instance, adequate disclosure provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not disclosure.

—Senator Parer should note that disclosure is very much part of this, although he and his Leader may not understand it. What are involved here are two inherently involved issues and they arise from what Commissioner Roden said at the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) hearing:

SPEECH.PARA: The alternative to compulsory public disclosure, I believe, is an unacceptable risk that through financial necessity, influence with Government (of any political colour) will be a purchaseable commodity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The urgency motion is to do with freedom of speech.

—I kept quiet while Senator Parer spoke, so perhaps he could give me a break. What we have here is a Government very keen, as part of our democratic process, to address two inherently interwoven problems. One problem is the level of reliance of political parties and political organisations on fundraising and the second problem, and interwoven in that first one, is the question of disclosure. Every time we have raised it here, whether it has been through public funding, through disclosure or through the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to see how we could curtail costs, Opposition senators have taken blind reaction to it and the brick wall has gone up immediately.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of disclosure, for instance, there have been calls across this country from Fitzgerald in Queensland to ICAC in New South Wales and further afield. We have in this country four inquiries either just completed or currently in operation, that addressed or are addressing the issue of the relationship between the corporate dollar and government. If that is not a clear sign to us that we have to act to ensure that that infectious nature does not go any further, I do not know what the Opposition needs.

It is argued that this issue of the corporate dollar and its influence on the political process have not really come onto a national level. The `Joh for PM' campaign was driven by the same sort of money that led to the Fitzgerald inquiry. That was a great example where someone could very well have made an impact here.

TALK.START.PARA: —It failed.

—Of course it failed, but the Opposition cannot tell me that the lungs of the body are infected and the body is healthy. That is precisely the sort of argument that is coming from the other side. Let me just get off the Opposition. What I want to address is the very fundamental question of democratic rights. Other speakers after me will address other aspects of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that we are attacking democratic rights. We are told that by Opposition senators who, for a number of years now, have opposed the enshrinement in our legislation or in our Constitution of the most basic constitutional rights. We have invoked before us today article 19(2) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR).

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the one you signed.

—It is the one that we signed and it is the one that the Fraser Government ratified, but it is also the one that the Opposition since 1983 has refused to enshrine, through a Bill of rights, in this country's Constitution. Opposition senators were the ones who opposed, for instance, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC). They are still committed to its abolition. However, they are the ones who come in here this afternoon and quote the words of Commissioner Burdekin. What sort of hypocrisy and double standards are they showing and continuing to show? If they believe in HREOC why are they still committed to its abolition? If they believe in the sorts of fundamental freedom that they talk about, why did they resist such basic freedoms as the right to vote, the right to one vote one value, the right to freedom of religion, the right to trial by jury and the right to fair compensation? Why did they resist those at a referendum? Because of short term political gain, and that is precisely the motivating factor in this particular instance as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me talk about democracies. I will quote Mr Justice Skelly Wright of the United States Appellate Court. I think he sums up, as far as I am concerned, the most basic premise of our democratic system and that of the United States (US). In summarising his position, he states:

Financial inequities pose a pervasive and growing threat to the principle of `one person one vote' and undermine the political proposition to which this nation is dedicated-that all are created equal.

What we draw directly out of that is that, if one's voice in the political process is dependent on the size of his or her bank account, we do not have a fair and equal system. Advertising is an inherently undemocratic medium. It is not free speech; it is bought speech. It is speech that can only be bought, in terms of television, for $13,000 a minute and, in terms of radio, at an ever expanding rate of $1,300 a minute.

The basic point is that this sort of financial inequity-this sort of medium which can only be a bought medium and which directly implies that one's voice and one's role in the political process depend on the level of one's bank account-is not a democratic right. Another thing about advertising that has been recognised internationally is that it leads to money, not people, setting agendas. I do not have to quote radical, left-wing thinkers in respect to this. Let me quote Senator Barry Goldwater of the US Senate. In a very telling and stark three lines, he says:
It's not . . . the people . . . but moneyed interests who are setting the nation's political agenda and are influencing the position of candidates on the important issues of the day.

Senator Barry Goldwater, an extreme conservative in the United States of America, makes that very telling point. In terms of supporting that statement, one really has only to look at the former Director of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Tony Eggleton, who, recently in the Melbourne Age in an interview with Michelle Grattan, in terms of setting the agenda-in terms of the very inherently interwoven point that, by setting the agenda, what those who donate want is not influence in terms of the result but influence with the government, whoever it might be after an election-admitted that during the Fraser era donors might get quicker access. But he goes on:

If a company asked me (for access to Fraser) I wouldn't intimate how big a donor they were, but I might say that a friend of the Party wanted to see him. It might get them in the door marginally more quickly.

Malcolm never asked how much they donated but the basic point is that it got them through that door quicker. What we are talking about is an access to decision making, which goes through the back door.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the ACTU?

—Senator Parer might raise the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). While the Opposition resists disclosure of campaign funding of the accounts of political parties, as it continues to do, it can see what the ACTU donates to political parties. Annually, all unions and the ACTU have to declare their income and expenditure to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, and the Opposition can look at those. But let us have a look at the Opposition's accounts. What is it trying to protect? Dr Hewson tries to move away from the Opposition's position, but the organ-grinders of the Liberal Party have dragged him back. Hopefully, he will be able to present and develop this image of an honest politician and support the Government on this but, with the likes of honourable senators opposite, Andrew Robb and the secret donors behind him, I would not put my money on it.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about undue influence in the process. The Opposition comes in here today and says, `You are going to stop all these community groups from having access to the system'. Let us look at the facts, the reality. For instance, at the last election where third parties had to declare their expenditure on political process, $1.75m was spent by third party groups on the campaign. Of that, $63,000 was spent by those community groups that the Opposition talks about and $26,000 by the Australian Conservation Foundation on radio advertising. As opposed to that, the loggers spent $1.1m. Quite obviously, radio is a medium which depends on the level of one's bank account; one's access to the system depends on the level of one's bank account; and one's influence after the event also depends on the contributions made beforehand.
Senator Parer quoted the Society of St Vincent de Paul. The Society of St Vincent de Paul wrote to my office and said:
1. The Society has no position, for or against, the Cabinet decision to ban political advertising.
2. We are a non-political organisation and we do not run advertising supporting or opposing any political party.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got them scared.
—I resent an inference that I have got any organisation scared, particularly St Vincent de Paul. I go on:

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, any ads we do run-for appeals and the like-will not be affected by Cabinet decision.
The reality is that the sorts of groups the Opposition is bleating about do not have the capacity to spend $13,000 a minute to get their voices heard.

Phillip Adams made a point quite well about advertising in a superb article on the weekend. He is someone who has been involved in advertising, who knows the area and who expresses his views extremely succinctly. He made this point about what has happened both in the United States and Australia. To paraphrase, he said, `The television campaign has replaced the election campaign; forget the policy speech'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was it? Who wrote the article? Anonymous, is it?

—Phillip Adams; Senator Bishop may know him. He makes the very telling point that out there, as the Manager of MMM FM radio said, the public does not care for political advertising; they do not get information from it; and in reality they regard political advertising as not worth the celluloid it is printed on. That is not just my own view or the view of Phillip Adams--
—Who is supporting you?

—I will tell Senator Kemp who is supporting me on this particular point. The Opposition members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters-the Committee that has been quoted recently in debate-had this to say about political advertising:

SPEECH.PARA: We reject as absurd the assertion that political advertising is a social good.
The Committee went on to say:
We have seen no convincing evidence of any co-relation between election results and either the quality or quantity of political advertising on electronic media.
It also said:

It seems likely that it is the news and current affairs programs, and not the party advertisements, that provide the information which makes television a significant influence on individual political choices.

These comments come from colleagues of Opposition senators who told the Joint Standing Committee what they think of political advertising. What we are talking about is the defence of the concept of freedom to advertise. It is an inherently undemocratic concept and has dangers within it. I have expressed why it is inherently undemocratic; so let us look at the dangers. First of all, one does have that undue influence in the system-as Tony Eggleton paid witness to. But it also takes participation in the electoral process right out of the hands of ordinary people.

If the two major parties in this country have to sell assets-the Liberal Party has in Queensland and Victoria-and if other parties are struggling, how can we expect minority groups in this country to have their voices heard? How can we expect them to be part of the system? What we are talking about here is a late twentieth century revision of the property franchise. If one's participation in the process and one's voice depends on one's bank account, then we are talking about the reintroduction of a property franchise and about censorship by stealth. Let us have no misconception about that. If people do not have the power, the money, to advertise, then they are frozen out of the system.

In closing, I return to a couple of points about the need for this legislation. To this Government, to any thinking people, and to any libertarian not living in a vacuum, it is not an attack on freedom of speech or on freedom of the press. The ban goes very much towards the commercial transaction of advertising. It does not go towards anyone in this place or elsewhere having their views carried by news, news services, current affairs or review programs on radio and television-and it only goes to radio and television.

We are levelling the playing field. We are taking out of the playing field the factor that one needs a big bank account to play in the game. From now on, everyone will have equal access to the media and that should be the driving force for governments. I recently read a book called The Best Congress Money Can Buy, a book about the United States, which shows very starkly the power in the US of the corporate dollar because of one factor, that factor being the amazing and exploding demands on political parties of campaign advertising. The US, New Zealand and Japan have uncontrolled advertising on television whereas other countries allow for free time. But those three countries have paid advertising-apart from us and apart from Canada, which bans it in the last 28 days of a campaign.

It is no coincidence that the costs of advertising and the costs of campaigning have led to a situation where, in the US, members in the same position as us spend three-quarters of their time going out campaign fundraising because they have got to raise millions of dollars to get into Congress. That is a great example of the democratic process not being available to people. What we are concerned about here is to contain costs and also to ensure that those who play the game can be exposed. If the Opposition has got nothing to hide, if it has got nothing to protect in terms of its secret bidders and the organ-grinders that run Senator Parer, his Party and his leader, then the Opposition should be supporting the disclosure provisions. Senator Parer knows what they are.

Let me give this challenge to the Opposition. Opposition senators have seen the Joint Standing Committee report, entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune, and know what is contained within it. There is no need for Opposition senators to drag their feet and drag their leader around and around on this particular issue. The challenge to us on this side is one that we have met consistently, no matter what the issue. If we have to make a hard decision, we do. In this case, we are concerned to maintain campaign costs. We are also concerned to ensure that the system is cleansed from undue influence and corruption, both currently and into the future. That is what we are on about. We cannot do that by just having disclosure. John Howard mentioned the case of Spiro Agnew the other day on television. Spiro Agnew was driven by the need for funds, despite the disclosure laws in the US. We cannot approach this problem by just one arm and not the other.

The package we present is one that will enhance the democratic process. However, we expected the Opposition's reaction-given its history in the last eight years of opposition to any endeavour by the Government to ensure that the system works cleanly, openly and honestly and to any endeavour from the other side to protect people's rights and to enhance them and to acknowledge the inequities in our society-because there is nothing new about it. Having regard to the Opposition's soiled record in Utah mines in Queensland, I would tread rather gingerly about how it approaches this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Powell) moving an amendment to the motion.
I move this contingent motion because the terms of the urgency motion before us really do not address the debate, which the Australian Democrats agree is a worthy debate.

This motion speaks only of a part of what is a package. It is for that reason that we seek to suspend Standing Orders in order to be able to amend the motion as put forward by Senator Parer. I would leave aside the grammatical problem with the motion, however, as Senator Parer also raised grammar in the context of, I think, the Minister's press release. It should read, `through any medium of their choice'.

We are concerned that this debate should take place but equally concerned that the debate, as it has taken place in public thus far-apart from some fairly hysterical responses to what is a serious issue, I will agree-has been very limited in the context of an overall package.

As well as that, the motion talks about the restriction to impart political information. Quite clearly, what little detail we do know of the Government's proposal does not do that in toto. In the first couple of days of debate in the community some people seemed to see the implication that no broadcasting of any kind of any political material would be permitted. It is not part of the Government's package that no political information will be imparted through any form of media, only that which is paid for and, in the case of television, paid for very expensively.

The Democrats, in particular, are interested in a full debate. As Senator Parer has pointed out, and as we have pointed out, as our position in the public arena is important we are not making a precipitant decision on any aspect of the package. In order to have a rational debate which will be productive we are seeking advice, we are listening to debate, we are listening to representations and we will seek advice from within our own Party next weekend at our national executive meeting. So we are interested in a full debate. Therefore, we believe that this motion should be amended.

Should this motion to broaden the debate be successful-I seek it for this reason-we will move to extend the framework of Senator Parer's motion. First of all, it will exhort the Senate to give due consideration to the Government's package and emphasise, in particular, addressing matters such as the high cost of electronic advertising, ensuring disclosure of all political donations and ensuring honesty in political advertising. There are more, but those are the crucial issues that we think the Senate should be debating today. They do not at all exclude the issues raised, as I say, somewhat oddly by Senator Parer.

We believe that this debate definitely needs to encompass other aspects. This is a package to change the conduct of election campaigns. This is an area in which the Democrats have operated consistently throughout our time in this place. Of course, disclosure of election campaign funding was a move in the right direction, pushed and promoted by the Democrats. The issue of disclosure of all party funding is an urgent issue for us; therefore, we believe it should be the subject of this urgency motion.

I have moved that we suspend Standing Orders at this point to allow me to move an amendment to this motion to broaden the debate. It will make it useful-certainly for us-if the Opposition has any useful contributions and if the Government is going to put forward any further elucidating material at this stage, and not waste the time of the Senate by trying to whip up again the hysteria on a very limited, although important, part of the package which has been put forward by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the face of it I am opposed to the contingent matter of urgency but, in the interests of this debate continuing, we will not oppose and divide on it because that would take up the time that has been allocated to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make this point and give my reasons for my opposition to it. Firstly, it has always been my view that matters such as disclosure and truth in advertising are important and should be debated, but I think it is very important not to muddy the waters by putting within them this attack on freedom of speech. I draw to the attention of Senator Powell and the Australian Democrats that this matter of urgency is simply a precis of article 19 of the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, if they would like to look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't draw the conclusion that you wish to draw; you can't draw it.

—The conclusion that I wish to draw is that we are looking at and concentrating on the most outrageous attack on freedom of speech that this country has ever seen. The other issues, I have said, are important and should be debated-and the Senate might recall that the Democrats' attempts in the past to get truth in advertising failed only because both the parties decided that it would not work.
—What you are putting is a political perversion.
—Senator Cook interjects and says it is a perversion. If ever there was a perversion it is this attack on freedom of speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I said I would not take up too much time because I do not want to eat into the debate. In conclusion, we have speakers on this side who wish to make a very serious contribution to this attack on freedom of speech. I believe that Senator Powell is deliberately muddying the waters, and it makes us suspicious that a deal has been made by Senator Powell and that she has been bought. I make the point that, while we are not in favour of the amendment as suggested by the Democrats, we will not oppose it and cross the floor because we wish the debate to proceed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after `urgency', substitute the following:
`The necessity for the Senate to give consideration to the Government's package of proposals to change the conduct of election campaigns, addressing in particular, measures to:
(a) stem the high cost of electronic election advertising;
(b) ensure disclosure of all political donations; and
(c) ensure honesty in political advertising.'.

I have amended Senator Parer's motion because what he brought before us today is a mere fraction of what the Government is putting forward. What he has done is limit the debate in this place. The Australian Democrats agree with the Opposition that it is important that there be debate on the package for the change of conduct of election campaigns which the Government has brought forward. There has already been considerable public debate of which we have been a part. We have been acknowledged as playing a leading role here each time it happens-and those occasions become rarer and rarer-that the Government and the Opposition disagree.

In this particular case, immediately the package was announced a position of opposition was taken by the Opposition parties with the exception, however, of an initial statement by Dr Hewson at the National Press Club, I believe, in which he said in answer to a question that he thought that it was probably a fair thing that the Australian people did have full information about the sources of funding of political parties. As we have subsequently seen, very quickly after what I thought to be a reasonable and rational response to a very important proposal of the Government, Dr Hewson has been pulled into line by the party operatives-those who know what is in the books; those who know where they want to go for funds for the upcoming election. Those who know?

They are not the members of the Australian public who, we believe, have an absolute right to know where their political parties and other political organisations are getting their backing from. Quite clearly, this aspect of the package put forward by the Government is something that the Opposition opposes absolutely. We want to hear more about that issue from the Opposition in this debate. We have inserted that as part of our amended motion because we do want to hear from the Opposition. As a political party now coming up to fifteen years of existence-which began with, and has had ever since its inception, full disclosure as a matter of firm policy-we are absolutely delighted that this Government has finally come all the way.

As honourable senators know, for several elections now donations to political parties for campaign purposes have been disclosable. Until now, that was as far as we had been able to push the Labor Government on disclosure. Of course, it was a situation which left massive loopholes, through which, as we know, the old brown paper bag or the shiny black briefcase, which was mentioned today, has been able to find its way very easily. It is a particular delight that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) of Senator Loosely and the Harris-Daishowa donation should now be prepared to put forward, on behalf of the Australian people, the right to have full disclosure of political funding of all kinds to all political groups.

That is a part of this proposal which must be passed, and the Australian Democrats will do all that is within our power to ensure that it is passed. We want to hear arguments with substance from the Opposition-not rubbish about union funding of the Labor Party, which is already a matter of open public disclosure. The Liberal Party may not want the unions to fund the Labor Party; that is entirely a different matter. All Australians deserve to know where all of the funds of all political parties come from-not just the Liberal and National parties but the ALP and, indeed, the Australian Democrats.

It was very important to us that we not engage in this debate without addressing that issue and that we not allow the Opposition, in the hysteria of this campaign on a limited aspect of the Government's proposals, to side-step that issue. It has been assisted by the media, which has not probed that position or the reasons for the Opposition's position on this issue. I could not count the number of journalists to whom I have said, `Where is your analytical piece about the Opposition's intransigent approach to maintaining the secrecy about where it gets its money from?'. This continues in spite of royal commission evidence that we do have problems in this country. Admittedly, at this stage at least, we have seen nothing at the Federal level beyond perhaps a misuse of the limited disclosure which we have had so far with regard to campaign donations, but not of the level that we have seen within the States.

I stress that the Democrats have not yet seen legislation on this package-none of us have. When we do see the legislation relating to disclosure we will go through it with a fine toothcomb. As I have said, this is the ALP of Stephen Loosely-now Senator Loosely, a colleague in this chamber-and Harris-Daishowa. With that in mind, we will certainly look closely at that legislation. We do not want any sham full disclosure. I am not accusing the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), who is putting forward the legislation, of having that in mind, but we often find unfortunate lapses in Government legislation. Within weeks of coming into this chamber, my colleague Senator Kernot was able to fix a piece of Government legislation on a technicality which seemed to be beyond everybody else. We will be looking at that aspect of the legislation very closely.

We believe that the Senate should give due consideration-and those are the terms in my amendment-to this whole package, as the Democrats are, and as we will continue to do right up until we see the exact legislation that the Government intends to put before us. During that process we will not speculate ridiculously about things we do not know about, but we will negotiate. We reserve that right to negotiate; so does the Opposition. Is Dr Hewson not currently in negotiation with Prime Minister Hawke about the question of four-year terms? I have not received a letter from either Prime Minister Hawke or Dr Hewson. The Prime Minister and the putative Prime Minister will no doubt want to do a deal, particularly on the question of whether a four-year term should be fixed. Of course it should be fixed. They will do a deal which suits whichever one of their parties comes into government next time, the time after or the time after that.

It is the right of the Australian people to have a fixed four-year term so that elections are not a matter of political opportunism but a matter of the proper administration of this country. Dr Hewson and Mr Hawke will do a deal on that, and they are currently negotiating-make no mistake about that. That is their right, but I just wish that one of them would drop me a line so I could tell them how to do it properly-instead of which I have written to all the newspapers in this country to tell them our view on the matter.

We will negotiate and we will do it with the goal of improving the Government's package. We will improve it, as we improved Medicare, the industrial relations legislation and the privacy legislation-as we do, day after day, week after week in this place. That is what balance of power is about; that is why the Australian people have given us back the balance of power year after year, election after election, under both types of government. Make no mistake; if there is a change of government at the next election, those on the Opposition benches now will have to frame their legislation so that it suits the Australian Democrats. I can assure them that if a new government should appoint Senator Macdonald in any way to negotiate with the Democrats it will be entirely unfruitful. We are accustomed to that role, and we relish it on behalf of the Australian people.

We know why there was an attempt to limit this debate: it is because the Opposition does not want to talk about disclosure. In our negotiations we will continue to press to get rid of the licence to lie. The Commonwealth Electoral Act is just that at the moment, and we want amendments to that Electoral Act to get rid of the licence to lie. We are realistic and we know that we will never stop politicians from lying altogether, but in May 1990 Senator Macklin, as he then was, after years of pursuing this issue, brought forward in this place a very simple and quite limited amendment on that question to ensure that basic truths are contained in political advertisements. We have put that before the Government again and we hope that it is getting due consideration.

I will pay Senator Parer the same courtesy. However, it is contained in Hansard and I am sure he is very well aware of it as he would have been aware of the debate at the time Senator Macklin put that amendment forward. That is another advance that is needed in the context of this package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty pieces of silver.

—We will get to Senator Macdonald's 30 pieces of silver. The Democrats have said that we will continue to consider this package and not go to our Party forum next weekend with any firm position on any aspect of it because we want to take advice from our Party. However, at Question Time we had what should be the last of a range of attacks on the Australian Democrats on this package, relating to one aspect of it. That is the aspect whereby the Government proposes to bring the entitlement for Senate campaigning under public funds up to the level of entitlement for the House of Representatives-which, in effect, will double the current value, for public funding purposes, of each Senate vote. Simply, it aims to bring the Senate and the House of Representatives into parity.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been accused today by Senator Macdonald and various editorialists around the country, most notably David Barnett in the latest edition of the Bulletin-fine company Senator Macdonald finds himself in-of being prepared to back everything the Government says for the sake of some $500,000, which is what would have come to us on 1990 figures, had the House of Representatives and the Senate votes achieved the same level of public funding.

Editorialists, David Barnett, Senator Macdonald and other people-including his Opposition colleagues who have been flinging press releases all around the backblocks of Western Australia and Queensland-have all ignored the $4m plus that the two other parties will get. If the Opposition gets the landslide victory that it is expecting next time, it is looking at $3m or so.

Today, in spite of the fact that we have not consulted our national executive, I am announcing our party room decision to vote against that aspect. Then Opposition senators will have the ball in their court. We will vote against that aspect because, as Senator Bolkus said, it was not our proposal. Honourable senators know what our priorities are: truth in advertising, disclosure and the issue of increasing costs of election campaigning. We will vote against that which was not our proposal. David Barnett and the Opposition should understand that the bulk of our funding-as is the case with the bulk of everyone else's funding-comes from our House of Representatives candidates who stand all around Australia, who do not get elected, but who will get elected at the next election.

We have amended this motion so that Opposition senators will address all the issues, so that they will stop being hysterical about one aspect of it, so that they will stop misrepresenting our position and so that they will be confronted in the rest of this debate with having to come forward with what they believe regarding the disclosure of political funding. They will have to state why they do not want any form of truth and honesty in advertising and why they are hiding behind one aspect of a comprehensive package which can bring to Australia better and more effective election campaigns if we all debate the issue responsibly and not hysterically and if we address all of the issues in doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to debate the matters before the chamber and to look at some of the issues which were raised by Senator Bolkus and Senator Powell in their contributions today. It was interesting that Senator Bolkus drew attention to the enormous cost of advertising. He argued that this matter was out of the hands of ordinary Australians, that the strength of one's voice depends on the size of one's bank account. He told us he was trying to level the playing field. I wonder whether exactly the same arguments could not be applied to direct mail advertising. I ask Senator Bolkus how many pieces the Australian Labor Party (ALP) put out in the last election and what the cost of that was. Is direct mail advertising of the scale contemplated by his colleagues out of the hands of ordinary Australians? Does it depend on the size of one's bank account?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I know Senator Schacht is embarrassed by this. He has been rolled up to support Senator Bolkus. I would be embarrassed too if I had been rolled up to support Senator Bolkus. Senator Schacht will have a chance to make his contribution, so let us leave it at that. The reality is that the arguments that Senator Bolkus put forward to ban political advertising on television and radio are precisely the arguments which could be used by Senator Bolkus for banning direct mail. Senator Bolkus knows that that is very expensive and that it is out of the hands of ordinary Australians. Those arguments could also be used to attack political advertising in the media, which is also very expensive, and to quote Senator Bolkus, out of the hands of ordinary Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell in her contribution berated us all here for not addressing what she regarded as the wider substance of the issues before the Senate. I say to Senator Powell that we waited patiently for her to outline in detail what her policies were. We waited in vain because she told us that she had to go to her executive. I do not know who these faceless people are, but Senator Powell said that she had to go to her executive to hear what it wants to do. If Senator Powell wants to come in here and berate other senators-both on the Government side and on this side-and call for us to come up with specifics, then I think the onus is on her to do precisely the same. The fact is that she failed to do so. Senator Powell gave us a number of wish lists. Perhaps we are being too harsh on her, but I detect that we are seeing a famous sitting on the fence procedure on her part.

TALK.START.PARA: —She's sitting right in front of you.

—Senator Bell will have his chance to make a contribution. Senator Powell wishes to stem the high cost of electronic election advertising. The best way to stem the high costs of electronic advertising is for parties to spend what they are able to raise. In the last election, the Labor Party spent and spent and spent again even though it did not have the money. It has now run itself into what can only be described as a massive debt.

SPEECH.PARA: If we really want to stem the cost of electronic advertising, surely the initial onus is on the parties themselves. I ask Senator Powell why we want to stem the cost of electronic advertising only. Do we not want to stem the cost of direct mail advertising? Why does Senator Powell effectively exclude that from her amendment? Perhaps later speakers may stand up and explain why the focus is on electronic advertising. If Senator Bolkus has his way, the vast bulk of election funds will be spent on direct mail advertising. I ask Senator Powell whether there is a need to control those costs. Let us have her views on that.

Senator Powell's second point related to ensuring disclosure of all political donations. I have a question for Senator Schacht who will shortly address this motion. Does he support disclosure to all trade union members that a certain proportion of the funds they have contributed to the union has been given to the Labor Party? Do we really want to go down that track? Let us see Senator Schacht answer that question.

Senator Powell and her colleagues might like to address themselves to the next issue. If we have disclosure of all political donations, what procedures would she recommend we have in place to protect those who will inevitably suffer intimidation from the Labor Party? Senator Bolkus should read the articles in the newspapers about the building industry in New South Wales. He would learn a little bit about intimidation from the Labor side of politics.
Senator Schacht interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht is going to have his chance. I know he is excited by this issue, but he will have a really good chance to make his contribution. The third point Senator Powell raised was about ensuring honesty in political advertising. There is an onus on political parties to be truthful; I have always felt that and I am sure my colleagues on this side have too. But how would the Labor Party react to this? Senator Schacht may remember that we warned the Government about a capital gains tax. That was a terrible campaign. What happened? The Labor Party brought in capital gains tax. Does Senator Schacht remember the Government's promise in 1987 that there would be no children living in poverty? That was one big lie. Senator Faulkner, who is in the chamber, may remember the big lie of the Government during the 1990 election that there would be no recession.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be interested in and will look forward to the Labor Party contributions from Senator Schacht and Senator Faulkner about truth in advertising because both of those senators will go down in history as members of the Government of the big lie. It has to be said that this Hawke Labor Government will go down in Australian history as being quite remarkable for its total lack of principles. It has never shown any loyalty to the principles which have guided the ALP through its first 100 years.

Who would ever have believed that a Labor Government in this country would boast that it cut the living standards of Australian workers or would take such pleasure in being cosy with the rich and powerful? Let us recall the John Curtin Foundation of Western Australia and that famous photograph. Who would have believed that a Labor Government would give priority to rich mates and trade union bosses rather than to the interests of Australian workers? Who would ever have believed that an Australian Labor Government would have attempted to limit the freedom of speech? We will look forward to listening to Senator Schacht answer that question today.

This motion was worded to pick up the sentiment, and indeed the wording, of article 19 of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. Freedom of speech, as enshrined in that article, is a basic principle of democracy. In view of what is currently emerging from Western Australia, I have to say that it is with some wry amusement that we read the headline on Senator Bolkus's infamous press release on 19 March which sought to ban political advertising. Does he remember how that headline read? Senator Bolkus said that the Government will not tolerate political corruption.

As the Royal Commission in Perth goes about its work and as the evidence unfolds, we will see how effective the Labor Party leadership has been in avoiding political corruption. We shall also see whether the leaders in the Federal arena have their hands clean. That will be of great interest. Apparently some $300,000 or $1m-Senator McMullan cannot tell us-was paid. Nevertheless substantial sums were paid. Senator Bolkus, you were very embarrassed at Question Time today when you were asked a number of simple questions about your Bill.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! This has been a fairly vigorous debate and that is as it should be, but two things are bothering me. Firstly, the requirement is that honourable senators address the Chair. Secondly, I would have to say, Senator Faulkner, that there is a requirement that, if you wish to interject, you do not do so except from your own seat.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President, but I am sorry that that has absorbed a further few minutes of the very brief time I have to debate this issue. If Senator Bolkus was truly concerned about limiting campaign expenditure, what would we have expected him to do? We would probably have expected him to put a limit on campaign expenditure, but there is no such proposal. What is happening under this proposal that Senator Bolkus has put is that campaign fundraising can go on as before but the funds will be directed, if Senator Bolkus has his way, into other areas, particularly direct mail.

SPEECH.PARA: I will conclude my remarks on Senator Powell's comments by saying that, at the end of the day, the resolution of this debate and the legislation which comes before this chamber will largely depend on Senator Powell and her colleagues. Some of us may deplore that, but the reality of the numbers shows that that is the case. I remind Senator Powell in regard to her considerations which will be going before this executive, this faceless group of people about whom I know nothing but which presumably will tell her what to do, that Don Chipp, who actually founded the party that Senator Powell belongs to and actually got her into this chamber, has argued in the press recently that:

It is now proposed to turn the clock back 20 years and prohibit any person, political party or concerned publicly spirited lobby group from advertising their policies, beliefs or objections on radio and television.

The problem Senator Powell has is that after all the debate, compromises and deals that Senator Bolkus and his colleagues will offer, in the end the Australian Democrats will be faced with making a choice on a great principle of public policy. The principle is whether they support the right of any aggrieved special interest group to bring its views to public attention in what is the most effective way, which is political advertising.

The fact of the matter is that Senator Powell will have to choose whether she will accept an unfettered right to freedom of speech or whether she will join with the Labor Party and attempt to save its neck and, undoubtedly, the neck of Senator Bolkus. Because of the chaos that will continue on this issue, I think that his colleagues will be very pleased to see the back of him. At the end of the day that is the choice that Senator Powell will have to make and all those special interest groups that she spends so much time cultivating and all those individuals who believe in an unfettered freedom of speech in relation to politics will be watching her moves with great interest. Senator Powell has a great responsibility. I ask her to consider very carefully the issues which we have raised today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this urgency motion to indicate my opposition to the extraordinarily badly worded motion which does not even deal with the question of the Government's proposal to ban paid advertising on television and radio and to force full disclosure. It tries to say that what we are doing is banning free speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I also take note of the Australian Democrats amendment, which I am more than willing to support because it raises the issues which have to be discussed in any sensible forum in the community, as well as Parliament. Those issues involve the good conduct of democracy in this country and the electoral process.

Senator Parer pointed out that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, in its report entitled, Who pays the piper calls the tune, rejected a complete ban on television and radio advertising and that, as a member of that Committee, I had signed that report, so where do I stand? Because Senator Parer has been a member of the Senate for some time, he would be aware that a member of any working committee can either take one attitude of being utterly alone and express that in a minority report or attempt to work through a series of compromises and get a consensus. My view has always been in favour of a ban--

TALK.START.PARA: —And disclosure.

—And disclosure. I was willing to get a consensus or a substantial majority to support the proposal in this report, which is for a ban and free time allocation but, of course, Senator Short, who was the leading Opposition member on that Committee, opposed everything.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no hesitation in saying that the simplest and most effective legislation is to support a complete ban on advertising. It means that there are no loopholes; it is very simple to administer. A separate committee is not required to administer the free allocation of time. I make no bones about that fact. I participated in the Committee to get a consensus position among as many members of the Committee as possible. I am now more than willing to support a complete ban. This report makes it clear that there are difficulties under the other proposals-and I accept that.

My interest in this issue goes back about 15 years when I was a full time official of the Australian Labor Party in South Australia. I have never equivocated in supporting major electoral reform, including full public disclosure, public funding and banning paid television and radio advertising. Opposition senators can look back at the records of the Labor Party in South Australia and they will find that I have always argued for that platform and have never deviated from it-and I never will. When it comes to the basic proposition of observing other countries and the functioning of the process of democracy, the best thing that we can do is to get the power of money out of the political process, to ensure that the process is as transparent as possible, so that people know who is calling the tune, know the sources of the donations and who is putting the pressure on so that people in the community can condemn us accordingly and make a judgment when they cast their votes.

Opposition senators and the Liberal Party of Australia are about hiding as much information as possible from the general public so that they can go on with the old back-room system of politics. I have to say to Senator Parer and the Opposition that I am uncomfortable about the disclosures that appear to be coming out of the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in Western Australia. It proves my point that money is linked with the desire for political parties to survive and to pay for expensive election campaigns. In the end, political parties start making judgments about getting money, irrespective of whether it is the Labor Party, the Liberal Party or the National Party of Australia-and where is the National Party in this debate? No-one is listed to speak. No-one is in the chamber listening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would like to bring to the notice of the Senate that Senator Schacht has a little trouble with his eyesight. I am here; I am a member of the National Party; and I am listening to the debate. I fully support Senator Parer in this urgency motion because I think that the Government's proposal is denying free speech for all Australians. It is absolutely imperative that Senator Parer's urgency motion is carried.

—Senator Brownhill, that is not strictly a point of order. It would have been more orderly to have made a personal explanation along those lines at the end of the speech. I also note that you are acting Whip of the National Party and, therefore, sitting where you are.

—I did not notice Senator Brownhill because he is not sitting in his normal seat but in the seat usually occupied by the National Party Whip. However, where is the Leader of the National Party in the Senate (Senator Boswell)? Where are the Queensland National Party senators? I will tell honourable senators where they are: they are in a bunker with brown paper bags over their heads rather than filling those bags with money. They do not want to take part in this debate because they have been exposed in Queensland, first of all, for taking donations for the Bjelke-Petersen fund and, secondly, for having a number of their former Ministers go to gaol for rorting their expenses. We will not hear anything from the National Party in this debate. Its members have been proved guilty of corruption and of corrupting the system. They wanted to raise money to enable their Party to pay for its election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: The Independent Commission Against Corruption report has proved that money is being used in the political system in New South Wales. I make no bones about the fact that the John Curtin trust fund was established because the Western Australian Labor Party, like all political parties in the long run, was faced with how they would raise funds to pay for effective campaigns. Political parties must rely on corporate funding. Unless we deal with the problem of knowing that the only way in which we can pay for a $10m or a $20m election campaign is to get it from the corporate sector, we are putting ourselves in the hands of a very small number of people in the community-people with real power.

I would be much more interested in hearing the Opposition's arguments regarding the banning of advertising in the electronic media if it said that it was in favour of full disclosure. The Opposition is not in favour because it is very afraid that people will see who really is running the Liberal Party. Honourable senators opposite have claimed that the ban is unheard of in the Western world. They do not realise that most European countries and most countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development that are defined as first rate democracies have limitations and bans on advertising. Even Margaret Thatcher-the neo-type New Right leader who, for example, Senator Bishop models herself on-for 10 years supported, and never moved to get rid of, the complete ban on paid advertising on radio and television in Great Britain. She made not one move to change that. There is also full disclosure in Great Britain. Public companies in Great Britain make full disclosure as to which political parties they give donations. There has been no evidence of intimidation.

Honourable senators opposite say, `What about the trade unions?'. At least a trade union's donations have to be published in an annual report. There is no requirement on the Opposition's mates in the company sector to disclose publicly to whom they give donations. Why are companies not forced to tell their shareholders that they have given $500,000 to the Liberal Party, and/or $500,000 to the Labor Party? If the Opposition were serious about that, it would be forcing changes to the Companies Act so that companies would be forced to disclose political donations to their shareholders. There is not a word from the Liberal Party on that. Companies are afraid to explain to their shareholders where their money has been going for 50 or 60 years.

We have heard that the international covenant on human rights may be breached. If it is breached on this piece of legislation that is soon to come into this place, it means that every country in Western Europe has also breached that covenant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. I ask honourable senators not to interject.

—Then we have Senator Parer giving us a list of all the organisations that have supposedly come forward as supporters of free speech in opposing the Government's proposal. He mentioned some of them, including the Law Council of Australia-the last resort of utter privilege in Australia; an organisation that represents the highest income earners in this country in a vested and protected position. When will the Law Council of Australia start arguing that it should publish and put into the public domain so many of its own procedures to ensure transparency of its operations? Members of the Law Council were in the courts trying to stop the publication of the Westpac documents. They had no ethics about free speech. They used the system to stop disclosure of documents and to stop free speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The Law Council is a body with the most utter privilege in this country. It is a disgrace for it to talk about free speech. I have not seen the Law Council issue one statement during the 15 years when Bjelke-Petersen was rorting the judicial system in Queensland. Not one statement came from the Law Council of Australia opposing the rigging of appointments to the Supreme Court in that State. The Law Council is a body of utter hypocrisy on this issue. It represents privilege; it represents money.
