The reason that the Law Council does not want the ban is that sometimes, when governments may choose to change the law to affect the income of members of the legal profession, it wants to be able to pull in millions of dollars from its wealthy supporters to run campaigns against the Government-whichever Party that might be. The Law Council is representative of utter privilege in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I take this opportunity to remind Senator Schacht that he is in fact--
—Order! I ask Senator O'Chee to take his seat. This is not his chance to make any reminders. There is no point of order.

—Another organisation-News Ltd; the Murdoch press-is quoted in the newspaper editorials as being in favour of free speech. Any journalist who attempts to express an independent view in News Ltd is shown the door. News Ltd has control of 65 per cent of the print circulation of Australia's daily newspapers. For News Ltd to talk about free speech-in view of the way in which that organisation is run and bearing in mind that journalists have gone on strike in the past to defend free speech and journalistic ethics because of what it has done-is hypocrisy.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Farmers Federation is worried about free speech. It is worried about whether it can spend in political campaigns the $10m to $12m that it has raised from its members. It is worried about how it can spend all of that money. It is not worried about free speech. It is not worried about whether a small group of farmers, who may disagree with it and who have no access to money, can buy advertising on television and radio. It wants access so that it can use its $10m; it wants the power to use its money.

The CAI has made statements on this issue. Of course it would-who would not expect it to? It is like the famous statement of Mandy Rice-Davies who, in her famous court appearance, said of Lord Astor, `Of course he would say that'. Of course the CIA would say that this is an attack on free speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —The CAI.
—I must say that sometimes they may have similar views. I apologise to them for getting it around the wrong way.
—Which one are you apologising to?

—Both. Of course the CAI would take that view. It wants to protect the right to use the money of its membership to put its view. But most other groups in the community have no access. It is wrong to say that free speech is under threat; it is not. If it were, it would be under threat in every western European country where these reforms, in many cases introduced by conservative governments, have been operating for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not get any comment from Senator Bronwyn Bishop, who is a member of what I think is called the Democratic Union, which is an international body of conservative parties. Why does not Senator Bishop ask that body why it supports these proposals?

The motion moved by Senator Parer is obviously deficient because it is does not even talk about the Government's proposal. The position put by Senator Powell is much more in tune with the issues which have to be debated. I am more than willing not only to vote against Senator Parer's incompetent motion but also to support Senator Powell's amendment, which I think is more relevant to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate, which has sunk to pretty low depths, is what we might call a precursor to the connivance between the Government and the Australian Democrats and the deal that they will finally strike. This motion of urgency, moved by Senator Parer, espouses the principles laid down in article 19 of the International Covenant on Economic and Social Rights. What we have ended up with, by the trickery of suspending standing orders, which was connived at and agreed to by the Government, is the replacement of our motion by a motion which is contrary to the terms which we moved.

—I rise on a point of order. An allegation of connivance has been made with absolutely no substance to confirm it, to enforce it, to reinforce it or to substantiate it. I ask Senator Bishop to withdraw that statement. `Connivance' is an unparliamentary term, particularly in this context where there is absolutely nothing to substantiate it.
—There is no point of order. `Connivance' is not an unparliamentary word. I do not believe that there was any unparliamentary aspect to Senator Bishop's remark.
—Out of decency you should withdraw, but you are not decent.
—I beg your pardon, Senator? Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to whom was that remark directed?
—To you.
—You are saying that I am not decent?
—That is right.
—I am used to hearing the sort of language that Senator Bolkus is accustomed to using. Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask that you ask this senator to withdraw his remarks.

—The words `decent' and `indecent' are also not unparliamentary. Whilst the interjection may be offensive to an honourable senator, there is no precedent in the Senate for such a word to be withdrawn when directed at another senator. I call Senator Bishop and ask her to continue with the debate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am afraid that I find it quite offensive to be called not decent by a fellow senator. If you find that acceptable, then so be it. As I said, Senator Bolkus chooses to use language from time to time which other people find quite offensive. Perhaps at another time we may publish the sort of language that he chooses to use.
—In public places.

—In public places and on International Women's Day to boot. To return to the debate, I said that we are seeing a precursor of the connivance that will go on between the Democrats and the Government to achieve the curtailment of the freedom of speech. I said that what we have seen take place is the replacement of our motion, which was designed to uphold the freedom of speech and uphold the principle of article 19 in the International Covenant on Economic and Social Rights, with one which is contrary to it in all terms. Indeed, Senator Bolkus, I dare say, could be renamed `Censor Bolkus'. Government senators could ask themselves why the Australian Labor Party (ALP) today has protested so much at the concept of freedom of speech being protected.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we mean by the term `freedom of speech'? What does it mean to the ordinary man and woman in the street? It means enjoying the right to utter words and sentences, exempt from arbitrary control. Arbitrary control is what Senator Bolkus wishes to impose upon the Australian people. We have the right to speak free from intimidation. Today in Question Time we asked whether we would remain free from intimidation; whether the penalty for breaking this ban would be a fine; and whether a person who refused to pay the fine for breaking that ban against freedom of speech would be imprisoned. That to me is intimidation

We have heard those on the other side pontificate about the need for disclosure and make some sort of claim about moral ethics. I ask: why does this need to be on now when we see a need for the Australian Labor Party to somehow ease itself away from the sleaze of WA Inc. and what we might call the golden-shoe brigade-far richer than anything we ever saw in Queensland, I might say? These are the people who had slush funds of $300,000 for the secretary of the Premier of the day-and it came in cash. She brought a bag to collect it in, take it away and divide it up. The initials on the bag were whose? They were Brian Burke's initials. He is the man who is supposedly serving this country in a diplomatic way in Ireland at the present time. Every time the Minister responsible, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), is asked the question, he washes his hands like Pontius Pilate and says, `It is no business of mine'. It will not do!

As the WA Inc. inquiry continues, honourable senators on the Government benches will be dragged further and further into the mire. To counteract what will happen to them, they come out strong and say that everybody should be denied freedom of speech. They say in defence, `Well, look here, we are actually going to ban the right of everybody to have freedom of speech, including St Vincent de Paul, charitable groups, and anybody who comes along'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are disclosure provisions going to do?

—Let us deal with disclosure provisions. Let us establish what the disclosure provisions are really designed to do. Let me again ask honourable senators opposite about intimidation. Let me repeat to them that freedom of speech is the ability to speak free of intimidation. Equally, we have the right to donate the money that we earn free of intimidation. Let us look at how intimidation can be brought to bear on someone who may donate money to someone who is not of the persuasion of honourable senators opposite. Let us look at the intimidation that can result from unions bringing about strike action against companies that donate money. Worse still, what about companies that feel they are being intimidated in that they might be denied a contract because they have given money to a political party other than the one of which honourable senators opposite are members? Where is the protection against intimidation? It is not there, is it?

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is smearing every citizen of this country by banning freedom of speech. We are saying that, no matter what deal it finally does with the Democrats-and undoubtedly it is doing a deal-it will infringe the freedom of speech that is a principle and a tenet of democracy in this country. It can dress it up or down in any way, shape or form it likes. As I said the other day in a press release, when we examine the way the Government will curtail speech, when we look at the questions of definition that are involved and at the competing definitions, we will ask, `Who is to be the arbiter; who is to be the person who decides whether one advertisement is allowable and another is not? Is the arbiter to be the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT)?'.
Senator Faulkner interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —`Would that be the body?', I hear the honourable senator say. Who is the head of the ABT? He is a man, no doubt, who will do his duty because he believes that he ought to do it. But in this business we need to have justice not only done but seen to be done. I ask the Government why it has a former ALP apparatchik, a former Treasurer of the Labor Party, a former campaign manager of the Labor Party-someone who has shown his political colours-heading the ABT. How can the Government in all honesty ask the electorate of Australia to place its faith in an arbitration system which is arbitrary in nature and short on perceived justice?

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter of freedom of speech. When the people have said at large that socialism is dead, we ask, `Will the regulators fill the void? Will those people who say that they are part of the elite group which knows better than anybody else how people should be allowed to live or to spend their money and indeed how the question of smoking bans, alcohol bans, snack food bans--
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from the Government benches, and I ask that honourable senators be heard in relative silence and that there not be continuous interjections. I therefore protect Senator Bishop.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. This issue is the subject of as strong a crusade as was the Australia Card. If I might say so, former Senator Susan Ryan conducted herself with a good deal more competence than Senator Bolkus, but his end will be the same, I am afraid.

SPEECH.PARA: As we come to these issues in this chamber, there has been consistency in attitude from me on freedom of speech. As I was saying before, on the question of the curtailment of freedom of speech and the right to advertise in regard to tobacco, alcohol and snack foods, the regulators will move speedily every time to advance their cause.

Finally, we come to the question of direct mail, which is very dear to the heart of the ALP. This has already been raised by speakers on this side. We saw $3m of taxpayers' money illegally spent by the Labor Party with retrospective legislation passed to legitimise what was an illegal act. We are now adding more money to make funding available for direct mail. Let us look at the scenario. Here we have compulsory registration, compulsory voting and that very sophisticated tool of campaigning which anybody who has looked at the United States or the United Kingdom will see as a very accurate and targeted set of campaign tools. Let us go further and look at the data banks which the Labor Party has put together under a de facto Australia Card. Once data banks exist, information leaks. The Government combined compulsory voting and direct mail, accurately targeted, yet it sees fit to curtail the right of oppositions and individual groups which represent freedom of speech to put their point of view across using the television and the electronic waves.

Senator Bolkus may rise, turn his back to me and walk up the stairs because the plight of freedom of speech falls deaf on his ears-the rights that we have in this country to speak in an unfettered way and the right to have that speech made public, which is what happens through radio and television. Indeed, radio is one of the most cost-effective methods of getting a message out. It is cheap, it is efficient and everybody has access to it. A radio commercial can be put to air for as little as $40.

The arguments that are put forth by the people who want to exaggerate an advantage that they say comes to some in fact are covering up the fact that they are unattractive and therefore will not attract funds to compete with, that in the market place they can no longer compete and that they are broke because they overspent, and that therefore they want to take away the precious right of freedom of speech. It is pathetic. It is a very sad day indeed when we see a government attempt to fetter the right of individuals to speak out and when we see difficult and complicated legal aspects of definitional problems being put to an arbitrary tribunal as the body determining whether or not something is allowed to go to air.

Further, if we take that argument to its logical conclusion, every political statement that we make will be interpreted, filtered and fettered by a journalist who will publish his or her interpretation of what the political message is. If we take that to its logical conclusions, we should also regulate to require that every newspaper employs on its staff 50 per cent who are paid-up members of the Labor Party and 50 per cent who are paid-up members of the coalition. Permutations upon that theme--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Democrats?

—Quite frankly, I consider the Democrats to be the fourth faction of the Labor Party. Therefore we would have some sort of fair filtering and reporting of statements which are no longer allowed to be made and published directly to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: Other speakers have made the point that it is indeed an infringement upon people who do not have access to the written word. It is like the old Marshall McLuhan concept; it is like saying to children living in the twentieth century that they must live in the unheated part of a half-heated house. This is a time when television and radio are part of the way we speak and communicate with each other. The Government's attempt to fetter, to tie and to censor the freedom of speech which the people of this country enjoy is going to meet the same fate that its referendum attempt met: failure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet again the Opposition has chosen the easy and the sleazy path to deal with this most important issue before the Senate. Its stance is sure to maximise the potential for corruption. It supports paid advertising, but it opposes full disclosure of political donations. This sleazy approach of the Opposition is best characterised in a press release from Charles Blunt, that ornament to Australian democracy and paragon of political probity who as the then Leader of the National Party of Australia said on 7 September 1989:

SPEECH.PARA: From the National Party's point of view, political parties should be as free as is any other organisation to arrange whatever advertising they wish in whatever medium they wish. They should also be allowed to raise funds without having to disclose their sources and the whole concept of taxpayers paying for elections and referendums should be thrown out of the door forthwith.

This is the same Mr Blunt who is yet to be judged on his own actions during the last Federal election campaign. I am looking forward to the opportunity, which we will soon have in this chamber, to debate his actions in relation to the use of the government postage allowance. That opportunity, no doubt, will come after the inquiry.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was about to talk about the soaring costs of election campaigning, and there is no doubt that a major component of those costs is broadcast advertising. In relation to spending by political parties on television alone, in the 1983 Federal election some $3.75m was spent; in 1987, $7.17m; at the last Federal election in 1990 that amount had risen to well over $10m. The cost of an advertisement on television is up to $13,000 a minute; on radio it is up to $1,300 a minute. The costs are very great indeed. I noticed an article in the Weekend Australian written by Phillip Adams who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Free speech-here is the one form of speech that isn't free at all. Indeed it can only be afforded by the wealthiest of corporations or by lavishly funded pressure groups. Compare the $30,000 spent by green groups in the last election to the millions spent by front organisations for the timber interests. Even the political parties cannot afford this sort of free speech, which is why they have to go grovelling for donations doing their squalid backroom deals.

One may or may not agree about squalid backroom deals, but the reality is that the only way a political party in 1991 can fund an election campaign with a significant level of electronic media advertising is through donations from the corporate sector. There is absolutely no other way of doing it. The money must come from big business interests. I join Senator Schacht as one of those people who certainly do not want to see the Australian Labor Party at the beck and call of those sorts of vested interests. Frankly, I would not like to see any Australian political party at the beck and call of those vested interests. But of course in relation to the Liberal Party we have had that situation since its formation.

The question is: how does one raise that amount of money? Who has that amount of money? If one does get that amount of money, does one admit it to the Australian people? That is the crucial point. When this Government proposed a package of reforms in this area, two fundamental proposals were put forward. The first was a ban on electronic media advertising. The second was full disclosure of all donations to political parties. That was how Senator Bolkus announced the Government's package. As soon as it was announced, Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Liberal Party, jumped in and, for the first time, actually took a principled position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly.
—Briefly, Senator Powell is right, but he did take a principled position.
—For 24 hours.

—Senator Collins is also right. For 24 hours he supported full disclosure of donations to political parties. An article appeared in the Australian on Thursday 21 March this year under the front page heading `Libs accept disclosure of funding sources'. The article read:

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, yesterday overruled party policy and declared that the Liberal Party would accept full disclosure of the sources of political funding.

Despite Dr Hewson's clear statement, the federal director of the party, Mr Andrew Robb, denied this meant the Liberals favoured the Hawke Government's proposed electoral reform to require full disclosure of funds . . .
Dr Hewson is now facing a fight in the Shadow Cabinet and the party over his policy backflip on disclosure of funds, which has consistently been opposed by the Liberals . . .
Mr Robb told the Australian Liberal support was not certain, because Dr Hewson was talking about disclosure in a perfect world . . .
The Opposition's spokesman on electoral matters, Senator Parer-
I interpolate that this is a classic-
was also caught out by Dr Hewson's comments, saying the disclosure provision could lead to Liberal donors being intimidated by unionists.
What claptrap. But, as I said, Dr Hewson took a principled position for a few hours, and then came the back down at his press conference on 28 March. He then said:

Well, I've said it quite clearly, and it seems that some on the media have real difficulty understanding what I've said. I've said it very clearly, that my disposition is of course in favour of disclosure. But in the past there's been a lot of concern about the potential for intimidation and inequity and so I've said that I would need to see the legislation. Look, my disposition is there.
This is typical John Hewson, rolled by the Liberal Party machine after 24 hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you looked at the polls lately?

—The decision to knock over Dr Hewson was endorsed by the shadow Cabinet. I suppose it is typical of what a weak and ineffective leader John Hewson is. Yet again we have seen John Hewson comprehensively rolled in his own Party. Last time it was a party room rebellion over the dismantling of a few Federal departments, such as education and social security. This time he has been rolled by his Party machine. It is typical Hewson, the Clayton's leader, the leader one has when one does not have a leader.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no wonder that the Liberal Party has changed its mind on this issue. Let us look at its record. Let us take for example, Community Polling in New South Wales. I do not think I shall have enough time tonight to go into all the details about the rorts, the funding of independent candidates, the funding of Liberal Party candidates through a shonky outfit called Community Polling, deliberately established to breach the electoral laws in New South Wales under the guiding hand of machine apparatchiks like Senator Bishop and the others in New South Wales. Then we had the Independent Commission Against Corruption report on the investigation into north coast development. Who will ever forget the role of the National Party of Australia in the north coast of New South Wales? The paper bag mentality. Completely exposed by Commissioner Roden in his inquiry. This is what Commissioner Roden said:

The alternative to compulsory public disclosure, I believe, is an unacceptable risk that through financial necessity, influence with Government (of any political colour) will be a purchasable commodity.

No doubt he is right. There is no doubt also that this proposal from the Government to amend the electoral laws in this manner is a principled move and one which will receive the support of the overwhelming majority of Australians who believe in fair elections and genuine democracy in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bane of electors at election time --
—Order! The time for consideration of the debate has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Harradine speaking to the motion for five minutes.
I do so because I understood the speakers list contained seven members and that adds up to 1 hour 55 minutes, not two hours. The time expired after Senator Faulkner completed his speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not. I ran out of time.
—The light was showing on the clock.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Collins

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Harradine would like to take his seat I will agree to this.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I wanted to enter the debate because I have had considerable experience on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. As a matter of fact, I think I am now the longest serving member on that Committee. I want to make it perfectly clear, as I think it was made clear during the debate, that the current proposal by the Government is not the proposal that was recommended by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Incidentally, I wrote a very brief dissenting response to the report of that Committee. Nevertheless, I was a member of that Committee and went through all of the difficulty and trouble of going through submissions and trying to come to a conclusion on the matter. I, along with a lot of other people who presented evidence to the Committee, was concerned that election campaigning these days is about image making and very, very rarely is the voter given the opportunity of considering the policy issues in a reasonable, in-depth way through political advertising.

One of the problems of the recommendation put forward by the Committee was that the free time proposal contained no stipulation as to the form that it would take to ensure that information about policies would be given to voters and that there would be real debate. The slick political image makers are the bane of voters at election time. However, the current proposal of the Government to ban television and radio advertisements will not prevent the modern political campaigns being dominated by this type of sloganeering and image first politics. The image maker minders will simply divert the money saved to slick advertisements in the print media- magazines, video trailers, direct mail and junk mail. They will be able to pour more money into the production of campaign launches with accompanying razzamatazz, which the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and commercial television stations are required to carry during election campaigns.

Together with current affairs programs, whose agendas are set by the producers or the political minders and the 10-second news grabs, glib campaign launches will be the only political messages received by television viewers and radio listeners. So, with this proposal, if voters get their information from television and radio, they will get only the razzamatazz and political campaign launches or what the television current affairs producers or news producers think are important. Everything else will be censored out.

If the views of community groups or individuals on policy issues do not coincide with those of the political image makers or by the producers, or are not considered important by them, those citizens will be prevented by law from airing their views over television or radio. Voters who rely upon the electronic media for information are entitled to know where political parties and candidates stand on issues of concern and why. It can be argued that this right has become sullied in recent elections by the dominance of glib image making television political advertisements inflicted on viewers by the political parties. There are, in my view, ways to reverse this costly dominance without resort to decisions which attack civil and political rights.
I ask the Senate to consider why, if we are considering the cost of election campaigning, we do not have a ceiling on the amount which political parties and candidates can spend on elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: I understood from your previous decision that you are treating the motion that is now before the Chair as an urgency motion within the terms of standing order 75 in which case, at the end of such a debate, a vote shall be called. DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The annual report of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) which was tabled today is only in respect of that period from 5 March 1990 to 30 June 1990. In so far as it therefore relates to only a restricted part of the financial year, it is important to note that most of it draws on what would previously have been undertaken in reports of the former Department of Aboriginal Affairs. In fact, much of the report reflects the style, the tenor and the information that has formerly flowed from that Department. I will await either the Estimates next week or, alternatively, a later stage to talk on the more interesting aspects of the operations of ATSIC as they have unfolded in recent months.

Tonight I would like to take the opportunity to refer to the particular comments on page 25 which relate to the community development employment projects (CDEP). Honourable senators will be aware that a number of my colleagues and I have placed on the Notice Paper of the Senate a series of very comprehensive questions from each State and Territory in Australia with regard to the operation of the CDEP program. The answers that have come in across every State have revealed that there are serious problems with the operation of this program.

In its concept form the CDEP is an excellent scheme in that it basically replaces unemployment benefits with a better form of arrangement in Aboriginal communities-in fact, many hundreds of them. This report shows that as at 30 June there were 166 participating communities with over 27,000 people affected-workers, spouses or children. However, the concerning fact was that the vast majority of those communities and the programs that have been implemented were subjected to either qualified audit reports or unsatisfactory management comment by ATSIC in the answers that were tabled over the past month to the questions on notice.

I think it is very important that if we are to have a program of this nature and cost magnitude operating we need to be very careful in ensuring that all of the objectives are being properly met. I know that from the point of view of the Northern Territory the amount of benefit that is being paid in the current financial year to the 30-odd communities and over 7,000 participants well exceeds $40m.

The answers that were given to the questions on CDEP cause me again to reflect on the urgency of this matter and the need for strict audit, comprehensive management of ATSIC and close attention in each of the communities in which they are intended to serve where we must ensure that the benefits are properly flowing to those families that are affected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to speak on the annual report of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). In keeping with my normal concern about the timeliness of annual reports I mention the fact that it is now April and this report is for the few months that ended in June 1990-in fact, the period from 5 March 1990 to 30 June. It has taken an extraordinary amount of time for this report to come to the Senate. The letter conveying the report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) was dated 4 March so there has not been an enormous delay in the Minister's office, but I think we do need an explanation as to why this report took so long to get here, particularly in view of the fact that the Office of Evaluation and Audit (OEA) has been established within the Commission pursuant to Section 75 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the purposes of that office is to ensure that reports are relevant, constructive and timely. On the issue of timeliness it certainly has not started off too well. We recognise that obviously there are a lot of problems to be faced and the Office of Evaluation and Audit has set out on a course to try to make certain that reporting is more effective in the future. I notice that the report states:

OEA evaluations and audits are directed not only to ensure the maintenance of the highest possible standards of administration and accountability but also to assist ATSIC management in program review and policy development.
It goes on as follows:
Additionally, OEA has been given the responsibility for the development of risk assessments and a fraud-control plan for the commission.

I would hope that the problems we have seen so far in this report will be absent in the future particularly, as I understand it, as a fraud control plan is expected to be finalised early in the current financial year. The report continues as follows:
OEA's work program will be reviewed in the light of the risk assessment of commission activities.

I would also like to point out, as I do with any organisation which has qualifications to its report, that there are qualifications from the Australian National Audit Office on this report as follows:

. . . the Commission acknowledges that due to inadequacies in its accounts and records it is unable to verify that all expenditure relating to Community Development Employment Projects has been made in respect of participants resident in the relevant Community . . . For the reasons detailed in Note 9 to the statements, I am unable to attest to the value of plant and equipment acquired from the former Department of Aboriginal Affairs . . .

The auditors' report on Morr Morr Pastoral Company Pty Ltd was qualified because . . . it did not conduct a stocktake as at 30 June 1990. Accordingly, the auditors were unable to satisfy themselves that the value of stock disclosed in the statements at that date was accurate. The auditors' report on Yeperenye Pty Ltd was qualified because the auditors were not present at the stocktake conducted at year end, and were unable to form an opinion on the value of the stock.

In fairness, I should say that these qualifications in the auditors' statement do not, in the opinion of the Auditor-General, have a material effect on the state of affairs of the Commission as at 30 June 1990. All they demonstrate is that there are still some problems yet to be resolved in the accounting function in this area of government. I should also mention that there is a substantial provision for doubtful debts of $6.7m required in the gross receivable loans of $178m. That is not a large amount in view of the outstanding amounts, but I would hope that the new procedures will diminish the risk of bad and doubtful debts. I think the only other matter of moment is to note the following:

A liquidator was appointed by the Supreme Court of Queensland on 5 February 1991 to wind up the affairs of Warrama Living History Centre Pty Ltd, following its earlier appointment of a Receiver to the company on 29 October 1990. Realisation of the cost of the Commission's investment in the company will be dependent upon the outcome of the liquidation.

Perhaps I should just mention briefly that the qualifications about Morr Morr Pastoral Company Pty Ltd are about its stockholding, which has something like $2.1m or $2.2m, and the profit for the company was $238,000. Something like a 10 per cent variation in that stock valuation could have a significant impact on the stated profit.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The report relates to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 and to the report on financial assistance granted to each State in the calendar year 1989. I note that shortly the Senate will also be considering the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 report in respect of non-government schools for the same calendar year. This is an important report because it sets out and establishes the various grants that are given by the Government for many reasons-whether they are for ethnic purposes, for non-government schools or for various financial assistance reasons-and whether they are capital or recurrent.

However, the issue that I want to address relates to my electorate in the Northern Territory, where one of the beneficiaries mentioned in this report is an important school-an independent Aboriginal school-called Yipirinya School in Alice Springs, which has been set up to provide for the special educational needs of Aboriginal children. The finances that are made available through the Federal Department of Employment, Education and Training are, of course, well-targeted and well-established for the purposes that they must serve in each community, particularly where the education of Aboriginal children is concerned. The Yipirinya School receives financial grants, as has been pointed out in this report.

It concerns me that in recent weeks there has been a continuing protest in Alice Springs relating to the proposal to construct a flood mitigation dam very close to the region of Alice Springs. It has been reported to me that a number of staff, including senior staff, from the Yipirinya School have been engaged almost full time in manning various protests which have resulted, subsequently and consequently, in work on the flood mitigation dam being stopped. I hope that the resources, and in particular the financial benefits that are made available to Yipirinya School, are not being applied to fund what I can only describe as extracurricular activities which must be outside the scope of Commonwealth funding programs. Indeed, it would be a great irony if we found that one arm of government was funding a school for the purpose of providing education and that those resources were being applied to fund activities against other arms of government-particularly within this portfolio, where the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner, has had to take deliberative action with regard to that flood mitigation dam.

I hope that during the Estimates Committee hearings next week I will receive an assurance from the Department of Employment, Education and Training that none of the funding that has been so generously and properly provided for the provision of educational services for Aboriginal children has in any way been syphoned off or applied to these other activities. At the same time, I note that groups such as the Central Land Council and Aboriginal Legal Aid, which have provided professional assistance to Aborigines with regard to the protest at the dam site, would be acting totally within their charters of responsibility, both as land councils and as legal aid providers. However, I would be annoyed if any other organisation which is funded for specific purposes, such as education in this instance, relied on government money to fund the protest purposes.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

David John Gundy, a 29-year-old Aboriginal man, died as a result of receiving a wound prior to six o'clock-and that is material-on 27 April 1989 when a police shotgun discharged in his bedroom during an unlawful police raid on his home at 193 Sydenham Road, Marrickville. The important point to note, even at this stage, is that the police had no legal right to be at his home at that time. If the police had had reasonable grounds to believe that Porter, the suspected criminal that they were pursuing, was in any one of the premises-and there were six of them-which they forcibly entered on that day they would have needed no warrant to make a surprise and forced entry into those premises to arrest him. In fact, they had no information to justify a belief that Porter, the man whom they were seeking, was in any of the particular premises-including the one where David John Gundy was asleep.

A search warrant could be validly applied for and issued only if there were reasonable grounds to believe that Porter's gun and clothes were in the particular premises for which the warrant was sought. As the evidence unfolded before the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, it became quite clear that the police had relied on an unreliable witness who had simply pointed out to them a number of premises where Porter could be. The police, in their anxiety to get hold of Porter, decided that they would stage a series of simultaneous raids on the basis of search warrants.

But police demonstrated a lack of respect for the law in other ways when carrying out that particular raid. They did not bother to wait until 6 a.m., which was the earliest time at which the warrants authorised the searches. The premises were entered and David Gundy was shot six minutes before six o'clock. The written notice required to be given to the occupier of the premises was never served. Peaceful occupants were held at gunpoint and made to lie on the floor, although they had not resisted the execution of the warrant in any way. The required report was not made to the justice of the peace until seven weeks after the raid, instead of the prescribed 10 days.

It is clear, therefore, that the police had no right to be in David Gundy's bedroom, much less to point a loaded and cocked shotgun at him. It was found that he was accidentally shot by the gun of a trespassing policeman when he sought to turn the intruder out of his room. Despite the fact that the police officer had been highly trained to enter premises and confront dangerous criminals, he had not been trained to cope with an unarmed, near-naked man who reacted angrily when woken from his sleep by armed men bursting into his house.

Another aspect of this case is causing concern. Regrettably, to this day, police have refused to recognise the shortcomings in the training and methods used by the Special Branch, the unlawfulness of the raid and the patent untruth on which it was based. Police have continued to have this particular attitude. The killing of the man was followed by an assassination of his character, to which some sections of the media all too readily lent themselves.

The Commissioner examined carefully all physical evidence of how the shooting actually happened. He examined Mr Gundy's body and the patterns made by his blood on the walls, floor and furniture of the bedroom in which he was shot. He reached the conclusion that the man's left hand must have been touching or very close to the muzzle of the shotgun at the time it went off and that he was probably leaning forward near the doorway. The Commissioner was satisfied that Dawson, the policeman who shot Gundy, believed that it was necessary to pull the shotgun back in order that it should not be taken by Gundy and that in the process, his finger quite accidentally went onto the trigger and pressed it as he used his hands to pull the gun back.

The report of the Commissioner goes on to say that, firstly, it is quite clear that the police need to have greater respect for the law, which they are intended to enforce, and secondly, that their training was quite clearly deficient. In addition to that, I think it must be said that the policeman who was the unfortunate perpetrator of this killing has indicated his regret to this day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report into the death of David John Gundy is a report of a shameful, horrifying and dismaying event in the history of New South Wales, indeed, in the history of Australia. A lot has been said about the way in which Mr Gundy was shot. In the beginning of the report, it says that Mr Gundy was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in truth a law-abiding hard-working family man who had no criminal association and who had no contact of any kind with Porter and no contact of any kind with him after his shooting of police.

Mr Gundy was shot; he was killed. The point I want to mention this evening is the way his son, Bradley, and his wife-his widow by that stage-Mrs Doreen Eatts, were treated by the police immediately after his death. On page 134 of the report, we read about what happened to Bradley. Bradley was not told what had happened to his father. He saw some blood on the floor. He obviously heard the gunshots, but he was never told that his father was dead; or that his father had in fact been shot. The police decided that he should go to a relative's place. In the police car on the way to his uncle's place, Bradley heard over the radio that his father had died. He started to cry. One of the police officers stopped the car and tried to calm him. The police then drove on and left Bradley with his aunt. This was apparently the end of police interest in Bradley. That is a really horrifying thing to say about the police in this country.

While Stephenson, Wilson and other police officers displayed great concern for the psychological effect on the man who shot Mr Gundy when his shotgun discharged, they seem to have been much less sensitive to the terrible experience of young Bradley whose father had been killed in the next room by a police officer's gun. No real attempt was made to explain anything to Bradley or to obtain any professional assistance for him. He was simply driven to a relative's place and left there. This is another particularly striking example of the lack of sensitivity and concern shown on the part of police for the effect of their activities on civilians.

Let us look at what happened to Mrs Doreen Eatts. On page 138 she told the coroner that while she was talking to a police officer on the phone about her husband-and we understand at that stage the police officer had told her that her husband had been injured-she saw a film of her house on television and heard the news that her husband had died on the way to hospital. That is another truly horrifying occurrence. She was unable to continue to speak to the police officer and her mother took over the phone. Doreen is now unclear about the sequence of events and still finds talking about it very distressing. I find reading about it very distressing. The whole thing is extremely distressing.

At this stage I would like to join the very large number of my fellow New South Welshmen and women, including the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Robert Tickner, in giving my strong support to the recommendations of Commissioner Wootten, which call for compensation for Mrs Doreen Eatts and Master Bradley Eatts, the widow and son of Mr David Gundy. The sooner the New South Wales Government comes up with some fair compensation for these people, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support the remarks made by the previous two speakers. The report is sober reading for anyone. I would certainly commend its reading to anyone concerned about the proper administration of the rule of law under which we all live. A police officer's job is a difficult one at the very best of times and my sympathies are often with the police. I know many of them in the Northern Territory extremely well. They work under difficult conditions, particularly in domestic situations. I also know that to many dedicated and professional police officers, this entire sad and sorry incident is of the most extreme regret.

SPEECH.PARA: I was profoundly disturbed when reading this report not only for this unfortunate man's own loss of life, but also for the way in which his wife and son were treated afterwards. They were treated in an unfeeling and insensitive manner which I am sure most police officers would regret. Also of great concern to me are some attitudinal problems that exist within the police force. In some of the interviews given by police officers after the incident, the police blamed the victim. I have not forgotten an interview with an officer of the New South Wales Police Association whose argument was quite simply that if Gundy had not struggled in the way described in the report-and described briefly by Senator Spindler-with a police officer whom he found pointing a shotgun at him at six o'clock in the morning in his own bedroom, he would not have been shot. Therefore the fault for his being shot was his-the victim's-not the police officer's. That kind of attitude, expressed even after an incident like this has occurred, causes grave concern.

I join, as others have done before, in expressing my concern to the family of this unfortunate man who was shot unlawfully by police on his premises while he was peacefully asleep in his bed at six o'clock in the morning. I certainly join all others in the Senate in hoping that such an incident is not repeated. I must say that I hope that some of the attitudes that were unfortunately expressed by serving police officers after this incident occurred are not perpetuated.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Administrative Services: Australian Government Analytical Laboratories

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

INTERJECT.PARA: Report No. 21 of 1990-91-Department of Administrative Services-Australian Government Analytical Laboratories.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I do not want to speak too long on this report, but it happens to be one of those reports by a governmental body which is having, as one would expect, some difficulties coping with the change to that awful word `corporatisation' The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) shakes his head and I agree, but it is the go word.

Corporatisation is an uncomfortable halfway house between being a governmental body and being privatised. This organisation has moved to trust account handling of its finances, which may well remove it from the scrutiny of Senate Estimates committees, despite the fact that it will be spending what could be described as large amounts of taxpayers' money or could be acting under guarantees of taxpayers. Nevertheless, it still is receiving budget allocations. So for that reason, even though it has moved to trust account funding, it will be subject to some sort of scrutiny at Senate Estimates. One problem is the extent to which those trust accounts will be readily available for a detailed examination in a timely way by the Senate.

The Auditor-General's report does raise some interesting questions. These questions are outlined in the response from the head of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL) to the audit report. He starts off by saying:
. . . the final recommendations are positive and that their implementation will be of significant assistance to AGAL's future operations . . .
Then the Auditor-General goes on to say:

This Report highlights some of the problems faced in publishing the results of efficiency, as distinct from financial, audits of `commercial' programs in the public sector; particularly those which are required to recover their full costs and to compete with the private sector for much of their work. One of the principal concerns is that the public reporting of deficiencies, irrespective of their gravity, will be likely to promote selective criticism from competitors either in the market place or through parliamentary or administrative processes. The reasons will, of course, be more related to commerce than any desire to improve efficiency, and, in the service industry market, be likely to aim at changing public perceptions.

There is no obvious simple solution to this problem since similar arguments could be advanced to restrict the publication of a whole range of criticisms of administrative processes. Nevertheless, this issue has clear implications for a large number of DAS programs which are trying to establish and maintain their market in a competitive environment . . .

That raises some serious problems for us. If by implication there is a suggestion that governmental bodies like this should not be subject to detailed scrutiny, that there should not be exposure of their deficiencies and that these inquiries, properly conducted by the Senate, for example, at Senate Estimates should not expose these organisations to scrutiny which may embarrass them or cause difficulties in their marketplace, the way to resolve it is not to block inquiry; on the contrary it is to get rid of this uneasy, halfway corporatised position and privatise these bodies so that they compete reasonably, openly and properly in the marketplace.

This is the first time I have seen this kind of problem raised by a corporatised body. It should encourage the Government to proceed further down this road rather than remain in this uncomfortable halfway house. I hope to see AGAL largely capable of maintaining a position in a privatised form, even though the great bulk of its business is with governmental departments. If it is felt that it could not survive in a privatised state, surely the fact that it is competing with the private sector to provide services to government should encourage it to reveal all and behave in the most competitive way possible.

I also make the point and agree with the head of AGAL that there should be recognition of the magnitude and complexity of the task that the Government gave AGAL to achieve in a tight time frame and with limited resources when in fact it changed the nature of its functions only recently.
The Australian National Audit Office acknowledges, and I quote from the report:
. . . the Australian Government Analyst's concern that AGAL's competitors might attempt to use the published audit report to disadvantage AGAL in the market place.
The Auditor-General goes on:

Unlike a private sector body, however, AGAL is part of a Department of State and is therefore subject to a higher level of accountability to the Parliament and the public. External audit is part of that higher accountability, and, because of the assurance it provides, can be to AGAL's advantage. Any adverse commercial effects arising from a published audit report can be minimised when references to deficiencies are accompanied by reference to remedial action taken or in hand.
At this point it should be noted that remedial action is in hand in almost all the matters raised by the Auditor-General so that there will be higher efficiency in AGAL.

The overall point made in the report is that AGAL, in the opinion of the Auditor, has been managing well in the transitional stage of its move to commercial operations and has developed a greater client focus in the conduct of its work. There is scope for further improving the efficiency and effectiveness of its operations, particularly in the management of its public interest functions. I simply say that what the Auditor-General says is required is this: AGAL would benefit from having a coherent program for its public interest activities; some of the costs currently charged to public interest should be charged instead to clients, either directly or through overhead costs; AGAL would benefit from having a long term marketing and promotion strategy; AGAL should ensure that its pricing policy results in charges sufficient to achieve full cost recovery of its commercial activities; AGAL has generally achieved a high level of quality in its work, but there is a need for clients to be more involved in establishing acceptance criteria for analytical results; and AGAL should establish minimum standards for quality assurance applicable to all of its laboratories. In conclusion, the report says:
Implementation of the recommendations contained in this Report could achieve savings on expenditure on public interest activities and reduce the need for finance from the Budget.

Clearly, this report points very rationally to the sorts of problems facing these bodies. I would like to make only one further point where the Auditor-General deals with the Government decision to establish AGAL's public interest arrangements. The report states:

The government decision establishing AGAL's public interest arrangements also required that AGAL's clients pay the full cost of services. There are several reasons for this. AGAL's clients (mainly Commonwealth departments) are likely to impose higher efficiency demands than if AGAL were to do the work for the taxpayer via the public interest activities. If client departments bear the full cost they are in turn more likely to pass these costs on to the final users (for example, importers or agricultural producers) thus giving the necessary signals that will encourage improved behaviour (for example, better scrutiny of the overseas suppliers and better use of agricultural chemicals).

Costs passed on to the private sector reduce the burden on government revenue and thus the taxpayer. Should clients react to paying full costs by cutting back analytical programs it is they, not AGAL, who should properly be responsible for this decision.

In other words, there is an acknowledgment of the role of the marketplace in the Office of the Auditor-General and certainly in the decisions corporatising AGAL. However, there is still a long way to go and the problems involved in corporatisation, and not privatisation, are clearly outlined in this report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for inquiry and report by 30 November 1991:
The relations between Australia and the republics of Latin America, with particular reference to:
(a) extension of political and cultural exchanges;
(b) the further development of trade and transport links;
(c) the prospects for investment and joint economic ventures;
(d) joint participation in multilateral and other international organisations; and
(e) co-operation on matters of international law enforcement.
I seek leave to incorporate my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Until recently Australia's interest in Latin America, at both official and unofficial levels, was relatively limited. This was due to geographical realities; differing linguistic, cultural and institutional heritages; an absence of substantial commercial contact; relatively little person to person contact in the political and business spheres; and perceptions that the region was both remote and of little strategic significance to Australia.

Other powerful perceptions which limited Australian awareness and understanding of the region arose from Latin America's traditional orientation towards Europe and North America; the fact that Australia's exports were largely competitive with, and not complementary to, those of the region; and a historical absence of substantial trade links, compounded by poor transport connections inhibiting the development of new trade opportunities.

However, over recent years, interest in Australia-Latin America relations has increased considerably, due to developments both within Australia and in that region. This fresh focus marks the beginning of a process which can only be of benefit to the countries concerned.

The Latin American region comprises some twenty-three separate states or entities of government: the 11 republics of South America (Argentina, Brazil, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru, Suriname, Uruguay and Venezuela); the eight nations of Central America (Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua and Panama); one independent Commonwealth State (Guyana); one colony French Guiana; as well as the chief neighbouring islands: the Falklands (Great Britain) off Argentina and the Galapagos (Ecuador) off Ecuador.

Although Australia's relations with the USA, Japan, the Asian region and Europe warrant the high priority presently accorded to them, the expansion of our links with Latin America also deserves serious attention. In recent years, due principally to the consolidation of democracy in Latin America, its republics have increased their efforts to explore new forms of, mainly economic integration, to make possible stronger economic negotiating strength and establish a more attractive market for foreign investment.

Australia can seek to strengthen its ties with the Latin American republics in several ways, among them the extension of political and cultural exchanges; the further development of trade and transport links; increased investment and a greater readiness to participate in joint economic ventures; stronger joint participation in the activities of multilateral and other international organisations; and greater cooperation on matters of international law enforcement.
The new opportunities open to Australia and other nations by the liberalisation of Latin American trade are immense.

More regular government to government contact at the political and public service levels between Australia and the Latin American nations would be highly beneficial to all parties. Attempts at increasing bilateral cooperation in the cultural sphere are already underway. A Consortium for Iberian and Latin American Studies in Australia (CILASA) is to be established in July 1991, and it is planned to eventually set up an Institute of Latin American Studies at the Australian National University.

Latin America, with a population of 450 million, plays an important part in world trade. The region has a productive and commercial capacity and record which is often under-estimated. It produces 40 per cent of the world's silver and 25 per cent of its copper. Brazil is the world's largest sugar exporter. Australia's major Latin American trading partners are Argentina, Brazil and Mexico. Trade between Australia and Latin America grew from $A393 million in 1980-81 to $A1,346 million in 1989-90 (i.e. 1.5 per cent of Australia's world trade in 1989-90). Australia's overall trade volumes in the region-while not great-are nevertheless significant. In 1990 Australian-Latin American trade flows were greater than those with South Asia and about the same as with Eastern Europe. Clearly Australia is in a sound position to embark on a campaign aimed at increasing the volume and extent of Australian-Latin American trade.

Such a process is underway but Australia needs to do more and quickly because other nations and groups of nations have already divined Latin America's trading and investment potential. Japanese investment in the region has been steadily expanding since the mid 1980s. Like the USA, Japan has recognised that the issues of debt, aid, trade and investment are strongly linked. The provision of aid and the financing of debt are increasingly becoming the chief means by which new investment in Latin America is being financed.

Equally important have been recent developments in the free trade area between North and South America. In June 1990 President Bush announced the ``Enterprise for the Americas'' Initiative, committing the USA to playing a constructive role in making the Americas the first fully free trade hemisphere. And last November came the ``Partnership for Democracy and Development'' which aims to make it possible for Central America to participate in the ``Enterprise for the Americas'' Initiative. On 5 February 1991 the USA, Canada and Mexico began negotiations to establish (in 1992) what would in population terms be the world's largest free trade zone (360 million people compared with Western Europe's 326 million).

The need for quick and determined trade and investment approaches on Australia's part cannot be overstated. I would like to illustrate this by reference to two Latin American nations-Venezuela and Mexico.

Venezuela, mainly by virtue of its enormous oil reserves, has played a central role in encouraging greater economic integration within Latin America. Australia's exports to Venezuela have increased substantially in recent years ($A10.7 million in 1987-88 to $A66.2 million in 1989-90). Australian imports from Venezuela during the same period rose from $A1.3 million to $A12.7 million.

Venezuela's economic restructuring, including privatisations, offers considerable scope for Australian involvement in areas such as mining, agriculture and telecommunications. One Australian mining company is currently engaged in a joint venture gold mining operation in Eastern Venezuela. The Venezuelan oil industry has expressed an interest to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in securing Australian participation in oil exploration and development in Venezuela. BP Australia is already involved in the Venezuelan oil industry through co-operation in technology and research.

Senator Gareth Evans' visit to Mexico in October 1990 and President Salinas of Mexico's recent trip to Australia have confirmed that the Mexican/Australian economic relationship has significant potential. Areas of possible trade and investment interest for Australia include:
(a) the possibilities opened up by the privatisation process, including the banking, transport and minerals/metals sectors;
(b) the emerging demand for coal imported from Australia;
(c) Australian agricultural exports, particularly dairy products.

Dr Blewett will lead a high level business delegation to Mexico early in May. It has been organised by the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI). Specific areas to receive attention will be banking, telecommunications, coal exports, transport, minerals development and the provision of port infrastructure.

Australia has a solid base on which to build in the area of multilateral relations with Latin America. Our participation in recent years in the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations in the context of the Cairns Groups has forged closer ties with the five Latin American members of the Group (Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia and Uruguay).

Australia chaired the Cairns Group Meeting of Ministers held in Chiang Mai, Thailand in November 1989, at which agreement was reached on a comprehensive proposal for the global reform and liberalisation of agricultural trade. Australia subsequently played a central role in presenting this proposal, on behalf of the Cairns Group, to the GATT Negotiating Group on Agriculture in Geneva. These efforts to secure more equitable conditions for world agricultural trade, combined with Australian-Latin American co-operation on Antarctic matters and Australia's evident environmental concerns, especially in relation to Brazil, have strengthened Latin American-Australian ties significantly.

Some Latin American nations are looking to Australia with increased interest because of their wish to integrate more with the other Pacific Basin economies. A number of countries are already participating (or wish to participate) in regional economic organisations, for example, the Pacific Economic Co-operation Conference (PECC) and the Pacific Basin Economic Council (PBEC).
The benefits that could follow from greater cooperation with the countries of Latin America in combating drug trafficking is another area that needs to be more fully explored.

It is clear that considerable scope exists for establishing closer ties between Australia and Latin America for the substantial mutual benefit of both continents. The Committee aims to contribute to this process.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for inquiry and report: The potential for developing satellite launching facilities in Australia and the role of government in their development.

That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 to improve the promptness with which undertakings given to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances are implemented.
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Australian Democrats commend the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The Committee's work is a most important part of the work of the Senate, and that work is not often recognised and acknowledged as it should be.

However, there is a real concern that, very often, undertakings given to the Committee have not been honoured by the Minister who has given them. This is a matter of particular concern where those undertakings relate to the rectification of deficient or poorly drafted items of delegated legislation.

Ministers make promises based on the advice of public servants and those promises are made in good faith. However, in some cases the advisers have no intention of delivering on the undertakings they have persuaded their Minister to give, and in other cases, other more pressing matters interfere and the undertakings are forgotten.
In situations like these, the Senate is powerless. Even the most conscientious of Ministers-considering their workload-is tempted to treat the matter as water under the bridge.

My colleague, former Democrat Senator Norm Sanders, introduced a similar Bill in 1989 and the problem is no less important now than it was then. In essence, the Bill provides that when an undertaking is given but not honoured subsequently, the delegated legislation in question comes before the Senate again, as if for the first time. This means that the Senate again has the power of disallowance that it had the first time. This renewed sanction should concentrate the minds of those who advise Ministers to give such undertakings.
I believe that all Senators will welcome this Bill, which gives the Senate the power to ensure that promises made are promises kept.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Foreman) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 March, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1990 seeks to ensure that a corporation is not able to avoid the merger and acquisition provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974 by making acquisitions through associated or related companies. The background is that section 50 of the principal Act prohibits the acquisition, directly or indirectly, of any shares in any capital or assets of the corporation where either the acquisition would result in the corporation being in or being likely to be in a position to dominate a market for goods or services or the acquiring corporation is already in a position of market dominance and the acquisition would substantially strengthen the power of that corporation to dominate the market.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal amendments proposed by this Bill were announced by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) in a media release in 1990. The amendments relate to the acquisition of interests in entities that may lead to a breach of the principal Act but, due to technicalities, fall outside the current scope of the principal Act. The issue was raised in a court judgment in the Trade Practices Commission v. Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd and Others. In a sense, the judgment stated that an acquiring corporation would fall under the provisions of the Act but only where the subsidiary, acting for the acquiring corporation, acts as an agent for the acquiring corporation. It has become necessary to ensure that this loophole is closed and that where the subsidiary or associated corporation does not act as an agent it is still caught by the provisions of the Act.

This proposition was queried in the lower House. The Australian Democrats do not see any difficulty about confirming that this loophole is closed and will therefore support the Bill. However, we do intend to look at other provisions of the Trade Practices Act and wish to take this opportunity to rectify what we consider to be some deficiencies in the legislation as it currently stands.

The competition provisions of the Trade Practices Act prohibit various forms of conduct. The relevant provisions are section 46, dealing with misuse of market power, and section 50, dealing with mergers. The test for the former is whether the corporation has a substantial degree of market power and is prohibited from engaging in certain conduct, eliminating or substantially damaging a competitor, preventing entry to the market and preventing or deterring a person from engaging in competitive conduct in the market. Section 50 prohibits acquisitions which result in the acquirer being in a position to dominate a market.

It will be useful to advert briefly to the historical context of these provisions. Between 1974 and 1977, the Trade Practices Act prohibited acquisitions which resulted in a substantial lessening of competition in the market for goods and services. In 1976, the Swanson committee report recommended a narrowing of the test because it interfered unnecessarily with mergers of no real significance in the context of competition policy and also imposed administrative burdens on the Trade Practices Commission.

In the event, the 1977 amendments to the Act significantly narrowed the merger provision by inserting a test which prohibited acquisitions which result in or substantially strengthen, as I have said before, a position of control or dominance in a substantial market. The merger authorisation test was changed so that the Trade Practices Commission was not to authorise a merger unless it was satisfied that the proposed acquisition would result, or would be likely to result, in such a benefit to the public that it should be allowed to take place.

Some further major amendments were made to the Act in 1986, after the release of the 1984 Green Paper. The Green Paper included a proposal for a return to the substantial lessening of competition tests, in conjunction with the existing limitation that the affected market constituted a substantial market. It is this position that the Democrats prefer to the current dominance test. It will be the burden of our amendments to return to that position.

The context in which the present controls operate is, of course, the Government's emphasis on the need for Australian industry to become more efficient and internationally competitive. The only test that seems to be applied is that of size and long production runs. However, it is clear that, with advancing technology, long runs are not the only measure of efficiency; that we can, indeed, produce efficiency by shorter runs; and that we can sharpen up our competitive stance in international markets by greater competition. I believe that the history of Australian industry in the last few years shows quite clearly that we have had aggregation in size that has not sharpened our competition and that has in fact allowed people to occupy a position of monopoly in their particular industry.

In particular, we need to look at the media. We now have a situation where one corporate entity can control in excess of 60 per cent of that industry. It should, of course, be noted that an additional criterion enters the considerations of the Trade Practices legislation: the public interest. That a critical industry, such as the media, should be allowed to be aggregated to that extent is surely against the public interest.

The Australian Democrats believe that, taking into account all of these factors, the time has come to take another look at the provisions that govern the acquisition and mergers in Australian industry. While this will be dealt with in greater detail during the Committee stage of the Bill, I would like to foreshadow at this stage that we will seek to reintroduce the criterion of substantially lessening competition for mergers and other acquisitions; that we will, at the same time, introduce a requirement for the Commission to be notified when such mergers or acquisitions are planned. We suggest that the criterion for notification should be where the target of an acquisition is $10m.

Further, we will seek to introduce an amendment to empower the Commission to investigate, in certain circumstances, the existing State situation of market dominance in certain cases and may, as a consequence, if it finds that such market dominance is not outweighed by the public benefit, apply to a court for divestiture to ensure that an element of competition is reintroduced in that particular industry.

These are the intentions of the Australian Democrats on the trade practices legislation. I hope that the Government, which has been so active in promoting deregulation in Australian industry generally, will support these measures which will ensure that the consumer does not pay the bill and that Australian industry becomes more competitive in international markets. Similarly, I believe that the time has come for the Opposition to have a close look at that. A former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, has recently stated that we should return to the pre-1977 criterion. I believe that that should give Senator Panizza and others some food for thought. If the Opposition is serious in its position that we must have more competition in our industry, it should be pleased about tightening up the criteria and about introducing measures which will further competition in the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Opposition does not intend to oppose the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1990, we have several grave concerns that are philosophical in nature and practical in application. Basically, the intent of the Bill is to extend the application of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act, which deals with the prohibition of mergers and acquisitions found to result in market dominance. The amendments are intended to close a suspected or yet to be proven-although in one sense proven-loophole concerning the ability of a company to gain effective commercial control of another company through subsidiaries or unincorporated bodies, thus purporting to circumvent the existing provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Under this Bill, section 50 of the Trade Practices Act will take account of bodies corporate indirectly related or associated with a corporation when assessing whether a merger or acquisition results in market dominance.

SPEECH.PARA: There is substantial doubt as to whether this Bill is a condition precedent to effecting better trade practices law. This is borne out of the fact that there was concern that this loophole could be utilised by News Ltd in acquiring the assets of the Fairfax Group. News Ltd has denied any such intention. Even the outgoing Trade Practices Commissioner, Bob Baxt, has indicated that such a move would breach the Trade Practices provisions already in existence. So, in a way, the man of straw that was set out to be knocked down has been admitted by Professor Baxt to be just that-a man of straw.
