It is of concern that this Bill demonstrates a push by the Trade Practices Commission for greater powers and tougher penalties under the Trade Practices Act, including greater powers to order the divestiture of asset holdings. A problem with such laws is the difficulties which arise in defusing anti-competitive commercial activities. It is ironic that in some areas where market dominance is clearly defined, the Commission is totally without power. I particularly refer to those regulatory government schemes where the lack of competition is enshrined by legislation or institutional arrangement.

Take the area of telecommunications, where there is a most inconsistent application of trade practices law. The Commission claims that the tele- communications market will be treated in the same way as other markets but has been totally silent on the merger of Telecom Australia and OTC Ltd. This merger would have to rank as one of the largest corporate consolidations in this country's recent history. But, using the criteria of market dominance, the merged entity is indeed without peer. The debt ridden Aussat Pty Ltd is hardly a viable competitor under the current climate, and yet, despite this unambiguously clear market dominance by the megacom, not a word in opposition has been raised by the Trade Practices Commission, nor has there been any comment on Austel's plan to allow Telecom and OTC to price discriminate between themselves and a third carrier.

This is but one example of the inconsistency of the current approach. Indeed, there has been applause and encouragement from the Government on the amalgamation of unions and trade associations. The fact that this type of cartel goes unchallenged by the Commission and the deafening silence on statutory government monopolies raises serious questions as to whether the Trade Practices Commission is seriously a champion of consumer sovereignty.

It is curious that, even though private sector mergers and acquisitions provide much greater problems in defining market dominance, the Commission has no hesitation in raising doubts supposedly on behalf of the public interest. A problem in seeking to define dominance arises, for example, when a particular drawing of market boundaries is made irrespective of the inevitable expense of recognising markets for substitute goods and services.

At the very root of this legislation lies the myth that market dominance is inherently evil. Studies of mergers and takeovers indicate that they generally tend to succeed where there are reduced costs of production and tangible benefits to consumers. To accept the foundation of this legislation would be to ignore the simple truth that many firms obtain and, indeed, hold a market share by virtue of being consistently more efficient and competitive than their rivals.

Behind this legislation lies the view that near enough is good enough. I have never resiled from my rejection of that second best option, and I would not let this opportunity pass without registering my concern in regard to this Bill. I have spoken on many occasions in this chamber on the need for freer trade. I find it slightly hypocritical that, at a time when the Government has finally accepted our calls for reduced protection, it is erecting a further barrier to free trade of goods and services through the trade practices legislation. On one view of it, the Bill does amount to greater industry protection. Indeed, it flies in the face of many of the hopes and aspirations expressed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in their much vaunted industry statement.

Indeed, at a time when the Government, following its industry statement, is supposedly winding back protection, it is important to note that the Government does not have the courage to admit that it is prepared to maintain, if not increase, protection in other forms. Perhaps it is not really courage that is at stake: perhaps it is intelligence to realise where the good cause of free trade is best served.

But my concerns about the Bill extend beyond my commitment to freer trade. I also question the accountability of some of the Commission's actions. Given that the Trade Practices Commission is the only body that can undertake proceedings for breaches of the Trade Practices Act, on matters such as market dominance that which is said by the Commission is then de facto law in that area. The onus is therefore put upon the Commission to act in a certain, disciplined and predictable way. When the law is not certain, it is put into disrepute. Merger and takeover policy requires consistent reasoning rather than an ad hoc, informal negotiation, as is now the case.

Added to this is the question of due process. The Commission has questioned the capacity of ordinary courts to deal with issues of anti-trust policy and has expressed its preference for them to be handled by the trade practices tribunals. But the fact remains that the result can be frequently arbitrary, retrospective and capricious when proceedings are initiated by the Commission. For this reason alone, I think we should proceed with caution before the Commission is endowed with further power.

Indeed, the timing of the Bill itself is worthy of note. In this period of recession, there is a tendency, as firms close their doors as a result of this Government's policy failures, for market power to be concentrated in the remaining enterprises in any given industry. But legislation such as this closes the only pressure valve that the market possesses in times of economic downturn. Thus a firm that could be sold or merged simply will have to go to the wall because otherwise it would be in breach of the Trade Practices Act. Should such legislation be taken to its logical conclusion, it is clear that those firms which are in dire straits because of Government policy and facing that decision to close are condemned if they do and condemned if they do not, because competitors that remain in the field are allowed to become more dominant simply by the other firms going out of business.

Having outlined our concerns with the Bill and having said that we will not oppose its passage, there is one request that I put forward to the Trade Practices Commission-that in the interests of consistency the Commission be asked to address the market dominance of government trading entities and statutory authorities, to engender consistency and predictability in decisions on mergers and takeovers and to be aware of its duties to be finally accountable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no objection at all to the Trade Practices Amendment Bill and support all that Senator Bishop has had to say about it, but what has been proposed by the Australian Democrats causes me grave concern. The Democrats are proposing to move into an area in relation to section 50 of the Trade Practices Act about which I have grave concerns and about which I think honourable senators, if they were to apply their minds to what the Democrats are talking about, should also have grave concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of this matter is that for the period from 1974 to 1977 section 50 had a provision relating to mergers which in effect said that mergers, including takeovers and acquisitions of assets, are prohibited between corporations if they are likely substantially to lessen competition in a market for goods or services. That provision in section 50 was the subject of an inquiry by the Swanson Trade Practices Act Review Committee, which reported in August 1976. Following that report, in 1977 the Fraser Government introduced amendments to this provision, amendments which stand in place today. Those amendments refer to acquisitions as a result of which a party in effect obtains a position of dominance in the market. I suppose that to non-lawyers they are just some funny words about a merger which is likely substantially to lessen competition in a market and a merger which enables a company to obtain dominance in a market.

I stand on a fundamental principle of more competition in the market place. It is my belief that competition in the market place is an aim that we should all be pressing towards and an aim which will assist consumers. After all, they are the people that we are most concerned about-our consumers, the ordinary people of Australia. They want to be able to get good quality at the right price.

That is what the Trade Practices Act is all about. It seeks to ensure that there is an opportunity in the marketplace for such reasonable competition as will enable consumers to be sure that they are obtaining the best quality available at the best price so that they shall have some choice.

There has been a degree of debate as to whether the 1977 amendment substantially weakened section 50 so that this competition was weakened. It seems to me to be a matter of grave concern for the Parliament of Australia as to whether there has been a weakening of competition in the marketplace. I know that Senator Schacht has referred in this place on a number of occasions to his concern about, for example, the alleged lack of competition in the media. Some people have the audacity to suggest that the Fraser Government's amendments of 1978 were designed to enable Mr Murdoch to acquire additional newspapers. I do not know whether there is any merit in that proposition, but I think that Senator Schacht would allege that. Therefore, he would be interested in what is happening here at present.

The Government, to its detriment, has not addressed that problem in this amendment. It has brought forward this amendment to the Senate because of a problem in connection with a case concerning Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd. I should have thought the Government at that stage would have applied its mind to the whole of the provisions of section 50 as to whether the 1977 amendment had weakened the Trade Practices Act to such an extent that there should be further amendment.

Instead of the Government bringing this forward, the Australian Democrats are bringing it forward in their usual manner as some sort of amendment to be whipped into the Senate at the last moment for consideration. This is far too important a matter for that sort of consideration.

I have asked Senator Spindler on a number of occasions to let me have a copy of his proposed amendments; they are still not ready here tonight. He says that we will adjourn the debate after the Minister has spoken and he will bring in these amendments during the committee stage. I say to Senator Spindler here and now that, although I am gravely concerned about the existing provisions of section 50, I will not be able to give this matter five minutes consideration tomorrow morning when I read his amendments and say yes or no one way or the other. I hope that the Government and the Minister will address this problem and perhaps defer further consideration of this Bill for a period of some weeks while the Government considers the matter, or else refers it to a Senate committee to enable it to consider the matter. I believe that this is a matter of grave importance and one to which the Senate should apply its mind thoroughly and not casually.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have indicated their support for the Trade Practices Amendment Bill which has been presented to the chamber. The Bill attempts to fill a gap which might enable exploitation of some supposed weakness in the Act. I am sure that Australian competition law would be strengthened by the passage of this Bill. Honourable senators will know that the Bill is expressed to come into operation from 21 December 1990, the date of its introduction into the House of Representatives. We believe-and I take it that there has been support around the chamber-that will be an appropriate response to a matter of some technicality which was indicated to be a matter of concern arising out of the Trade Practices Commission on what is colloquially known as the New Zealand steel case.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is no need to go over that ground. In fact, I agree with almost everything that has been said by my friend and colleague Senator Austin Lewis, that the attempt by the Australian Democrats to use this Bill as a vehicle for consideration by the Senate of the very essence of the law relating to mergers, takeovers, monopolies, dominance, lessening of competition and the whole way in which the marketplace in Australia might operate is inappropriate. Indeed, there should be some other mechanism open to the Democrats to enable both chambers of the Parliament in a more considered and deliberate fashion to discuss the issues which are of great importance and to which Senator Spindler adverted.

I note, for example, that as recently as only two years ago, in May 1989, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs tabled its report Mergers, Takeovers and Monopolies: Profiting from Competition. As this was a report of the House of Representatives, I realise that the Democrats were unable to participate in that Committee. A range of members, both from the Government and Opposition parties in the House of Representatives, discussed all these matters and put together a considerable report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not bad for a House of Representatives committee.

—It is probably not of the standard that we would anticipate from a Senate committee, but nevertheless it tackles some of these problems. It does so in a way which is appropriate, by taking evidence from a wide range of interested parties and considering it in an atmosphere that is different from that which obtains in the chamber, or even in the new committee type meetings that we hold on Fridays on suggested amendments to Bills before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would ask Senator Spindler, if he intends to press for the deferral of the committee stage tonight, that we take the time of such a deferral to work out whether some other mechanism might be more appropriate for consideration of these issues. There is no doubt that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), having had the benefit of this report and having been asked by that Committee within five years of the tabling of the report to undertake a comprehensive review of the whole area of mergers, monopolies and the tests that might be applied, is already undertaking such a discussion with his ministerial colleagues as to whether there is cause to re-examine the test, and, if so, how this re-examination should proceed.

The Government is very aware that there is a lot of interest in this matter out in the general community, particularly in the business and legal communities. There would need to be extensive discussion and consultation before one could sensibly put forward any proposal, whether in support of the present position or seeking some modification of it. There is a lot more to possible modification than a simple reversion back to the lessening of competition test. There are many other threshold tests that might be applied, and we should take the time to hold discussions and consultations and to look comparatively at other mixed economies, to take Senator Bishop's point, where one has a range of corporations-statutory corporations, private sector corporations-acting in the marketplace. We could perhaps deal with Senator Bishop's matter of concern, namely, where one moves from a government owned enterprise with a monopoly position into a market situation of some competition being introduced by way of, for example, permitting a second carrier to operate in telecommunications.

These are very difficult questions. I do not think they can be dealt with in the committee stage of a Bill. I think that such is not an appropriate forum for such discussion if what is desired at the end is a very considered view. I believe that the Government would not be in a position either this week or next week, or possibly this session, to reach any view on the merit of any proposal which, for example, the Democrats might put forward by way of an amendment later this week, next week or during the course of the Autumn session.

I believe it would take many months of deliberation and consultation. The Attorney-General is discussing with his ministerial colleagues how such an examination might be undertaken, and I do not think I can take it any further than that. However, I indicate to Senator Spindler that, should it be desired that there be a deferral of the committee stage, it should be to enable us to have some discussion as to a more appropriate and parliamentary means of deliberating upon these important issues.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That consideration of the Bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it has disagreed to the new clause and amendment made by the Senate, for the reasons shown in the annexed schedule.
Ordered that consideration of the message be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.
Debate resumed from 20 February, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening the Senate has before it the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1991 for scrutiny and debate. This Bill is essentially the old Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1990. It is, once again, an omnibus, difficult taxation Bill covering a vast range of matters, many of which bear no relationship to each other. In fact it is appropriate that I should draw the attention of the Senate to the extraordinary handling of the Bill in the House of Representatives. I mention this because the handling of the Bill in that place was in stark contrast to the way in which it has been handled in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: In the House of Representatives, not only was the Bill brought forward with notice given only on the morning of the debate but less than half an hour before the debate was to commence a series of extensive amendments was introduced. The Opposition drew attention to these amendments and welcomed them but nevertheless the lack of notice was inexcusable. However, in addition, the explanatory memorandum which accompanied the Bill, though technically available, was not distributed to members of the House of Representatives.

So I ask the logical question in this chamber: what has this Government to fear from the House of Representatives spokesmen on taxation matters, either Mr Reith or Mr Rocher, to the extent that neither was given the courtesy of adequate time to even read the amendments or certainly have the opportunity to read the explanatory memorandum? Was it a question of the Government being afraid that they would point out problems in these amendments or was it just another example of the Government in that place preventing any meaningful debate?

With that sort of approach and attitude, it puts an additional responsibility on the Senate to get things right. I am encouraged by the support I have received from the Government in trying to ensure that we get the best legislation that is technically possible, even though we might disagree with some of the philosophical background to some of the particular matters. However, the Opposition notes that there are a number of problems with these Bills, such as the imputation provisions relating to life insurance companies, the treatment of partnerships, roll-overs into company group funds-all of which we will discuss later-and the need for different treatment in accident disability matters, because one accrues to profits and the other to shareholders, so the Government needs to distinguish for equitable treatment in this area.

However, it is appropriate that where we do receive assistance, we acknowledge and express gratitude to the Government and in particular the office of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) for the willingness to give us answers to a number of questions that I put in a form of notice. It was not the normal form of notice, except that the Opposition did provide the Government with 16 major areas of concern, and today we received extensive responses to most of them. I understand that Senator McMullan has agreed to incorporate these answers in Hansard and has organised with the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) to provide a disc that will incorporate both my question and the subsequent answer to ensure that the issues are dealt with seriatim. I should ask Senator McMullan at which stage he would like that incorporated in Hansard.

However, I also applaud the introduction of the bereavement allowance in this omnibus Bill, the extension of the mining, quarrying and all prospective deductions to expenditure outside Australia and, in principle, to the reduction of the 21 per cent marginal tax rate to 20 per cent.
At this stage I signal our opposition to the intention of the Australian Democrats to move an amendment cutting out those deductions which would be available to Australian companies operating abroad.

More importantly, I should point out what I perceive is a general overall problem in the drafting of the Bill. The Bill implements the wage tax trade-off announced by the Government on 20 November by amending the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 and reducing the lowest marginal tax rate from 21 per cent to 20 per cent. This is, naturally, a change that the Opposition applauds because the Opposition is strenuously in favour of reducing the impact of taxation and the income tax rates to very much lower levels.

However, together with these fundamental changes, which will affect every income earning citizen in Australia and will therefore need to be implemented quickly, we have, amongst others, complicated, intricate measures relating to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill, changes to capital gains legislation in relation to companies and partnerships and to changes to dividend imputation arrangements for life assurance companies. They are some of the more complicated matters. Naturally, such issues require extensive debate and consideration. Therefore, we submit that the taxation changes to the pay as you earn (PAYE) and provisional tax rates really should not be part of an omnibus, complicated tax Bill. We saw the complication last year when an election was called and there was a failure to pass Bills.

I ask the Government, for the purpose of simplicity and to help itself and particularly the Taxation Office which was put in a difficult situation on previous occasions, to ensure the speedy passage of such legislation, which involves changes to income tax rates, by having those changes in a separate piece of legislation rather than in omnibus tax Bills which often require debate and amendments, and have many technical aspects associated with them.

Therefore, I appeal to Senator McMullan that in future we have a separate Bill. When a complicated tax Bill does come before the Senate it is sometimes referred to a Senate standing committee and, consequently, the swift passage of this Bill-so relevant to all Australians who pay tax-is prevented. In fact, the Opposition indicated that if the Government was prepared before Christmas to separate these income tax changes we would have passed this section of the Bill. But, regrettably, the Government did not heed our encouragement on that occasion.

Traditionally, we have had two Bills when tax rates have been changed, one imposing the tax and the other declaring the rate. This Bill contains a new tax and Medicare rate, reducing it from 21 to 20 per cent, resulting from a previous imposition due to the amendments proposed by the Government and supported by the Democrats. However, today, because of those past changes regarding the imposition of taxes, we do not have an imposition Bill. This Bill is the first since that change. I believe that the effect will be to give greater powers to the Senate to amend because rate change legislation, as opposed to imposition tax Bills, is now amendable by the Senate in the first form but not in relation to the second. As part of a question on notice that I submitted to the Government, I specifically asked the Government:

Since this is the first taxation bill . . . since last year's legislation placing certain income tax impositions under permanent legislation, has the Government raised an unintended consequence of providing an additional power to the Senate in making Taxation Laws Amendment No. 6 an amendable Bill by the Senate since there is no current supporting Bill?
I have been informed that:

Section 53 of the Constitution imposes limitations upon the powers of the Senate to amend legislation. Where the Senate may not amend a Bill it may request the House of Representatives to make the amendment.
2. The Senate's powers to amend a Bill are established by section 53 of the Constitution, and clearly can't be amended simply by implication in a Statute.

I heartily agree with that. But, with respect, I do not believe that Senator McMullan has fully answered my question, because there is still an unintended consequence in that there is now a new range of amendable Bills. The difficulty arises especially where the tax burden increases. However, in this case, no problem arises because the tax burden has actually been lessened from 21 per cent to 20 per cent.

So, in addition, the Opposition was surprised at the tabling of Statutory Rules 1990 No. 398, the Income Tax Regulations (Amendment), which estimates the tax payable from January 1991 to reflect the decision of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 20 November 1990. It does seem strange that governments nowadays can issue regulations adjusting tax, including provisional tax for 1990-91, before the Bill is enacted. The Opposition really did not raise any major problems to that because we believed that the tax paying community had an entitlement to know the tax scales for deduction-and certainly for PAYE-purposes.

We note that the Crown law advice at the time was that the regulations adjusting the rate of tax instalments could be validly made before the Bill is enacted. I suppose we accept that, but it is an unfortunate practice and I hope it does not become too much of a precedent. So long as the regulations simply estimate the tax payable over the year and so long as the regulations are made for that purpose alone, then they are sufficient. But people do not always appreciate whether regulations are made for that purpose or for other purposes. It remains quite a moot point, because the regulations do not actually impose the tax rate. But I still hold to my point that there is no supporting legislation imposing these rates.

What this Bill is doing is opening the taxation Bill to the Senate and allowing the Senate a greater opportunity to amend. In this area of taxation rates the rates should be definite and not just estimates. I thank the Government for the answers to my question on notice in this area. When Senator McMullan tables the answers to the question I am sure that this chamber will understand the point I am making. I give him the courtesy of tabling his answers, but he has given me the opportunity of looking at them in advance.

A further area of concern is the answer that has been given that there is no particular time limit in terms of the law of how far the regulations in question can precede statute law. I believe that is a legitimate concern and one that should be raised by every responsible Opposition. Another concern is that the present situation of provisional taxpayers still being assessed on the old 1991 rates really should not occur. Again, I have raised this matter previously in the Senate, stating that provisional taxpayers will be disadvantaged.

The Government, in response to my questioning on this matter, stated that the financial impact on taxpayers will be minimal. The term `minimal' of course is relative. What may be minimal in terms of total revenue to the ATO may not be minimal to provisional taxpayers in these difficult economic times. Consequently, in clarifying the statement as to what was minimal in relation to my question to Senator Button on 6 December 1990, we have now received further advice from the Government that on an income of $25,000 the extra payment for provisional taxpayers as a result of being assessed on the old 1990-91 rates will be $96.10. I leave it to the discretion of individual people to decide whether $96.10 is a minimal payment, in difficult economic times, on $25,000. I think it is a matter of some concern.

I now make some general comments relating to the legislation. The Bill contains the amended imputation arrangements for life assurance companies, as announced in the 1991 Budget. The Life Assurance Federation of Australia (LIFA), following the announcement by the Federal Treasurer in August 1990 of the proposed changes to the arrangements, entered a submission pointing out to the Government a number of problems with the Budget announcements. I am pleased to acknowledge that the Government has acceded to the request by LIFA to provide for the apportionment of franking credits on receipt dividends, as well as tax paid on the statutory funds. In other words, under the amending legislation currently before the Parliament, franked dividends received by the statutory funds of non-mutual life companies will be able to be used to generate franking credits or franking dividends as paid to shareholders. As a result of this change, the 80 : 20 formula now should be much more acceptable to the industry.

However, with the legislation and new rules regarding the cancellation of franking credits which have been built up by mutual life offices there is, according to a number of tax experts with whom I have spoken, the possibility of some constitutional difficulty and the ATO and the Government have been made aware of it. In fact, one tax expert went so far as to say that it really invalidated section 55 of the Constitution. We tested this with the Government. The answer that we have received from the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is that the franking surplus does not constitute property. Because it does not constitute property, the requirement relating to the acquisition of property on just terms under section 51(xxxi) of the Constitution was, therefore, not applicable. But this question of what is property would really be the arguable point. I do not think that has really been satisfied. Furthermore, the Office of General Counsel does not consider that there is any authority for the view that the removal by the Commonwealth of this imputation credit really constitutes a tax and, therefore, is not affected by section 55 of the Constitution.

Naturally, the life insurance industry is disappointed that the Government has not accepted the force of LIFA's argument on a number of the other issues that it has raised, including the parity of treatment of mutuals and non-mutuals under transitional rules. I understand that the Government is concerned about the takeover of these non-mutuals in the use of the built-up franking credits-it is worried about the anti-avoidance provisions. Nevertheless, it is a cancellation of an entitlement-a built-up benefit-and I believe such action is always somewhat retrograde.

In addition, I understand that the industry has accepted the Government's decision on a number of issues with the possible exception of the formula method relating to accident and disability business. I wish to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that while it would be appropriate to incorporate a factual basis of apportionment of franking credits into income tax law, the development of a basis acceptable to Government and industry would be somewhat complex and difficult to exercise. Therefore, it is outside the time frame of the current legislation and we have been assured that it will examine in future. I believe it would be a good idea if further consideration could be given to this in the future, particularly in the light of the experience of the 80 : 20 formula, and if people applied their minds to the issue a satisfactory resolution could be obtained.

The formula for the determination of franking credits is not appropriate in relation to non-participating businesses-for example, accident and disability insurance-because there is no statutory restriction on the amount of profit or surplus arising from such business which can be distributed to shareholders. In fact, the Life Insurance Act allows for shareholders to receive 100 per cent of profits from non-participating businesses and, in practice, a proportion, if not all, of such surplus derived by companies is generally distributed to shareholders.

It is also relevant that accident and disability business transacted by life insurance companies is akin to general insurance in that it generally involves the underwriting of specific risks rather than the provision of savings investment facilities. Such business, in fact, is undertaken by both life and general insurance and is taxed on a similar basis to general insurance business, that is, the tax base is net premium-net of reinsurance and unexpired risk reserves less claims and expenses incurred plus net investment income.

Consequently, the industry believes that franking credits arising in respect of accident and disability business should be determined separately from other business. We have received an assurance from the Government that it intends to provide a mechanism to distinguish these. We look forward to the amendments at some future time because we believe that amendments are necessary to ensure that there is uniform treatment of accident and disability business, whether it is transacted by a life or general insurer and, thus, we have a concept consistent with a level playing field.

I think the Opposition is generally satisfied about the Government's resolution of a number of problems. I realise that we have embarked on new ground by giving the Government advance notice and, consequently, this speech during the second reading debate may appear to be something of a hotchpotch in that we are not making a general attack as we would have otherwise. In view of the fact that the Government has acceded to so many of our requests immediately, and has also given us undertakings that other aspects are under active consideration, perhaps other matters are subject to longer term review. Perhaps section 160ZZO comes within that. Those aspects have been addressed by virtue of the very late amendment that appeared in the House of Representatives that I referred to earlier, and also by amendments which the Government has yet to move in this House of which we have received some notice.

Let me now go on to another aspect. I must also acknowledge certain changes to division 19A. That did reflect very sloppy drafting. We notice that there are certain changes to pick up the problems in new section 61. At this point I believe that the Government has certainly partly clarified the problem, particularly with relation to third party indebtedness or third party loans which were a problem in the original drafting.

I would also like to draw attention to aspects of the Bill which I refer to as somewhat cumbersome and complex and which produce unintended consequences. I indicated in one of my 16 questions the need to adopt a practice that is now widely accepted in New Zealand where the tax section of the Treasury, the tax office and the Parliamentary Counsel, who are all instrumental in framing the tax laws, come together and form a consultative committee.

We now have an unsatisfactory situation where a concept is devised in the tax office of the Treasury, passed on to the Tax Office which then puts on its own provisions and interpretations and the parliamentary draftsman then seeks to protect his position. I believe that perhaps we get over-technical wording in terms of the presentation of Bills because of the separate box-like approach-a protection that people feel they have to build into the pending legislation to ensure that nothing slips through.

I want to draw the Senate's attention to a matter which was raised by Mr Turnbull, the First Parliamentary Counsel, before Senate Estimates Committee. He referred to a lack of communication that occurred between these three elements as being a problem in the drafting of legislation. Therefore, I believe that we could be well served by adopting the New Zealand example, as Professor Arnold has suggested, by implementing a consultative committee when framing taxation legislation. I believe that our taxation laws and our amendments to those laws would be better served if the Government framed its laws in this manner through the use of a consultative committee. Of course, this Bill already illustrates the need for such a committee. I think the commercial world was aghast at the original changes to section 160ZZO. A number of submissions from prominent businessmen and commercial institutions within Australia were forwarded to the Government at the time of the original drafting. I believe that this is the third or fourth attempt that we have before the Senate to try to overcome these particular problems.

I thank the Government for giving consideration to the number of problems that I raised in those 16 questions and other discussions that I have had with it. I must say that I have received some criticism about this particular approach-that we are giving the Government notice, and forewarning and forearming it about the issues that we intend to raise in this debate. However, I would like to point out to the Senate that on this side of politics, particularly when I am in charge of Bills, I intend to try to get the best possible legislation to remove as much complexity as we can, and to improve the understanding of our taxation laws in a manner which is acceptable to the Taxation Office, the practitioners who have to advise on them and the taxpayers who have to obey them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1990 which was formerly the Taxation Laws Amendment (No. 6) Bill 1990. The contents of this omnibus Bill were competently detailed by Senator Watson, the previous speaker. It is, as I said, an omnibus Bill dealing with a number of areas of taxation law including the personal tax cuts which commenced on 1 January 1991 and a reduction in the medical expenses rebate from the existing lowest marginal tax rate of 21 per cent to the new rate of 20 per cent. The Australian Democrats are not happy about this particular change. We opposed the reduction to 21 per cent when it was before the Senate last year, and we believe that the further reduction to 20 per cent does not take account of the needs of people who are on low incomes and who incur substantial medical expenses.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill further includes a simplification of the capital gains tax consequences of company group restructurings and contains a further strengthening of anti-avoidance provisions dealing with such restructurings, and these provisions are welcome. Further, there is the cancellation of imputation credits which would otherwise arise for mutual life insurance companies and 80 per cent of those applicable for the statutory fund of non-mutual life insurance companies to ensure that unintended advantages do not arise for prospective new owners of these institutions. Once again, the Democrats are supportive of these provisions.

Further, the Bill contains an exemption from income tax for certain bereavement payments made under social security and veterans affairs legislation, and we welcome those. There is also provision against the double dipping of bad debt deductions by financial institutions and the protection of taxation information held by the Commissioner of Taxation. However, the second last point is one that the Australian Democrats are concerned about because we believe that in this particular area the Government has left a loophole which should be closed.

The problem of double dipping on bad debts incurred by foreign branches of banks was in fact identified by a House of Representatives committee as long ago as 1987. In our opinion, the proposed provisions-which, incidentally, pick up an alternative Budget proposal of the Australian Democrats-can be easily circumvented and may also be technically flawed. The legislation appears to allow institutions with non-performing loans-just another euphemism for bad debts-held through branches in comparable tax countries to transfer those loans to branches in low tax countries and subsequently write off the loan as a bad debt, thereby obtaining partial tax relief in Australia.

The only way that such a practice could be stopped appears to be through the use of the general anti-avoidance provision in part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This appears doubtful as the proposed provisions assume that such transfers are legitimate. We believe the onus with regard to this matter needs to be shifted to the taxpayer to prove that when such transactions are being carried out they are bona fide and do not require the use of part IVa of the taxation Act.

The other thing that the Australian Democrats are extremely concerned about is the fact that concessions are being made available in many areas to companies which engage in commercial activities offshore. Concessions are available to domestic mining operations, industrial property and income-producing buildings, and it is proposed that these concessions be extended where these activities occur outside Australia. This was announced in last year's Budget and conforms with Treasury's policy of capital export neutrality. What this really means is that Australian businesses are in fact encouraged to shift their operations overseas.

It is the Democrats' view that Australian companies should be encouraged to carry out their commercial operations in Australia rather than shift them overseas, thereby occasioning a considerable loss of commercial activity and employment in Australia. Since many countries provide incentives to encourage foreign investment, these foreign countries will often be preferable for Australian firms over Australian opportunities. We believe we should not be adding to these incentives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do they go offshore?

—I suppose that Senator Panizza would love to have more companies go offshore. He clearly seems to favour that. If he does not, he will obviously vote for the amendment that I propose to move in this particular area. I argue in fact that the tax system should favour Australian economic activity over foreign activity by restricting concessions to local development in Australia which would assist our economy rather than the economies of countries overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed extension of depreciation to buildings is particularly deplorable. It can do nothing but encourage the development of Australian companies outside Australia-for instance, the building of a head office in Hong Kong. I am sure that Senator Panizza would welcome that. The proposal also extends to buildings used for research and development activities. But the question remains: why should Australia encourage the offshore development of such facilities? The Australian Democrats will certainly oppose it.

The Australian Democrats will take this opportunity to move several other amendments which we believe should have been considered by the Government in this Bill, as it is an omnibus Bill. One of them is to remove tax deductibility for that part of salaries which exceed $200,000 per annum. In recent years we have seen a veritable explosion of executive salaries in Australian industry and, in particular, in those companies which have accumulated paper profits but have not contributed to the productive efforts of Australian companies and the Australian economy.

I believe that it is also useful in this context to look at what has happened to the income and tax scales in Australia to see how they have worked out in recent years. I quote from a recent article entitled `Wealth by stealth' a rich irony for the lower paid' by Richard Farmer:

The truth is that a trade union-based party, which has skilfully sold the virtues of wage restraint to the masses, has delivered amazing wealth to the minority. From 1982-83, the year before Labor came to office, to 1988-89, the last year for which the Taxation Commissioner's figures are available, after-tax incomes of the top fifth of taxpayers have increased by about 57 per cent. Down in the bottom fifth, they have gone up by just 14.1 per cent.
In another portion of the article he says:

The bottom 80 per cent of taxpayers benefited from wage rises and tax changes to see their after-tax incomes rise from 14.1 per cent for the bottom fifth, 33.2 per cent for the second fifth and around 38 per cent for the third and fourth fifth. At best they kept up with the changes in the cost of living. Yet top-bracket tax rates were cut and together with imputation, they provided the top 5 per cent of taxpayers with an 88.8 per cent increase in after-tax income.

These figures show clearly that the Government should pay some attention to shifting our income tax scales towards a more progressive scale but at the same time-and this is what this present amendment is directed to-it should ensure that it is not the community or the taxpayer that funds the explosion in executive salaries. It is clear that salaries above $200,000 per annum do not deserve community support and subsidisation through the public purse.

The other amendment which the Democrats wish to move on this occasion concerns the removal of tax deductibility for advertising of alcohol and tobacco products. In terms of revenue, it would gain $32m for tobacco and $40m for alcohol. We believe that the Australian taxpayer should not subsidise, by allowing a tax deductibility, the immense costs that are being incurred by the Australian community-some $14.3 billion every year-through the detrimental effects on health which are a burden on our health system, and absenteeism and sickness at work which cause considerable losses to our industry.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak very briefly. While it is a valued role of parliamentary privilege to bring to light examples of injustice suffered by ordinary Australians at the hands of larger institutions, it is equally important that this right is not abused. We have a duty not to malign people on the public record on the basis of totally misleading and inaccurate information. This is exactly what happened in the adjournment debate in the House of Representatives on 6 March when the honourable member for Kennedy, Mr Hulls, launched a savage attack on Lumley General Insurance for being `charlatans' and for `kicking its clients when they were down'. These are serious and destructive allegations about a fine insurance company.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the honourable member for Kennedy, the barge Tasma overturned in January when conveying essential supplies to isolated Gulf communities cut off from road communication by flooding. I emphasise the words `essential supplies' because the honourable member used those words a number of times during his speech to the House of Representatives. He told the House of Representatives that because the goods were insured for road transport only, Lumleys had denied liability without a formal claim having been submitted.

There is a strong inference, not to say an allegation, that Lumleys has refused to assist a client in an emergency when the goods in question were essential supplies. The honourable member for Kennedy had talked about shortages of milk, fresh produce, sugar, flour and toilet paper. The salient fact conveniently ignored by the member-anxious to impress his constituents and to bash the insurance industry-was that the goods in question were alcohol supplies for the Normanton Hotel.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is essential!

—Perhaps in the view of Senator Colston and some others, alcohol is a necessity of life, but this does not alter the fact that the Parliament was misled. The question could well be asked why the crew of the barge was put at risk for the delivery of such a cargo. The emotive charge of a heartless insurance company refusing to assist clients and contributing to the hardship suffered by Gulf residents is baseless and dishonest.

SPEECH.PARA: The second aspect of the attack on Lumleys was its alleged rejection of its client's claim. Again, it is a fact that the client in question has not so much as asked Lumleys for a claim form. When a company has not heard from its own client, it is premature, to say the least, for instant judgments to be made as to the propriety of its actions. Lumleys would never refuse to send a claim form when so requested. I do not believe there is any insurance company in this country that would refuse to send a claim form when so requested. Unfortunately, the honourable member for Kennedy did not see fit to treat the truth with respect. It is an absolute untruth therefore to assert, as the member for Kennedy did, that Lumleys `has even refused to issue my constituent with a claim form'. The insurance policy in question specifically restricts the transport of liquor to road transport because of problems experienced with sea transport. It was accepted that the marine cover would cost more.

I have risen to put straight this record, not merely because I despise the use of misleading statements, but because I am concerned at the possible damage to a reputable company chosen as an arbitrary target by a member of the Hawke Labor Government. With singular vindictiveness, the member for Kennedy stated that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) should institute an effective witchhunt against Lumleys, an investigation as to `its fitness to be involved in the insurance industry'. This is not, therefore, just a matter of an unfair, mistaken accusation. It is a deliberate use of parliamentary privilege to damage a commercial reputation. Indeed, the Minister should look at the matter to learn of the disgraceful conduct of the honourable member for Kennedy.

There is truly no excuse that the honourable member for Kennedy is unaware of the truth of the matter. This was conveyed to him by facsimile on 11 March by the managing director of Lumleys, Mr Sprangers. Yet as at the end of last week, Mr Hulls has chosen not to respond to this communication. It was open to him to have the matter clarified over the three sitting days following 11 March. He saw that he did not need to do so. Perhaps the honourable member for Kennedy is so nervous about the next election that he resorts to such unfactual statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wouldn't have any trouble from the Liberals up there.

—Perhaps the insurance industry is being set up for some kind of general scapegoating to cover the failings of the Hawke Labor Government. I wish I could hear the interjections of the Deputy President, Senator Colston, who is obviously supporting these untruthful statements made by his Queensland colleague.
—I raise a point of order. I regard that as a reflection on myself. I do not know whether the statements are untruthful, but if they are---
—What is your point of order?

—If Senator Knowles would like to wait, she might find out. I will start again, Mr President. I regard that statement as a reflection upon myself. I am not aware of whether the statements were untruthful, but I did not indicate--
—It is not a point of order! It is a personal explanation.
—Order! I am waiting to hear Senator Colston's point of order.
—I did not indicate that I was supporting untruthful statements.

—Unfortunately, I did not hear the interjection and I think it would be better if the debate continued. If you have a point to make, Senator Colston, I think you could make it in a personal explanation.
—Did you rule on the point of order? There was no point of order.
—That is what I said.
—I presume you have ruled that there is no point of order.
—I said that.

—I am disturbed that the Deputy President, Senator Colston, has seen fit to say that he is now unsure of what the truth is, given the fact that I have made a truthful statement in this place that the goods were not essential as described by Mr Hulls; they were alcohol, not food requirements. The insured did not even ask the insurance company for a claim form. Yet Mr Hulls has said that Lumleys had refused the claim sight unseen. I think it is a very sad reflection on this Parliament and on this Senate that the Deputy President is now seeing fit to side with Mr Hulls in this accusation against Lumleys. In any event, the adjournment speech of 6 March was simply a disgraceful misuse of privilege and I am glad to have set forth the facts of this matter, even if Senator Colston does not agree with the facts.

—Interjections are disorderly and I try to abide by that ruling as much as I possibly can, as opposed to Senator Knowles. Sometimes Senator Knowles makes statements which override my wish not to make objections. She said that I was siding with Mr Hulls on some pretext and that he is obviously worried about his chances in the next election. I said that he would not have much trouble from the Liberals up there. That was my comment and it was nothing to do with what Mr Hulls was doing or otherwise.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Irish Convicts-British Justice-Death Penalty-Australian-Ireland Social Security Agreement-Irish Australian of the Year

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to tonight's adjournment debate will hopefully be brief. It will be on a subject that is dear to my heart and indeed dear to the hearts of all honourable senators, particularly the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), who is so encouraging to me. I thank him for that. My topic is Ireland and I want to break it up into four particular themes.

SPEECH.PARA: Three years ago-in 1988-Australia celebrated its bicentenary. This year we celebrate or remember another 200-year-old event in the development of this nation. It is 200 years ago this year that the first convict ship left the shores of Ireland to bring those unfortunate migrants to this country. A large number of other people arrived since that date until deportation was stopped in the 1850s or so. Some 40,000 people came directly from Ireland as convicts and 16,000 others came from other parts of the world. A lot has been written about those convicts and the injustices that they have suffered, both in their conviction and in their transportation. Unfortunately, their lives in Australia were very short.

I want to recognise that particular anniversary and move on to another theme of injustice. I refer, of course, to the release from prison in England some three to four weeks ago of a group of people who are worthy, I believe, to be named in this place-Richard McIlkenny, Patrick Hill, Hugh Callaghan, Gerard Hunter, William Power and John Walker. Those people are collectively known now and have been known for a number of years as the Birmingham Six. They have something in common with another group of people from Britain, the Guildford Four, who were released from prison in 1989 after serving 14 years in prison for crimes they did not commit. Previous to that, a group of people known as the Maguire Seven were gaoled in 1976 for allegedly running bomb factories but were subsequently released as well. The convictions against those people were supposedly for unlawful crimes. In each instance it has been found by the British system of justice that the evidence on which they were convicted was indeed forged. That was the case with the Birmingham Six. After 16 and a half years of incarceration in the system, the prosecution in the final appeal was not able to offer evidence.

I am very grateful for the final release of those people. I look forward to the payment of compensation to them, their families and their friends in the vicinity. The incarceration not only hurt the individuals but also hurt their family members and relatives throughout the world. Compensation in monetary terms will not be enough. I do not know personally what will be enough. I do look forward to the results of the royal commission which has been set up to inquire into the system of British justice. Hopefully in future years we will find that travesties of justice, such as I have indicated here tonight-I have only instanced three and there are indeed many more- will never be allowed to happen again.

At a future time in the Senate I will be pursuing the fact that the Australian system of justice is very loosely based on the British system of justice. I wonder and certainly hope that travesties of justice such as I have indicated earlier have not occurred in Australia and indeed will not be allowed to occur.

I want to send out a very salutary message particularly to my electorate in Western Australia, although I know that this has happened in other parts of Australia. In my electorate of Western Australia there has recently been a demand for the reintroduction of the death penalty or capital punishment. There is no death penalty or capital punishment in existence in England at the moment and there has not been for years. Had there been a capital punishment system in Britain 16 1/2 years ago, six people proven innocent by the system of justice might actually be dead. There is no way that we can compensate people for lawfully taking a life. I argue against capital punishment. I certainly will do everything in my power to resist its reintroduction. I ask those who advocate the reintroduction of it into Australia to think of the lessons of these people. The Birmingham Six were convicted of murder under the British laws of justice on evidence which has now been proven to be forged.

Unfortunately, there is yet another Australian link between Britain and Ireland. I have it from the Sun Herald newspaper of 17 March this year, which incidentally was St Patrick's day, that the former detective superintendent who led the prosecutions on these particular individuals, George Reade, is currently resident in Australia. I hope that Australia is not being used as a clearing house for people of the calibre of George Reade.

My next theme is another historic link that has recently developed between Ireland and Australia. Yesterday afternoon in the Irish Embassy, the Irish Minister for Social Welfare, Dr Michael Woods, TD, and the Australian Minister for Social Security, Senator Graham Richardson, signed a bilateral agreement on social security between Ireland and Australia. The main purpose of the agreement will be to protect the rights of persons who have worked in Ireland and lived in Australia. It does this by allowing social security contributions paid in Ireland and periods of residence in Australia to be counted towards benefits in either or both countries. It is an agreement that will have benefit bilaterally for people from one nation to another. I hope that many people will live long and successful lives in retirement and will enjoy those reciprocal agreements.

It was a pleasure to meet Dr Woods whilst he was in Australia. I was fortunate enough to be able to attend a number of functions with him, as indeed were some members of the Senate. He is a very pleasant individual with a wonderful singing voice that some of us were able to enjoy on a number of occasions. He has the honour of being maybe not the first politician to sing in the Sydney Opera House, although he certainly gave that a try at an impromptu concert last Sunday.

Finally I want to express an immediate thank you to a Mrs Nancy O'Donnell who is the president of the Irish Week Association in Sydney or indeed Australia. Nancy was instrumental in dragging me down to Sydney on 15 March this year, allegedly, as it now turns out, to present the trophy to the Irish Australian of the Year. After four trophies for different purposes were presented, I realised that something was wrong because nobody had given me a brief or told me who the recipient of the fifth and main one was going to be until I was called up to receive that trophy.

I must admit publicly that, on this occasion, despite my profession as a politician, I was left somewhat speechless. I am glad that we did not have Hansard in the Parliament House in New South Wales at this bipartisan function organised by the President of the Legislative Council and the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Fahey. I was speechless on that night. When I did manage to utter some words, they were not the best set of words I have ever put together, so I am grateful that Hansard was not present on that night.

I am deeply honoured to receive this award. Whilst the award was presented in Sydney, the nominations came from Irish clubs and associations across Australia. This is the first occasion on which a Western Australian has been honoured to receive the trophy, which proves that the New South Wales Irish community is not narrow-minded and secular and that it looks further than its own State. I have since found out that my nomination for the award came from an organisation in Canberra. During the coming year in which I will hold the honour, I trust that I will be able to serve well the Irish community within this country and that I can work towards the settlement of its members and their assimilation into the community. I will be doing all things possible within my power as a member of this Parliament to ensure that the number of Irish people-it is rumoured that more than one-third of the Australian population are either Irish or of direct Irish descent, which makes us a not insignificant force-as a proportion of the Australian population is maintained or perhaps grows.

I particularly thank Nancy, the person who nominated me. I wish that she had given me some warning so that I might have been better able to construct my speech. As I say, Hansard was not present on the evening. After all, it is a night for honesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In 16 days time, on the twenty-fifth of this month, Anzac Day marches will be held around Australia. I would like to use this adjournment debate in the Senate tonight to call on all of the organisers who are arranging those Anzac Day parades to invite the returning Gulf war veterans to lead the 1991 Anzac Day marches in their communities.

SPEECH.PARA: Naval personnel are not madly keen on marching. Their attitude, in much the same way as the Royal Australian Air Force, with which I have some acquaintance, is that if they wanted to march they would have joined the Army. Nevertheless, they can be persuaded to march. That is why I have used the expression that they be invited to lead the march. I am not suggesting that it be made an order, nor am I suggesting that they all be asked to parade in Sydney or Melbourne. The naval personnel that I know would not like that-some might; but most that I know would rather not be up-front in the marching area.

I am sure that this would be an opportunity for the community that they represent, that they have served, to recognise their contribution. Further, this would be an opportunity for that unique band of Australians-those veterans who have served this country in World War I, World War II, the Malayan Emergency, the Korean War, Konfrontasi and the Vietnam War-to be welcomed back as having served their country in a war, to be recognised as colleagues and to pay a tribute to them.

Traditionally, Anzac Day has been devoid of political posturing and the inclusion of these Gulf veterans in the position of honour in Anzac Day parades would be an appropriate means of recognition of them. I do hope that the opportunities which are presented on the return of these veterans do not lead to political posturing. I am a little concerned that there may be some of that. I remind the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that these people are the troops of the Governor-General, not the troops of the Prime Minister, and that if there is any formal welcoming and salutation to take place it should be done by the Governor-General.

As I say, I envisage that communities around Australia that are having Anzac Day marches ask their returning Gulf personnel to lead the parades. Of course, we are fortunate that we suffered no casualties in the 43-day Gulf war. However, our service personnel were exposed to all of the hazards, dangers and stresses of the war and their kin were subject to all of the associated anxieties which, I might say, could only have been exacerbated by the extensive television coverage of the war.

Australia owes a particular debt of gratitude to the Royal Australian Navy and the other services that supported our ships in the Gulf during Operation Desert Shield and the war. I put to the Senate: what better way to acknowledge their contribution to the coalition forces than by inviting our Gulf war veterans to lead the 1991 Anzac Day parades?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last time I spoke on the adjournment in relation to a matter that concerned an Aboriginal was, as I recall, very early in my term in this chamber. That matter related to an occasion when I had been leaving my electorate office and saw three policemen using what I regarded as excessive force to put a young Aboriginal into a paddy wagon. The complaint I raised was that my complaint to the police complaints authority had not been dealt with as promptly as it should have been. It is perhaps appropriate to say that that matter has now been dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that a change was achieved, albeit a small change. The change that I am told is to be achieved-I have not checked that it has been achieved-is simply that a change will be made to the training manual for police officers in the use of their batons. Apparently, we need to tell police officers that they do not smash people in the kidneys with a baton. I do not know whether that says anything about the brightness of the people who are employed or the manuals as they were written. I am told that the training manuals are to be changed. I am also told that the police orders, or daily orders-whatever they are properly referred to-will be changed to make it abundantly clear that whenever a baton is used an incident report will have to be made. I believe that there is a possibility that more than that could have been achieved by complaining, but at least that was achieved.

Tonight, I want to raise a separate matter in relation to the training of Aboriginals in Australia. Again, this incident was gained from first-hand experience. This area is not one that I spend a lot of time looking at in terms of Federal funding. This is a personal experience. On Saturday, I had occasion to be driving from Ulanda, a town on the west coast of South Australia, to Adelaide, which necessarily meant that I had to go through Port Augusta. I stopped to have lunch at a chicken shop in Port Augusta. While waiting for the lunch to be prepared, I felt the presence of someone behind me whom I assumed wanted to look at the counter that I was standing in front of. I moved aside and said, `I am sorry, do you want to look at this counter?'. I found myself looking straight into the eyes of someone who must have been pretty close to being a full blood Aboriginal. He seemed a happy enough bloke and there was a mutual exchange to the effect that he did not really want to look at the counter anyway. Nonetheless, I had some passing and light-hearted conversation with this fellow, as did my husband.

We moved to the back of the shop to get some drinks out of the fridge and three young men came in, one of whom chose to make not that offensive a remark but a passing derogatory remark about the Aboriginal person's dog, which was sitting outside. We may not have expected it to, but the remark occasioned some concern. The Aboriginal took that as something of an insult and marched outside saying, `Well, I will wait for you outside'. He obviously thought better of this after a few minutes and came back inside, and a further exchange of words took place between these three gentlemen and the Aboriginal.

I should have said that at no time did I feel any apprehension as a consequence of his presence; nor did I see any apprehension in the Aboriginal's eyes. He might have had a few drinks-I do not deny that-but from my perspective he was not causing anyone any trouble or any harm. It is also fair to say that the young man who had made a derogatory remark about this tough-nut looking dog outside the chicken shop realised that he had made a mistake and tried to make some complimentary or appeasing remarks about the dog to ease the situation but, as I have said, the Aboriginal left saying, `I will meet you outside', and then came back into the shop. At that point the two gentlemen who thus far had not spoken launched into some further remarks, not about the dog but about the Aboriginal himself.

It is probably not appropriate to repeat those remarks in here, but they were not complimentary. A portion of them at least should be left out. I do not think it is necessary, wise or does any credit to us for young teenagers to be saying to people who appear to be full bloods, `It is just a b . . . shame that the whole damn lot of you were not shot when we first got here'. That sort of thing in what one would otherwise regard as a civilised country strikes me as being indicative that our race relations are not all that they should be.

I just want to emphasise that this fellow was not causing any trouble. This is an example of where someone came into a chicken shop and was making a few light-hearted remarks. Sure, he had a few under his belt, but at that point he had not been causing any trouble. A fair round of abuse came from the two gentlemen who prior to that stage had not spoken. Again, the gentlemen who had first made some semi-insulting remarks about the Aboriginal's dog tried to calm the situation down, but not to much effect.

The woman who owned the chicken shop, or appeared to be managing it at the time, basically pointed at the Aboriginal and said, `You, out', and he left in compliance with that instruction. She made a remark that she had had trouble with him before and that he did not like her. She had to say, `If you don't go, I will call the police', and as he was going she called the police in any event. She indicated that she had had trouble with him in the past.

I make no judgment with respect to her because she was looking after premises that may or may not have been owned by her. She indicated that she had had some trouble in the past, and perhaps from her perspective and the historical knowledge that she had she could see trouble brewing and thought the best thing to do was to call the police. But I do not say the same with respect to the three gentlemen at all. I do not know from their perspective what trouble they may have had with the Aboriginal community or with this particular Aboriginal in the past, but there was certainly no indication that they had had any trouble in the past and there was certainly no indication that they were going to have any trouble that day but for the remarks they chose to make.

The story does not end there. It gets slightly better. When the police arrived, it appeared that they did what I would have thought was the right thing: namely, they had a chat with the fellow and reintroduced him to one of his mates on the other side of the road, and he left quite happily. I assume that nothing was done to him as a consequence of that, but it was a bit galling to see these three teenagers smiling quite happily at the policeman, waving and saying, `See you later. Thanks very much for coming to bring some calm into the situation'. But for the involvement of these teenagers, the situation would have remained calm in any event.

If it were I calling the police, I would have been calling them for the disturbance created by these three young men. While I normally take the view that one is entitled to use whatever language one likes, either in private or even perhaps in public if one is not offending others, if there are any bones to be pointed, there were certainly some bones in terms of breaches of the peace that could have been pointed at these three young men. But they appear not to have been.

As I say, I do not go through Port Augusta that often. I do not have that much experience with Aboriginals at all. But, from an outsider's point of view, this was a pretty disgusting thing to witness. If I were a tourist in Port Augusta, I could be forgiven for wondering just exactly where I was. One certainly would not think one was in the sort of country that we say we are. I think those teenagers did no credit either to Port Augusta or, for that matter, to the race relations that we want to see practised in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic I wish to address tonight is that of arms sales, the international arms trade which is going on apace in the wake of the Gulf war. I am particularly pleased that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is here this evening. He probably will not listen to a great deal of what I have to say, but some of it may percolate through. I know that the Minister is concerned about this issue of arms transfers internationally, and of course has spoken, with some effectiveness I believe, in the United Nations on this subject. I look forward to the recommendations that come out of the United Nations expert committee on that subject, which I believe will be forthcoming in a few weeks or months.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that we see all of this business of arms trading and arms transfers in light of the huge arms bazaar which is planned for Canberra in November this year-the Australian International Defence Equipment Exhibition 91. Since I spoke about this issue in the Senate a couple of weeks ago, Newsweek has published an article called `Arms for Sale'. It makes very depressing reading indeed. A few of the lines from it are enough to indicate that there is a big bonanza on, and of course Australia, hosting this huge arms bazaar in November, indicates that Australia as a nation supports this push and that we will try to cash in on it wherever possible. I think that is totally reprehensible. To quote one buoyant lobbyist who was speaking to the writers of this article for Newsweek:
The next big push in the defense industry will be to exploit the Middle East. This is not arms control. This is an arms opportunity.

The countries of the Middle East are still recovering from the war, which I think is far from over, of course, as we can see-particularly with what is happening to the Kurdistan people in northern Iraq-but their governments are already thinking about how to prepare for the next one. This is one of the terrible legacies of any war, that it creates the seeds for the next war. We have seen it happen so many times in the past, and as a society we do not seem to be able to learn the lessons of history, that war creates more violence and does sow the seeds of political instability for the future. That is exactly what we are seeing in the wake of this Gulf war, claimed by the United States and its cash box coalition as a great victory. It is no victory in any sense at all if one is opposed to war as a method of conflict resolution, and I think that any civilised people ought to be.

We really have to understand, too, that yesterday's enemies become today's friends, as we have seen so clearly demonstrated in this tragic situation in the Gulf. We should remember the adage that there is no such thing as a permanent ally, only permanent interests, and this is as true today as it ever was. A couple of examples from the recent conflict would include Jordan and Syria, while not so long ago Iraq was a good guy and a suitable market for weapons until Saddam Hussein blotted his copybook by invading Kuwait. When he invaded Iran in 1980, Britain and the United States actually blocked a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning Iraq's aggression against Iran. How is that for hypocrisy?

As for Iran, the West sold vast quantities of expensive and very sophisticated arms to the regime when the Shah was in charge but, after the revolution, Iran became a bad guy, and the United States then had to arm Iraq against Iran until the next change. This is how it goes on-the seesaw in geostrategic interests-largely, I would say, dependent on the arms sales opportunities.

What we have seen since the Gulf war is a $30 billion tally of arms sales. Some countries, paid by the United States to go in such as Syria and Egypt and other countries such as Israel are paid to stay out, and all being rewarded with massive arms sales in the follow-up to that war.

Even before the recent collapse of Soviet power, Pentagon and arms industry officials were hard at work searching for new enemies and devising new worst-case scenarios to justify preserving and extending the global reach of the United States military apparatus. Not surprisingly, all the new candidates to replace the Soviet Union in the role of public enemy No. 1 now reside in the Third World. An ensemble cast of terrorists, madmen, and drug traffickers has been pushed to the forefront as the rightful objects of public ire and the military resources formerly devoted to thwarting the Soviet threat. The elegant simplicity of focusing on one great super power enemy is being replaced by an emphasis on fighting a rotating coalition of Third World regimes and guerilla movements that are viewed as a threat to continued United States political and economic dominance of critical regions.

This has dangerously backfired on the United States in areas other than the Middle East. It was not so long ago that General Noriega of Panama was the bad guy of the year, having formerly been a recipient of CIA largess when he was a good guy. Before that it was Colonel Gaddafi of Libya. I was interested to see in the papers recently how the United States decided to resume aid to Kenya because the Kenyan Government has offered a refuge to a group of Libyans, formerly based in Chad where they were training to overthrow Colonel Gaddafi's regime. However, the government in Chad which had originally hosted them had been overthrown and replaced by a pro-Libyan government, so the unfortunate exiles had to go somewhere else-very expedient but having to fit in with United States' geostrategic plans. There is no evidence that the Government of Kenya has improved its human rights record, but President Moi had to be paid off somehow for hosting the unfortunate Libyan exiles, and hard luck on the Kenyan dissidents who continue to languish in detention, mere pawns in the international power play.

It is not only the United States that makes these mistakes with arms sales, of course.
