The Soviet Union's attitude is equally cynical, except that it does not get so heavily embroiled in Third World adventurism these days, I suppose largely because it cannot afford to with the Soviet empire collapsing or in danger of collapse. Even so, President Gorbachev was somewhat embarrassed over all the arms his Government had supplied to Iraq and he tried to make amends by passing on the details to the Americans, although this infuriated more conservative elements in the Red Army who had enjoyed Baghdad's hospitality since 1958. Britain, too, got a dose of the same treatment in the Falklands war when Argentina was using equipment supplied by British companies. Often the arms sold backfire literally to the selling countries.

French arms companies have suffered heavily as a result of the embargo on sales to Iraq as they had replaced the Russians as lead suppliers to Iraq by the late 1980s. As for the Brazilian arms export industry, it has virtually collapsed since the embargo on Iraq last August. Another Third World country which must be embarrassed is Egypt, which was also selling its wares to Iraq until the invasion last August.

In a multipolar world marked by shifting alliances and continuing instability within many Third World nations, the possibility that arms transfers will come back to haunt Western policy makers is likely to increase, particularly for the United States as the major supplier. This blind spot to the way in which lax United States arms transfer controls often end up expanding the arsenals of potential United States adversaries is even more dangerous in the realm of advanced military technologies such as fighter aircraft, ballistic missiles and nuclear and chemical weapons.

By promoting co-production and licence production arrangements that result because of the transfer of arms-making capacities to Third World states such as Egypt, South Korea, Taiwan and Pakistan, and by signing off plans to loosen restrictions on exports of high technology items that are critical to ballistic missile and nuclear weapons production, the Bush Administration is pursuing a path that can only make it easier for the so-called madmen like Colonel Gaddafi and Saddam Hussein to acquire advanced weaponry.

The Bush Administration's record on controlling sales of dual use technologies with applications in the development of nuclear weapons and long range ballistic missiles is only marginally better than its non-existent policy on export of arms making technology. A United States Government document released recently-on 11 March-showed that between 1985 and August 1991 the United States approved the export to Iraq of $1.96 billion worth of dual use items with military as well as civilian application, including powerful computers, precision machine tools and advanced electronics. An edited list of 771 export licences was released by the Commerce Department of the United States, according to this document, although it did not list the companies selling the items.

As Michael Maloof, Director of Technology Security Operations at the Pentagon's Department for Trade Security Policy, observed, the United States military in the Arabian Desert were facing their own technology sold to the Iraqis over the years by the Commerce Department. Germany has had the same trouble tracking what it sold to Iraq. The same excuse of commercial secrecy has been used here in Australia when I have tried to find out what military exports Australia has made in the last financial year. This shield of commercial secrecy has been used to block the information. This leads me to suggest possible measures that can be introduced at the international level to control arms transfers.

If the countries in the Gulf coalition had worked together during the Iran-Iraq war to forge an embargo on military supplies to both combatants, the current confrontation might never have come about and would certainly have posed far less danger of escalation. That is why I am so disappointed that the United States has started a new round of arms transfers in the Middle East, openly pushed by Defense Secretary Cheney and Secretary of State Baker. The United States and the Soviet Union still control close to two-thirds of the world's arms market, and their cooperation and leadership are essential to the inauguration of any workable system of multilateral arms transfer controls.

Former Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze stressed the need to curb the international arms trade in his September 1990 address to the United Nations General Assembly and in an earlier letter to the United Nations Secretary-General. The Soviets have agreed in principle to abide by the guidelines of the United States inspired missile technology control regime. Furthermore, unlike the United States, the Soviet Union already has an active program of converting military plants to civilian use, which should diminish institutional pressures to continue massive weapons exports. On the other hand, arms exports have become a critical source of hard currency for the battered Soviet economy. Like their US counterparts, moreover, many Soviet strategists see arms transfers and training as the easiest way to exert influence in the developing world.

Another danger is that both the United States and the Soviet Union might prefer to sell off equipment they have to get rid of as a result of conventional arms limitation agreements in Europe. The United States is already considering the sale of tanks to Egypt that would otherwise be destroyed. The Soviet Union is likely to fall to similar temptations with regard to all the hardware it must dispose of, as it has found it very difficult to date to convert its tanks and very expensive and time consuming to destroy them.

Along with the leadership of the United States and the Soviet Union, the support of the arms-supplying nations of Europe will be essential to any progress on the arms sales issue. European suppliers, with their smaller domestic procurement budgets, have always had a greater economic need to export in order to maintain an affordable modern armaments production base-the same argument used by this Government as well as the Opposition. Political motivations, such as France's efforts to curry favour with oil states like Iraq via military technology transfers, will have to be confronted as well.

The final piece of the multilateral arms control puzzle and perhaps the hardest to put in place is the participation of the emerging arms suppliers. Many countries, such as China, Israel, Brazil and South Korea, among others, see arms exports as a critical adjunct to high-tech industrialisation as well as a means of increasing their independence from more powerful countries. The political half of the equation can be addressed only through regional arms control agreements and assurances that the major industrial powers will pursue disarmament and forswear unilateral intervention in Third World conflicts in exchange for a slowdown in Third World arms production and sales.

These good faith efforts will undoubtedly have to be accompanied by political and economic pressure on regional powers such as China, whose role in arming the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, assisting Pakistan in its development of ballistic missiles and supplying both sides in the Iran-Iraq war indicates how much even a secondary arms supplier can damage the prospects for curbing the international trade in weaponry and, in turn, damage prospects for peace.

Daunting as the political challenges may be, the key to encouraging Third World powers to join in a multilateral arms transfer restraint arrangement may be economic. As long as arms deals are viewed as the road to access to high technology, moral appeals to curtail armaments programs in the developing world are likely to fall on deaf ears. As part of a revived dialogue on North-South trade, the United States and other industrial nations, including Australia, should offer concrete assistance to Third World countries for developing non-military industries and exports.

The United States and the Soviet Union should take a lead in developing a multilateral approach to implementing arms transfer controls. Once the former leaders of the two Cold War blocs have reached a consensus on basic principles, they should invite European and Third World suppliers to participate in multilateral negotiations.

Ideally, a United States-Soviet approach would build on existing mechanisms such as the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and the missile technology control regime, both of which need to be strengthened in coverage and enforcement and expanded in membership. As an example, as far as the Middle East is concerned, there is no way the world can get the Arab states to agree to such proposals until Israel signs the nonproliferation treaty, opens its nuclear facilities to inspection, and ends production and research on its ballistic missiles.

In addition, a United States-Soviet proposal should include several key provisions to guide multilateral arms transfer control discussions; a ban on exports to areas of active conflict; limits on the sale of arms production technology; a tightening of restrictions on sales of dual use technologies with applications to nuclear weapons and ballistic missile development; and regional limits on offensive conventional weapons such as heavy tanks and deep strike aircraft.

There has been some discussion about strengthening COCOM, otherwise known as the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls, which was created at the height of the Cold War and which caused some controversy in Australia in the early 1980s. According to a press report on 26 February, the United States is lobbying support for more stringent COCOM controls to prevent countries like Iraq and Libya from acquiring the means to build mass destruction weapons. But several European nations say there are already bodies whose charter is to attend to non-proliferation of nuclear weapons and arms controls, and they do not want to see the activities of COCOM extended.

Professor Michael Klare wrote an article for the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientist in January this year in which he outlined seven ways to curb arms transfers. To summarise the seven measures: firstly, reconvene the conventional arms transfer talks; secondly, expand and enhance the missile technology control regime; thirdly, establish controls on other advanced military systems; fourthly, convene an international conference on nuclear and chemical disarmament in the Middle East; fifthly, impose economic and trade sanctions against nations developing nuclear weapons; sixthly, reduce or restrict international aid to nations developing domestic arms industries; and, seventhly, establish an international clearing house for intelligence on clandestine arms technology transfers. The full details are on pages 24 to 26 of the journal, which is obtainable from the Parliamentary Library, through its Media Information, Current Awareness and Hansard section.

The point, then, is not for the United States and the Soviet Union to impose a solution on the rest of the world but to develop a common framework and negotiating position to facilitate multilateral discussions. These are ambitious proposals for curbing the international arms trade and they assume a high level of leadership on the part of the United States and the Soviet Union, which have been the world's most prolific and diversified arms trading nations throughout the Cold War era.

Ultimately, for the United States to play a constructive leadership role in limiting arms exports, there will need to be a domestic political consensus in favour of ending the United States role as a global policeman or global rent-a-cop, which has better characterised the nature of United States participation in the Gulf crisis-as I said, the cash box coalition-and it could be argued that the United States forces and the so-called alliance were the mercenaries doing the work that the Germans and Japanese were unable to do because of their constitutional limitations but which they have paid others to do on their behalf.

If the United States is to wean itself from its arms sales addiction, a new and truly defensive military strategy must replace the concepts of containment, forward development and the propensity for meddling in low intensity conflicts across the globe. The art of diplomacy and negotiation must be restored to its rightful place at the centre of United States foreign policy, with military action contemplated only as a last resort, which was hardly the case in the Gulf war.

In tandem with the new, more realistic defence strategy must come a new economic strategy that targets technological resources for growth industries without relying on military rationales to justify economically necessary investments.

These arguments apply to Australia. We can work at a regional level to limit arms transfers. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade should take precedence over the Department of Defence when it comes to regional security and conflict resolution. I guess I am not telling the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) anything new there, but I wish it were so that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade did take precedence over the Department of Defence-with the emphasis on peace making and peace keeping at a non-military level rather than on acquiring expensive and irrelevant high-tech military hardware that this country neither needs nor can afford. We need to promote economic conversion instead of trying to develop military technology and military exports, particularly when sales are directed at such an unstable part of the world as south and east Asia-a new growth area.

As Greg Sheridan's article in the Weekend Australian of 9 March headed `Disarming figures in our losing battle to export defence' pointed out, attempts to promote military exports have been a failure to date. `Thank goodness!' is all I can say about that. But maybe I will not be able to say that following the arms bazaar called AIDEX 91 in November in Canberra this year, which I believe should be the first item on the agenda of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for withdrawing Government support. There will be continued pressure on him to do that. If we are to act effectively to ensure that the new world order includes strict controls on the activities of the merchants of death, we have to get our own house in order first.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Privilege-Irish Australian of the Year-Death Penalty-Anzac Day Marches-Aborigines-Arms Race

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I am in a position to make any substantive reply to Senator Knowles's speech. I am sure the honourable member for Kennedy, Mr Hulls, will not feel so inhibited.

SPEECH.PARA: The speech made by Senator McKiernan was one that demonstrated amply his worthiness to be the recipient of the title of Irish Australian of the Year. On behalf of the Government and the Senate, I would formally like to congratulate him on that high honour. From the discursive nature of his comments tonight, it would seem he was putting in a bid for that trophy being a perpetual one in the future. But we do acknowledge the work that Senator McKiernan has done on behalf of the Irish community and in drawing attention to Irish issues over the years. We do think the award is one that is entirely justified.

The Government shares very strongly-even though Senator Kemp did not appear to-the views that Senator McKiernan expressed about capital punishment in the context of the Birmingham Six, making it perfectly clear, as that case does, just what an appalling risk societies take if they do keep capital punishment on the books in situations where manifest injustice and miscarriages of the legal process can occur.

Senator Lewis made the point about Anzac Day marches and Gulf war veterans being invited to lead those marches. I think that would constitute an appropriate recognition of the very substantial and credible role these Navy people played. I am sure that is a suggestion that will go to the appropriate quarters and be treated with the appropriate enthusiasm.
I am glad to learn that Senator Vanstone has been doing something constructive in South Australia and Port Augusta on behalf of Aboriginal people. The points she made were noted by the Senate.

Finally, from Senator Vallentine we had another tour de raison of advice for the Governor-General and me in particular about the conduct of various aspects of foreign defence policy. I must say that a number of the things in particular she said about the anxiety that does exist about a re-creation of the arms race in the Middle East in the immediate aftermath of the very unhappy demonstration of just what can follow from unrestricted arms sales are points that should strike a responsive chord around the world. They are points that Australia has been making in our own discussions.

It is important that there be an emphasis not just on the weapons of mass destruction but on conventional weapons control and, in particular, we are working-as she acknowledged-through the United Nations expert group to try to put into place international provisions for arms registers and things of that kind which will ensure some degree of transparency, and hopefully a reduction as a result in international arms sales. I have to say, however, that the most central line in her speech is one that one does have difficulty in accepting, that is, the absolutism of her attitude towards arms sales of any kind.

The truth of the matter, as we have said constantly-and I will not go on at length on this occasion-is that it is legitimate for countries to build up a defensive capability, a military capability, to secure their self-protection. Very few countries are likely to be in a position to do that from their own resources. They are going to have to buy arms as a result, and if it is legitimate for countries to buy arms in those circumstances it is manifestly legitimate for other countries to sell them. Some degree of international arms trade will always be entirely legitimate, and it is in that context that we should view things like the Australian International Defence Export Exhibition.

Australia's arms control policy, or policy in relation to defence exports, is not one of unlimited open slather. It is a policy that is built around existing guidelines which are being reviewed at the moment to ensure their continued sensitivity to some of the concerns which we all share in this place. With those reasonably brief remarks, Mr President, I think it is about time that we adjourned.
Senate adjourned at 11.31 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 15 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the disturbing video footage showing repression of the people of Tibet by the Chinese on the ABC report of Wednesday 1 August 1990, has the Government applied any sanctions against China for its treatment of the people of Tibet.

(2) In respect of the serious nature of the circumstances of the Tibetan people, can Australia seek sanctions against China through the United Nations because of the gross breach of human rights by the Chinese.
(3) What information does the Government have on the present state of the Tibetan people.
(4) Are Australians allowed into Tibet.
(5) Has the United Nations or any other peace-keeping force offered advice or assistance to the people of Tibet.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government has not applied sanctions against China in respect of human rights abuses specifically in Tibet. As called for in the Senate Resolution on Tibet, adopted on 6 December 1990, the Government will continue to make representations to, and seek responses from, the Chinese Government on the human rights situation in Tibet.

(2) The question of possible sanctions against China on the basis of its human rights record in Tibet has not been considered in any United Nations (UN) forum. There are a range of steps within the UN system short of sanctions which may be, and are, applied in relation to human rights violations. These include such moves as raising the issue in the UN Commission on Human Rights and establishing special investigative mechanisms. Resolutions on human rights violations are frequently employed within the Commission on Human Rights and the UN General Assembly. Australia supported an attempt by a number of Western countries to bring a resolution on human rights in China before the Commission on Human Rights in Geneva early in 1990. However, the move was unsuccessful due to adoption by CHR of a no action motion.

(3) The material available to the Government on Tibet includes that sourced from official Chinese publications, Tibetan exile and overseas Tibet support groups, Amnesty International and other non-government organisations. This material is supplemented by personal observations of individual travellers in Tibet.

It appears that the health and education services provided to the Tibetan people are now better than they have been for much of the time since the departure of the Dalai Lama in 1959 and especially during the period of the Cultural Revolution. At the same time, the Chinese authorities continue to stress the primacy of political stability and economic development in Tibet. This has led not only to large-scale deployment of troops and security forces in the Tibet Autonomous Region, but also to a significant and reportedly growing number of Han immigrants. While a number of temples and monasteries have been restored or are undergoing restoration, religious life in Tibet remains under close control. Moreover, international human rights organisations continue to report instances of alleged arbitrary arrests, detentions, torture and executions of Tibetans.
(4) Yes.
(5) The Government is not aware of any action by the United Nations or any peace-keeping force to provide advice or assistance to the people of Tibet.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the rationale for discriminating against taxpayers such as investors and others who may not strictly come within the term `people in business' as defined in a recent income tax ruling, IT 2582, that appears to restrict a taxpayer's ability to deduct interest on funds borrowed to pay income tax to `people in business'.
(2) Given the significance of the ruling, does the Government intend to incorporate this ruling into legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Taxation Ruling IT 2582 deals with the ``Deductibility of Interest Incurred on Moneys Borrowed to Pay Income Tax'' under subsection 51(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act (``the Act''). That provision contains two limbs, the first limb applies to persons who might be described as ordinary salary and wage earners or investors, the second limb deals with taxpayers carrying on a business. Although the two limbs of subsection 51(1) cover essentially the same ground there are situations in which the second limb may have a wider application. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal determined, in 1988 (Case V48), that taxpayers falling within the first limb of subsection 51(1) of the Act are not entitled to a deduction in respect of interest expenses incurred on money borrowed to pay their personal income tax liability. However, the Commissioner has accepted that other legal precedents apply so that taxpayers who carry on a business, such as companies, are entitled to a deduction in respect of interest on money borrowed to pay income tax. Taxation Ruling IT2582 simply reflects the application of this approach.

(2) Since the Ruling represents the Commissioners's interpretation of the present law based on existing legal authority, it is not intended to incorporate the Ruling into the law by way of statutory amendment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 6 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a report in the Canberra Times of 6 December 1990 that, on 4 or 5 October 1990, the Joint Scientific Committee (JSC) on Biological Conservation of the South East Forests was informed of an error in the computer program it used to construct a biotype map of the area, and that the error substantially influenced the published results.

(2) Will the Minister ensure that a full and adequate peer review of the JSC's report, including an assessment of the influence on its conclusions of this programming error, is conducted by independent scientists with expertise in conservation biology and ecology; if not, why not.
(3) Had the Minister been told of this computer error prior to receipt of this question; if so, when and by whom.

(4) Will the Minister review the reserve boundaries for the South East Forests of New South Wales in view of this error and in the light of the peer review mentioned in question 2 above; if not, why not.

(5) On 8 October 1990, the Prime Minister stated that the new reserves agreed by the Commonwealth and NSW Governments for the South East Forests had removed 11.5 per cent of the timber resource previously available to the timber industry. What were the amounts of: (a) newly reserved; and (b) total timber resource used in calculating this figure.
(6) Does the newly reserved timber resource figure referred to in question 5(a) represent the resource available in the first cutting cycle or in both cutting cycles.
(7) Does the total timber resource figure referred to in question 5(b) represent the resource available in the first cutting cycle or in both cutting cycles.
(8) What is the estimated time in which the first cut of the timber resource outside the new reserves will be completed.
(9) What is the estimated time in which the first cut of the timber resource in the South East Forests would have been completed if the new reserves were not declared.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the Canberra Times report which alleged there was an error in the computer program listed by Joint Scientific Committee (JSC).
(2) Professor Bryant Richards, Chairman of the JSC, advised the Department of Primary Industries and Energy on 7 December 1990 as follows:
``The so-called `bug' in the computer program would not have altered the Committee's conclusions and recommendations.

As indicated in section 3.2.3 of its report, the Committee was aware that in the initial simulations climate was weighted more heavily than the other environmental attributes (terrain and nutrient supply). The computer classification procedure groups areas of land having a similar array of environmental attributes. The actual number of groups (environmental domains) recognised is determined by the similarity or association criteria chosen by the user. This choice, while ecologically based, is essentially subjective and is determined by examining the output of successive computer runs using different association thresholds. The earlier runs did not discriminate sufficiently between areas of land known to differ in their nutrient supply rating. The classification finally chosen produced 127 environmental domains and captured the variation in nutrients supply known to exist.

It follows that the environmental domain analysis was not unduly skewed by climate factors, and hence can still be regarded as truly reflecting the environmental diversity of the study region. This is quite evident from examination of the tabular summary of key environmental attributes for each of the 127 environmental domains, given in Appendix 3.3 of the JSC report.
In view of Professor Richards advice I do not consider any further consideration of this matter is warranted.
(3) No; I became aware of this question and the Canberra Times report following my return to duty from overseas on 19 December 1990.

(4) No; I will not review the reserve boundaries for the South East Forests of New South Wales. As I outlined in my response to the second question, I am advised that the alleged error would not have altered the JSC's considerations and recommendations.

(5) The figure of 11.5 per cent of resource removed was calculated by the Forestry Commission of NSW using the Commission's resource data. I do not have a breakdown of this figure into (a) newly reserved; and (b) total timber resource.

(6) and (7) The removal of 11.5 per cent of the region's resource refers to the wood resource that was available to industry for harvesting prior to the reservation decision and therefore includes timber remaining from both cutting cycles.

(8) and (9) Prior to the reservation decision the first cutting cycle was scheduled to be completed around 1994 and the second cutting cycle was scheduled to be completed around 2014. The long-term strategy currently being formulated for the South East Forests will take into account resource losses due to the reservation decision and improved resource utilisation arising from the Commonwealth Government's industry development studies. I expect that industry activity will be adjusted in light of the long-term strategy to ensure that the cutting cycles will remain substantially as they were before the reservation decision.

(3) Grants prior to 1989/90

With the exception of Upurl Upurlila, 1988/89 and Oombulgurri, 1988/89, there are no outstanding matters in relation to acquittance of CDEP grants prior to 1989/90. The outstanding matters in relation to Upurl Upurlila are in the process of being resolved and acquittance will soon be finalised.

In the case of Oombulgurri, ATSIC grants identified in the audited financial statements do not match actual releases. The Regional Office has taken this matter up with the Community and Auditor and an early resolution is expected.
1989/90 Grants

In the Kununurra Region, audited financial statements are still outstanding for Kalumburu, Mandangala, Woolah, Muliarkar and Lamboo Gunian. Recruitment of additional resources are currently being undertaken to commence the acquittal process of these outstanding grants.
In the Derby/Broome Region, all 1989/90 annual audited financial statements have been examined and, where possible, grants have been acquitted.
Where grants cannot be acquitted at this stage, appropriate action has been undertaken as detailed below:
(a) Queries highlighted in Annual Audited Financial Statements have been raised in correspondence to relevant communities; and
(b) Copies of correspondence where queries have been raised have also been sent to relevant Auditors.
Upon receipt of satisfactory responses, relevant grants can be acquitted.
In this Region, audit reports for 1989/90 have not yet been received from Pender and Mowanjum. The auditor and community Chairperson have been advised of this breach of funding conditions.
In the South Hedland Region, audit reports have been received in the Regional Office but have not yet been analysed.
(4) ATSIC is not aware of an official review expressing reservations or inadequacies with regard to cash payments by any of the Western Australian CDEP communities.
(5) Qualified audit reports have been received for 17 (one third) of the 52 CDEP communities in Western Australia. The communities concerned are:

Djarindjin; Bardi; Lombadina; Junjuwa; Yungngora; Junjuwa (Muludja and Ngalingkadji); Wangkatjungka; Kadjina; Looma; Mulan; Beagle Bay; Punmu; Strelley; Burringurrah; Ngangganawili; and Upurl Upurlila.

The audits reveal a number of shortcomings common to these communities, primarily in the areas of bookkeeping, cash systems and management, records maintenance, and accounting systems and procedures. Problems of this nature are not uncommon in remote communities where experienced staff, qualified accountants and training facilities are all scarce resources.

The Commission has taken steps to rectify inadequacies in all the instances identified by the audit reports. Action undertaken includes implementation of financial management training programs for staff and councillors of several communities; the installation of new financial management, internal control and wages systems in a number of communities; and assistance given to communities in the appointment of bookkeeping or management staff.

(6) An evaluation of Grant Acquittals for all Programs is currently being conducted by the Office of Evaluation and Audit on a national basis. The Office will be involved in an evaluation of CDEP this calendar year.

(7) It was discovered that at Yungngora Community one of the staff members was falsifying names on CDEP wages payments. An amount of between $5,000 and $6,000 was allegedly re-directed to her personal account. The matter was referred to police authorities.

The projects officer at Upurl Upurlila, investigated in connection with payments for items of personal benefit, was charged by the Kalgoorlie Criminal Investigation Bureau, convicted and ordered to undertake 180 hours of community service and to pay restitution of approximately $600.
(8) COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT PLANS

The Commission acknowledges the importance of community development plans. Work has commenced on developing a program. Both the Commission and the Department of Employment, Education and Training are examining options for providing assistance to communities in the preparation of community development plans.

Under new administrative arrangements for CDEP, communities will have to provide a CDEP works program when making applications for CDEP grant funds. The works program will comprise a list of projects that the community sees as important to its social, cultural, recreational and economic development.
Communities are being encouraged to develop specific CDEP plans and/or community development plans. The CDEP works program would be an integral part of either of these plans.
ASSESSMENT CRITERIA
All CDEP grants are assessed by the Commission on the annual ``Grant Assessment Form'' which is completed by Regional Officers as part of the annual draft estimates documentation.

In addition to the annual grant assessment all CDEP projects are to be fully reviewed on a three year cycle commencing in 1991/92. It is envisaged that these reviews will be undertaken by officers from the Commission and the Departments of Employment, Education and Training and Social Security.
PRIORITY SETTING

Under new administrative arrangements, priorities for the allocation of CDEP Oncost and Support funds will be determined by Regional Managers in consultation with Regional Councils and CDEP communities and organisations.
INACCURATE PAYMENTS

It is acknowledged that some communities have not always submitted fortnightly variation schedules. However, while this can cause short term inaccuracies, community entitlements are adjusted when subsequent schedules are received.
While delays occur between the Commission and DSS this does not result in over or under payments by ATSIC, as any adjustments necessary (after DSS checking) are made in subsequent quarters.
The lack of sanctions under the standard grant offer have been corrected by additional mandatory special conditions for CDEP.

The administrative changes to the CDEP system to take effect from 1 April 1991 have been designed to simplify the calculation of communities' entitlements and should reduce the possibility of inaccuracies.
MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTING
TRAINING

The lack of qualified Aboriginal people has been a problem for DAA/ATSIC and communities alike. Training initiatives have been taken by DAA/ATSIC and the Department of Employment, Education and Training to address this issue.

As a part of new administrative arrangements for CDEP, a Training Needs Schedule and a training program to meet these needs for each CDEP is required. Under the Department of Employment, Education and Training (Training for Aboriginals Program) funding is available for communities to engage a consultant, where appropriate, to prepare training needs analyses and/or training schedules for project participants.
ENTITLEMENTS, ALLOWANCES AND
AWARD PAYMENTS

Since the ANAO audits of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory were conducted there has been a significant improvement in the take up rate of the Family Allowance Supplement by CDEP participants. The Department of Social Security is promoting this allowance through its Aboriginal Liaison Officers and Community Agents.
While ATSIC encourages the payment of wages at award rates, the setting of hours worked is left to the discretion of community councils and organisations.

Award coverage for CDEP communities is a complex issue as the nature of the work generally is only part-time. The Commission is currently in the process of contracting a consultant to undertake research into industrial relations issues associated with CDEPs including the question of award coverage.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Timor Gap Treaty: Security Liaison Officer

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 14 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it the case that Indonesia has appointed a security liaison officer to be based in Darwin as part of the arrangements under the Timor Gap Treaty; if so, on what date is it expected that this officer will take up the position.
(2) Will the Australian Government also be appointing a liaison officer to be stationed in Indonesia; if so when is this likely to take place.
(3) What are the duties of such a position expected to be.

(4) Are recent media reports which suggest that the Indonesian liaison officer, to be based in Darwin, will be appointed to monitor security in the area governed by the Timor Gap Treaty true; if so, how is it expected that such a position will require the monitoring of security and under what circumstances is this likely to take place.
(5) Has the Australian Government received any representations from the Government of the Northern Territory regarding the stationing of the Indonesian security liaison officer in Darwin.

(6) Has the Australian Government received any representations from any other nations, including those in the Asia Pacific region, regarding the stationing of the Indonesian security liaison officer in Darwin.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under arrangements agreed at the inaugural meeting of the Ministerial Council, established by the Timor Gap Zone of Cooperation Treaty, two officers with the dual responsibilities of technical officer and security liaison officer are to be appointed to the Technical Directorate of the Joint Authority established under the Timor Gap Zone of Cooperation Treaty. The Technical Directorate is to be located in Darwin. Under the terms of the Treaty the Executive Directors of the Joint Authority are responsible for the selection and appointment of the Joint Authority's staff from amongst individuals nominated by both Indonesia and Australia. With respect to the two positions of Technical Officer, with security liaison functions, it has been agreed by the Ministerial Council that one will be nominated by Australia and the other by Indonesia. At this stage Indonesia has not made a nomination to the Executive Directors of the Joint Authority. I am therefore unable to say when the individual to be appointed by the Executive Directors following Indonesia's nomination will take up his or her place.

(2) The Australian Government has made a nomination for appointment as Technical Officer with security liaison functions and the Executive Directors have signed a contract for the Australian Technical Officer to commence work on 11 March 1991. However, under the arrangements currently agreed by the Ministerial Council security liaison functions will not be required until closer to the time at which exploitation commences, that is, between 6 to 12 months after entry into force of the Treaty. Accordingly, the Australian Technical Officer will not be performing these functions at this stage. The Australian Technical Officer with security liaison functions will be located in Darwin not Indonesia.

(3) Under the Treaty the Joint Authority is responsible for controlling movements into, within and out of Area A, the joint area, of the Timor Gap Zone of Cooperation of vessels, aircraft, structures, and other equipment employed in exploration for and exploitation of petroleum resources and for requesting action by appropriate Australian and Indonesian authorities for search and rescue operations and in the event of terrorist threat to the vessels and structures engaged in petroleum operations in Area A. Under the Treaty the two countries have the right to carry out surveillance in Area A of the Zone of Cooperation and are obliged to exchange information on surveillance and on likely threats or security incidents relating to petroleum exploitation in that Area. The Ministerial Council has agreed that the two countries will keep the Joint Authority appropriately informed of such matters. The Ministerial Council has therefore agreed that the two Technical Officers with security liaison functions will be responsible for liaising with the appropriate Australian and Indonesian authorities and will be the point of contact within the Joint Authority on all security matters and incidents for both the contract operators and national response organisations. These Officers will also be responsible for ensuring that contract operators establish appropriate and consistent procedures for responding initially to security incidents on structures engaged in petroleum operations in Area A.

(4) The two Technical Officers with security liaison functions will only be responsible for security liaison in Area A of the Zone of Cooperation, the area in which there is joint control by the two countries of the exploration and exploitation of petroleum resources. They will not have any role with respect to Areas B or C which are under the exploration and exploitation regimes of Australia and Indonesia respectively. Neither will they have any role in respect of activities other than those relating to petroleum development. The monitoring of security matters will be handled as set out above in answer to question 3.
(5) No
(6) No

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 15 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With the prospect of sanctions against South Africa being dropped, what measures has the Government taken to guard against competition on the export market of primary products and minerals from South Africa.
(2) What is the estimate of the amount of export trade we could be competing with South Africa to sell.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) While the past 12 months have seen a period of rapid change in South Africa, with President de Klerk commiting his country to a democratic and non-racial future, we have not yet seen the complete dismantling of apartheid. At the London ``special session'' of the Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa (CFMSA), agreement was reached on a Commonwealth response to developments in South Africa. The communique, issued at the conclusion of that meeting, represents an important advance on previous CFMSA positions in that it maps out a plan for the phased lifting of sanctions. The communique states that the most important forms of pressure are trade, investment and financial sanctions which ``should not be modified until some further major step has been taken down the path of constitutional reform. This could take the form of the establishment of an interim government, the establishment of a constituent assembly or some other agreed constitution-making process marking the commencement of final negotiations, or any other form agreed by the multi-party conference.'' (para. 10 (b)).

For a number of products we could face increased competition from South African products in third markets as sanctions are lifted. In these circumstances, the Government's advice to Australian exporters will be to maintain and improve their competitiveness and to continue to work hard to develop new markets for their products. The Australian Government will continue to monitor South African Government trade and industry policies in areas of interest to us to ensure they are consistent with South Africa's international obligations.

It is not appropriate for the Australian Government to ``guard against competition on the export market'' from any country provided the competition is fair and the trade is conducted on a non-discriminatory basis. Rather it is in our interests to develop fairer and more open international markets for primary products and minerals. This is an important objective of our efforts in the GATT Uruguay Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations.

(2) It is not possible to estimate with any precision the amount of export trade we could be competing with South Africa to sell. However, in general terms it is clear that a global lifting of sanctions will have an impact on Australia's share of international markets. With a devalued currency, low wages and a lean, self-sufficient economy, South Africa is well positioned to challenge in world markets for commodities produced by Australia, such as coal, wine and fruit. The small but active South African wool industry is not likely to have any impact on Australian trade; nor will wheat exports be affected as South Africa is at present an importer of wheat.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 15 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Antarctic Division approach Mr Ewald Brune, in the belief that he was Ice Pilot on the recent Pakistani expedition, to provide reports to the Antarctic Division on the progress of the Pakistani expedition; if so, who made that approach to Mr Brune.
(2) If such an approach was made, was it made with the knowledge of the Minister.
(3) If such an approach was made, was it made with the prior knowledge of the Pakistani Expedition Leader or Pakistani Antarctic authorities.
(4) Was Mr Brune the Ice Pilot on the Pakistani expedition.

(5) Did Mr Brune agree to keep Australian Antarctic Division officers informed of the progress of the Pakistani expedition; if so, what reports did he provide, who did he provide them to, and if Antarctic Division officers plan to debrief Mr Brune on his return from the Pakistani expedition, who will conduct that debriefing.
(6) Has or will Mr Brune receive any financial or other benefit from the Antarctic Division for any reports he may have provided or may provide on the progress of the Pakistani expedition.
(7) What was Mr Brune's past association with Antarctic Division.
(8) What was the intended use of the information provided by Mr Brune.

(9) Would Pakistan have been encouraged to become a party to the Antarctic Treaty, to support Australia's proposal for an Antarctic World Park or otherwise cooperate in the protection of Antarctica by the apparent covert surveillance of their Antarctic expedition by the Australian Antarctic Division.
(10) Does Australia monitor the progress and activities of other nations' Antarctic expeditions or Antarctic tourist cruises; if so, how.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the

ANSWER.PARA: following answer to the honourable senator's question:
(2) and (3) See the answer to 1 above.
(4) Captain Brune has stated that he had taken a contract with the Pakistani expedition as their consultant ice pilot.

(5) There is no agreement between Captain Brune and the Antarctic Division. Captain Brune volunteered to keep the Antarctic Division informed on the progress of the Pakistani expedition. The Division has received advice on the location of the Pakistani base and contact details for the ship used by the expedition. This information is public. There is no plan to debrief Captain Brune on his return to Australia, but appropriate officers of the Antarctic Division would welcome the opportunity to talk to him on his return.
(7) Captain Brune was Master of the MV Icebird while it was on charter to the Antarctic Division from 1984-85 through to 1989-90.
(8) The Australian Antarctic Division is not actively seeking information from Captain Brune but has an interest in any information on the operations of others in the Antarctic.

(9) There was no covert surveillance of the Pakistani expedition by the Australian Antarctic Division. Australia and other Antarctic Treaty nations have encouraged Pakistan to accede to the Antarctic Treaty, and Australia has made frequent approaches to Pakistani authorities elaborating the benefits that participation in the Antarctic Treaty System can bring.

(10) Yes. Antarctic Treaty parties exchange information about their antarctic activities in accordance with Article VII of the Treaty. There is also other official and informal contact between Treaty parties, including exchange of scientists and scientific data and inspections of other nations' activities undertaken under Article VII of the Antarctic Treaty. Information is also exchanged on tourist and non-government activities in the Antarctic.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Defence Force Families and Information Liaison Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 19 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What specific initiatives has the Australian Defence Force Families Information and Liaison Staff (ADFILS) made regarding spouse employment.
(2) Has ADFILS looked at the UK or USA systems as examples of Defence Force spouse employment that could be utilised locally; if so, what are the findings and the potential and if not, why not.
(3) What are the measures that have been established with Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Commonwealth Employment service to sensitise them to the needs of service spouses.
(4) How effective are the measures and what evidence is there of that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) ADFILS has been involved in a variety of initiatives in spouse employment. These initiatives have taken due cognisance that they must reflect the needs expressed by Defence spouses; that spouse employment issues and needs vary from locality to locality; that maximum use should be made of organisations, services and structures already existing in the community and that the realities of the Australian industrial and employment scene must be recognised. Spouse employment initiatives can be grouped into three areas as follows:
(a) Provision of employment information to spouses:

(i) During 1990, a range of Spouse Information Days has been conducted in each State at major Service locations, providing spouses with information on the present local employment situation, the services and programs offered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Commonwealth Employment Service, and the potential to revise or enhance employable skills through the variety of programs such as offered by the TAFE system.

(ii) ADFILS has sponsored advertisements and advice in local service family newsheets and local newspapers on spouse employment needs, information/training days and courses which may be appropriate for Defence spouses. ADFILS also assists in providing information on the community, including employment matters, in welcoming packages for families arriving in their new locations.
(iii) ADFILS assists in the provision of guest speakers on employment matters for a variety of spouses meetings.

(iv) On its FIND 008 service, ADFILS maintains a register of 96 addresses of State registration bodies covering 20 professional/semi professional groups to assist spouses seeking registration as they move from State to State.
(b) Assistance in Developing or Renewing Employment Skills.

(i) ADFILS in conjunction with the Department of Employment Education and Training (DEET) and the TAFE networks have assisted spouses to participate in the Skillshare Program, Return to the Workforce Courses; other courses run by various TAFEs, Outreach programs and some special courses conducted by DEET/CES tailored to meet local requirements.

(ii) Emphasis is also placed on self-help. With ADFILS advice and assistance, spouses groups have been successful in receiving grants from State and other agencies to conduct spouse employment activities. As an example, a spouses group in Western Australia has recently received a grant of $18,900 under the National Agenda for Women Grants Program to conduct a series of spouse employment workshops.

(iii) As well as the more formal approach, spouses are involved in the wide variety of family support activities conducted by Defence families. This involvement also provides spouses with the opportunity to improve their skills and confidence, thus enhancing their job-seeking skills. Key volunteers in family support activities often move into the paid workforce.
(c) Liaison with Other Agencies on Defence Spouses Needs. See (3) below.
(2) ADFILS continues to monitor developments in family support in the UK and USA systems as well as those of the Canadian and NZ Defence Forces. The main spouse employment issues in all systems are:
(a) the need to improve the confidence and the skills of spouses who wish to enter or re-enter the work force; and

(b) the need to improve the availability of, and access to, employment of choice. Developments in family support programs overseas do not always translate readily to the Australian situation because of different needs, different social and cultural circumstances and differences in the size of the Defence population and hence the scope and availability of resources.

The steps being taken to assist Australian Defence spouses to develop self-confidence and to gain, improve or update job-seeking and employment skills reflect the emphasis given in overseas programs. Although the emphasis in all programs is still on the acquisition of personal skills, some overseas programs also use a spouse employment register-job agency approach. This has not been adopted in Australia, but spouses in a number of locations, with assistance from FLOs and ADFILS, have taken informal steps to register skills and to attempt to match these to advertised vacancies. Normally speaking, however, the comprehensive employment and developmental services offered by DEET and the CES in all localities already provide a sufficient service for Defence spouses. Spouse employment issues tend to be local rather than national in nature. Establishment and maintenance of a national job register by Defence is not appropriate.

It is understood that, in some instances, the US program accords Defence spouses some priority of employment in the Defence organisation. Given the size and nature of the Australian Defence Department and the practicalities of the Australian industrial and employment scene, this approach is not regarded as practical.

(3) Close liaison has been established between ADFILS and DEET and the CES at the State/Regional and local levels. ADFILS staff are in regular contact with DEET officers. While levels and frequency of contact vary from area to area, cooperation is rated as excellent. ADFILS staff have briefed DEET/CES managers and staff on the employment needs of both Defence spouses and dependents. In particular, ADFILS staff have been invited to brief DEET Women's Contact Officers and counter staff on the special needs of Defence spouses. DEET staff are closely involved in the dissemination of information and in the provision, design and conduct of training and assistance for spouses mentioned at (1) above. DEET also provide advice and suggestions on spouse employment issues and have, in some locations, developed special packages or courses to meet Defence spouses needs. The ADFILS Queensland Coordinator has appeared on the DEET sponsored program ``Jobspot'' on Brisbane Channel 7 to discuss employment issues.

(4) The difficulty in assessing the effectiveness of the spouse employment program is selecting the assessment criteria. The employment needs of spouses are individual and diverse. Employment opportunities are dependent on national and local influences. Success in obtaining employment involves many intangibles. Given that the primary goal of the programs is for spouses to gain or develop job-seeking and employment skills, the best criteria for assessment is not numerical but the degree of the satisfaction of the participants with the scope and relevance of the various programs. Feedback to ADFILS and DEET staff across the range of activities indicates that participants are generally satisfied. Varying with the location and the need, there is a continuing and increasing demand for the range of programs presently provided. Information gathered as part of the Defence Family Census in March 1991 will also help to determine the extent of spouse employment needs and indicate areas where more detailed surveys should be conducted. This will aid in the design and provision of further appropriate programs to assist Defence spouses.

The impact of Government financial allocations and other pressures, including manpower and operating costs is being addressed, as is an examination of the balance between Regular and Reserve forces. Reserves are therefore presently being addressed in the overall context of the total Defence Force. The Force Structure Review is still in progress and is expected to be complete by mid year.

(3) The use of financial inducements as attraction and retention measures is under consideration as part of an examination of the total package of conditions applying to the Regular and Reserve Forces. No decision has yet been made in relation to particular inducements additional to the conditions already applying. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is HMAS Derwent being refitted at the Fremantle Dockyard.
(2) Have several panels in the hull of the ship been replaced.
(3) Has any re-examination been made of the other five ships of the River Class to see if they have similar problems; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) HMAS Derwent is presently being refitted at the West Australian Marine Support Facility of Australian Shipbuilding Industries Pty Ltd on Cockburn Sound.
(2) Several panels in the hull of the vessel have been replaced.

(3) There are presently only four ships of the River Class in commission with the Royal Australian Navy. HMAS Yarra decommissioned in 1985, HMAS Parramatta decommissioned on 11 January 1991 and HMAS Stuart will decommission on 26 July 1991. This will leave HMAS Derwent as the only serving ship of the original Royal Navy Type 12 or River Class frigates built in Australia between 1959 and 1965. Two further ships of a significantly enhanced design, HMAS Swan and HMAS Torrens, commissioned in 1970 and 1971 respectively, continue to serve. The replacement of wasted hull shell plating on ships in refit (particularly a ship 25 years old) is a routine procedure which ensures the future serviceability of the ship. In the case of HMAS Derwent, a thorough survey of the hull structure was conducted using modern ultrasound techniques which enabled the shipyard staff to pinpoint exactly which plates should be replaced. This process was further expedited by experience gained during the intermediate docking of HMAS Stuart last year whereby areas of weakness in HMAS Stuart's hull plating enabled HMAS Derwent's survey to be more accurately specified.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 21 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the 1990 Budget, in which the Government announced the introduction of new social security rules for bringing to account income from cash and money in banks, building societies and credit unions, what was the reason for including a question requiring details of stocks and shares in the investment review form.
(2) Does the Government intend, at some later stage, to `deem' a specific interest rate on such items.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Social Security pensioners are subject to income and assets tests. In order to apply these tests, Social Security asks clients about shares when they claim a pension and as part of its periodic Income Review Program.
An Investment Review Form was sent to pensioners likely to be affected by deeming on accounts and cash.

The form asks questions on the full range of financial investments including shares because I have been urging pensioners to reinvest money which they have in cash or in cheque accounts to earn extra income so that they can be better off. While most pensioners will prefer conventional accounts with banks and other financial institutions, some pensioners will have chosen to use other kinds of investments including shares. The questions asked ensure that all this extra income is taken into account.

Asking about all financial investments also allows Social Security to treat the Investment Review form as a periodic Income Review, so that pensioners will not have to answer the same questions again in the near future.
(2) The Government has no plans to deem an interest rate on shares.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 21 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the agenda been determined for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) to be held later in 1991.
(2) Will discussion of the Cyprus issue take place at CHOGM.
(3) What action will the Australian Government take at the 1991 CHOGM to effectively implement previous CHOGM resolutions concerning the Cyprus issue.

(4) Has the Australian Government responded to recent calls from the Governments of both Cyprus and Greece for economic and trade sanctions to be applied against Turkey until the Turkish Government complies with United Nations Security Council Resolutions 353 and 550.
(5) Does the Australian Government support this call for United Nations sponsored economic and trade sanctions against Turkey; if not, why not.

(6) As the Australian Government has previously stated a desire for the implementation of the full text of United Nations Security Council Resolutions 353 and 550, will the Government take the initiative at CHOGM and at the United Nations General Assembly to urge for international and comprehensive economic sanctions against Turkey.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No agenda has yet been circulated for the 1991 CHOGM.

(2) The Communique issued at the end of the 1989 CHOGM in Kuala Lumpur included a reference to the question of Cyprus and reiterated the need for a quick solution. Given the continuation of problems in Cyprus, there may be discussion of the Cyprus question at the Harare CHOGM.

(3) Australia will continue to support UN Security Council resolutions and the Commonwealth approach to a resolution of the problems in Cyprus. The Australian Government believes that negotiation and dialogue between the two communities are essential if a lasting solution is to be found for the Cyprus problem, and that that process of dialogue is most effectively conducted through the UN Secretary General.

(4) &(5) The Australian Government is not aware of recent calls from the Cypriot and Greek Governments for economic and trade sanctions to be applied against Turkey. The imposition of economic and trade sanctions against Turkey would create great difficulties for the UN Secretary General's efforts to resolve the dispute through negotiations between the two communities, efforts which have the full and active support of Australia. Australia's position is consistent with the attempts of others including the US and the European Community to resolve the Cyprus issue. The recently announced EC initiative on Cyprus which is expected to involve greater EC Presidency contact with the interested parties is not intended to supplant or detract from the efforts of the UN Secretary General.
(6) The Australian Government would not urge international and comprehensive economic sanctions against Turkey at this time, for the reasons outlined in (4) and (5) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 21 February 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) During the opening of the arts exhibition `Sisters of the Moon-Kakadu', on 7 August 1990, did the Minister state that there was a greater need for the Federal Government to encourage the promotion of those Australian artists and authors whose works primarily promote environmental considerations.
(2) What action has the Minister initiated to fulfil any such commitment.

(3) Will the department provide additional funding to the Australia Council for the specific purpose of establishing a special Creative Artist Fellowship to be awarded annually to those artists whose works promote environmental considerations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories promotes community interest and understanding of environmental issues, including in the arts community, by its support for World Environment Day (WED) held annually on 5 June. Each year the Department coordinates an information kit on a WED theme for distribution to schools, community and conservation groups throughout Australia, and encourages other organisations to undertake appropriate activities to highlight the issue.

This year community arts organisations, Contemporary Arts Spaces and Craft Councils have been approached to undertake exhibitions, and to promote the concept of `No Excuse Let's Reduce'. To encourage this involvement, the Department has offered assistance in the form of advice, limited funding and the promotion of exhibitions throughout Australia as part of WED's general promotional activities.

The Department also administers a Greenhouse Information Grants Scheme to support community groups in undertaking projects which raise community awareness of greenhouse issues, promote action to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases and contribute to the development of adaptation strategies. The guidelines of the Scheme allow for the promotion of these issues through education and the arts.

In late 1989 the Australia Council established the Community, Environment, Art and Design (CEAD) program to encourage communities to actively intervene to improve their environment by working in cooperation with artists, architects, designers, planners or landscape architects, in partnership with local and state government authorities and sympathetic developers. Since the inception of the CEAD, the urban design projects funded by the Council have shown a much stronger emphasis on addressing major national and global environmental issues.

In conjunction with the Australian Institute of Landscape Architects, Tasmania, and the British Council, the Australia Council is currently sponsoring a tour of Australia by Ms Sue Clifford, lecturer in rural and natural resources planning and co-founder of the unique British environmental body `Common Ground'. This organisation assists in linking artists and environmentalists in a similar way to that of the Council's CEAD program.

The other Boards and Committees of the Australia Council fund projects as a result of applications which reflect artists' areas of special interest. Many of these include projects pertaining to environmental issues.

(3) At this stage it is not proposed to provide additional funding to establish a special Australian Artists Creative Fellowship for artists who focus particularly on environmental issues. The guidelines for the Scheme allow for the possibility of awarding Fellowships to such artists. All requests for funding, including Creative Fellowships, are dealt with by the Australia Council on the basis of each application's individual merits in competition with others received.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 22 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why was there a significant cut in paid training days for the Army Reserve in January 1991.
(2) What savings are expected to be made by this reduction in paid days.
(3) Why have a number of Army Reservists been told that they cannot be paid for a two-week training camp until the new financial year.
(4) Does compensation cover still apply to Army Reservists who parade but who are not being paid; if not, why not.
(5) Is attendance allowance, for those who travel long distances to attend training, being paid to Army Reservists who are not currently being paid for attending training, if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There was no significant cut in paid training days for the Army Reserve in January 1991 or indeed for any period in the current financial year. In 1990 Army Office advised the provisional allocation of Army Reserve Training Days for Financial Year 90/91 to be 1,040,000 days. This allocation was confirmed, unchanged, in July 1990. On current usage of training days it is expected that the full allocation will be utilised in this Financial Year.
(2) As there was no reduction in paid training days no monetary savings resulted.

(3) Members of the Sydney University Regiment were requested by their Commanding Officer to undergo voluntary unpaid training for part of their Annual Field Training in January 1991. I am happy to say that Sydney University Regiment has recently advised that all its members were paid for the full period of training. Sydney University Regiment had been allocated sufficient days to meet essential training. This allocation did not allow the Commanding Officer to conduct all the training he wished and therefore he chose to request members of his unit to forego pay. It is worth noting that the Commanding Officer of the University of New South Wales Regiment faced with a similar situation chose to cancel his Annual Field Training. Training Day allocation is based on unit strengths and the training obligation of its members. In most cases this amounts to between 35 and 40 days per member. This allocation is adjusted for units with greater commitments, for example, recruiting units. While allocations may not meet all units initial requests they are sufficient for essential training and, in the majority of cases, for additional training also to be conducted. Army policy is actively to discourage unpaid training, except when related to charitable or community support activities.

(4) Army Reservists undergoing unpaid training have the same compensation protection as if the training were paid. In December 1990 instructions were issued to units advising the administrative action necessary to ensure this compensation protection.

(5) Attendance Allowance is not paid to Army Reservists undergoing training. The allowance is paid to assist a member with travel expenses when required to attend a specified place of duty. In the case of unpaid training the attendance by the member is voluntary and therefore the allowance is not payable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 22 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current status of the review of the living-in policy for Defence Force members which was endorsed in August 1989.
(2) What are the details for implementation.
(3) When will the removal anomaly that exists between members without families and members with families be remedied.
(4) What is the progress of the implementation of back-to-back postings as announced by the Chief of Defence Force.
(5) How many back-to-back postings occurred in the December 1990 to January 1991 posting period.
(6) How many back-to-back postings are planned for the December 1991 to January 1992 posting period.
(7) What is the average saving to Defence of a back-to-back posting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The review is continuing and is well advanced in terms of identifying the conceptual issues involved. It is not possible, however, to predict when the review might be completed, nor, indeed, the final outcome.
(2) The implementation details of this review remain to be fully developed and agreed, not only within Defence but also by the Department of Industrial Relations.
(3) Removal entitlements are being reviewed as part of the overall policy review of conditions or service for members without family.

(4) The Services make every endeavour to meet the CDF directive on back-to-back postings. However, factors which militate against 100% compliance include the operational requirements of the Service, the career progression and development postings needed for members and members' personal preferences. Specific Service constraints also include the imbalance of sea to shore billets in certain localities in Navy and the Army's need to maintain continuity in Priority One units and Headquarters.

Additional initiatives include a locational stability scheme for officers, introduced by Air Force on 20 April 1990, which provides up to 98 positions in the Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra areas for officers of selected categories for periods of up to nine years.
(5) Posting records indicate 3,790 back-to-back postings occurred in the December 1990 to January 1991 posting period.

(6) Planning for the majority of posting plots for this period has not yet commenced. However, postings will only be issued as needed and as many as are feasible within the constraints outlined will be back-to-back.
(7) The average saving to Defence of a back-to-back posting is estimated to be about $5,200.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Surface Combatants: Damage Control and Fire Retardant Systems

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What damage control and fire retardant systems are employed in our major surface combatants to minimise the fire danger associated with missile and other forms of attack.
(2) Were these systems modified in any way as a result of the experience of British vessels in the Falklands war of 1982.
(3) Have any steps been taken to reduce the fire risk associated with building surface combatant superstructures with aluminium.
(4) Will the superstructures of the ANZAC frigates be built with aluminium; if so, what measures will be taken to minimise risk associated with fire damage from missile or other attack.
(5) Will the damage control and fire retardant systems of the ANZAC vessels differ in any significant way from the systems in our current surface combatants; if so, how.
(6) Are there any plans to enhance damage control and fire retardant capabilities in our DDGs and FFGs as these vessels are modernised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Our major surface combatants comprise 3 DDGs and 4 FFGs designed and built in the USA. Damage control arrangements, equipments and procedures, and related fire retardant systems derive from the USN's extensive operational experience and include:
* Multiple sea water fire main pumps and alternative pipe runs.
* Alternative and emergency power supplies to fire main pumps and other essential damage control systems.
* Fixed and portable fire fighting and flood control systems throughout the ship.
* Watertight and smoke-tight sub-divisions throughout the ship.
(2) Damage control improvements made to our DDGs and FFGs as a result of the experience of British vessels in the Falklands conflict of 1982 include:
* Improved damage control procedures and training.
* Improved self-contained breathing apparatus for fire fighting and personnel escape.
* Improved access and quick-action hatch and door mechanisms.
* Replacement of toxic/combustible materials and cables.
* Improved fire extinguishing agents.
* Ballistic protection of superstructures in way of critical spaces.
* Special cameras for seeing in smoke, special metal cutting tools and increase of water removal equipment.

(3) The RAN continues to make damage control improvements as a result of our own and other navies' experience such as the USN STARK and ROBERTS action damage during the IRAN-IRAQ Gulf conflict. Our DDGs and FFGs are provided with thermal insulation, intumescent paints (which swell when heated and decompose to form a charred layer between the fire and the structure they are painted on), and water cooling procedures as a means of extending the time available to effect damage control and personnel safety actions before structural failure from intense fire.
(4) Our ANZAC frigates will have steel superstructures.

(5) The more modern ANZAC frigate design has allowed the adoption of significant advances in damage control philosophy not practicable to retrofit in our existing DDGs and FFGs. The most significant difference is the sub-division of the ANZAC frigate into nine autonomous damage control and fire containment zones.
(6) The improvements described at (2) and (3) above are being progressively implemented and continually reviewed.
