QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 6 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What plans are currently in place for Interpol to open an office in Australia.
(2) In what activities would such an office be involved.
(3) What capacities does Interpol have which are not exercised by the Australian Federal Police (AFP).
(4) To what extent are the activities of Interpol likely to impede or encroach upon the work already done by the AFP.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia has been a member of the International Criminal Police Organization, commonly known as Interpol, since 1948. Interpol is an international organisation made up of 154 member countries. Its headquarters is at Lyon in France and each member country has an established link with Interpol Headquarters known as a National Central Bureau (NCB). There is some popular confusion about NCB's: it is frequently assumed that they are staffed by Interpol personnel allocated on posting to member countries. In fact the reverse is true: certain staff of the law enforcement agencies in member countries are assigned to work in the NCB. Each NCB is part of the member law enforcement agency. Responsibility for the control, operation and administration of an NCB rests with a member country: it is funded and staffed by the member country; its staff are subject to the internal rules of the member agency; and both the staff and the NCB as a whole are subject to the laws of the member country.

In Australia the NCB is administered by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police and is located in the AFP Headquarters in Canberra. The NCB operates strictly within Australian law and the personnel who work in the NCB are AFP personnel. They are subject to the AFP disciplinary provisions including the overseeing of complaints by the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The Australian NCB is not an ``office'' of Interpol, and there are no plans to open one.

(2) The role of Interpol is to facilitate the exchange of information between law enforcement agencies in the apprehension of criminals. The Australian NCB is part of this international network which provides the law enforcement agencies of member countries with an effective communications channel and an established avenue of obtaining assistance from other member countries to combat the international activities and movements of criminals. Through the Interpol network the Australian NCB also provides a community service by, for example, locating lost or missing people and conveying information about deaths to relatives of the deceased. The NCB also undertakes overseas character or criminal checks for Australian authorities where required by law and where the subject of the check has consented.

The Australian NCB is the Regional Communications Centre for Interpol in the South Pacific. Australia offered its NCB to undertake this function at Interpol's 59th General Assembly last year and the Interpol delegates accepted this offer.

(3) Interpol is an international network of 154 member countries, able to act as an information exchange between law enforcement agencies. The AFP, as a national law enforcement agency, does not have this capacity.
(4) The functions of Interpol and the AFP are completely separate: Interpol is an international information exchange network and the AFP is the Commonwealth's primary law enforcement agency.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sale of Mirage Aircraft to Pakistan

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Minister's comments at the National Press Club on 6 February 1991, where he stated in relation to the Mirage sale to Pakistan: `The government has said that it is somewhat concerned by that sale. It was impossible though, given the timetable of documents et cetera for us to intervene':
(1) What is meant by `the timetable of documents'.
(2) Given that approval of the sale of the aircraft was a matter for government, what did the Minister mean when he said that `It was impossible . . . for us to intervene'.
(3) At the same meeting the Minister said that `essentially we try to avoid selling arms into areas of instability'

(a) is this statement compatible with the statement made by his predecessor (Mr Beazley) on 14 June 1988 that `defence strategic or foreign policy objections must be specific and must outweigh export benefits in the particular case (of application to export);
(b) in identifying a region of instability, whose responsibility is it to determine that the criteria established by Mr Beazley's statement of June 1988 are applied; and
(c) in the case of Israel what specific foreign policy or strategic objections led to the decision to ban defence exports to that country.

(4) Is the area occupied by the states of India and Pakistan considered to be an area of instability; if so, when was the judgement made that it should be so considered for the purposes of evaluating applications for defence equipment exports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The expression `the timetable of documents' refers to the fact that time elapsed between the time when the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade first gave approval to negotiate the Mirage sale to Pakistan, and the time when the commercial contract with Pakistan was formally signed.
Once this contract was signed, it was impossible to intervene without incurring commercial penalties for breach of the contract.
(3) (a) Yes.

(b) The Minister for Defence acting on the advice of the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports which in turn is advised by the Departments and Authorities represented on the Committee.

(c) Israel is a country employing armed forces in a manner contrary to a decision of the United Nations Security Council. This does not prevent case-by-case consideration of defence related exports to Israel, particularly non-lethal items.
(4) Such considerations can only be taken into account at the time of considering individual applications on a case-by-case basis.

a. servicing trouble shooting, maintenance and training for the aircraft and supplies;
b. commissioning of production machines and tools; and
c. understanding and checking of technical documents and publications.

(20) No. A planned visit to Pakistan by a team of four RAAF technical personnel was cancelled due to concerns for the physical security of the team. Discussions with the Government of Pakistan on alternative arrangements are in progress.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made by Navy in the development of proposals for a Mine Hunter Coastal project.
(2) What are the titles and Public Service or Australian Defence Force (ADF) ranks of the Department of Defence and ADF officers involved in developing proposals for a Mine Hunter Coastal project.

(3) Has the department considered any proposals put forward by Navy for a Mine Hunter Coastal project; if so: (a) when were such proposals considered; and (b) what committees considered these proposals.
(4) If the department has not yet considered Navy proposals for a Mine Hunter Coastal project, when is it anticipated that the department will do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The current Defence Force Capability Proposal for a Minehunter Coastal is in the early stages of development and has not been seen by any of the major Defence Committees.
The Minehunter Coastal requirement is being addressed by the Force Structure Review. I will be reporting the results of that review in May 1991.

(2) The current proposal for a Minehunter Coastal is being developed by the Defence Force Development Division, headed by Major General Sanderson. Specifically, the proposal is being developed within the Force Development (Sea) branch headed by a Commodore with officers at the staff working level being of Captain and Commander rank.

(3) No dedicated Minehunter Coastal proposal has yet been submitted to the Defence Department. The Chiefs of Staff Committee has briefly considered the Minehunter Coastal as part of its deliberations on the Force Structure Review. These deliberations are not yet complete and I will be reporting the results of the Force Structure Review in May 1991.

Of the three major mine warfare projects currently underway, two, the Minehunter Inshore project and the Minesweeping Project, at various stages of their development, considered Mine Countermeasures vessels. These vessels were not Minehunter Coastals but were larger vessels with fitted minesweeping capabilities.
(4) I anticipate that the current Defence Force Capability Proposal for a Minehunter Coastal will reach the major Defence committee stages in late 1991 or early 1992.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) At what maximum sea-state conditions are the Royal Australian Navy Inshore Mine Hunter vessels currently able to operate such that they could satisfy Navy requirements when operationally complete.
(2) In likely operating areas, what approximate percentage of the time do sea-state conditions exceed the levels given in answer to question (1).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minehunter Inshore (MHI) is currently structurally seaworthy in sea states up to and including sea state 4. An assessment of the vessel's operational sea state limitations in the minehunting role cannot be provided at this time due to the poor performance of the minehunting sonar. Trials of potential alternate sonars are progressing.

To satisfy Navy requirements, when operationally complete, the MHI must be able to conduct minehunting operations at speeds up to 4 knots in sea states up to and including sea state 3 and transit in sea state 4.

There is a wide range of likely operating areas for the MHI and the sea states within those areas are subject to seasonal variations. The following tables provide information for four such areas over the calendar year.
[THE TABLES ARE OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE; SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 2149]

In these four areas, the average percentage of time an MHI could not conduct minehunting operations due to the sea state being above 3 is 39% and the average percentage of time an MHI could not transit due to the sea state being above 4 is 22%.

These figures only take account of the effect of the prevailing sea state conditions on MHI operations and transit periods. Other factors, particularly tidal streams in the northern areas, would further reduce the percentage of time an MHI would be available for minehunting operations but would not significantly alter the percentage of time available for transit.
The ADF's mine warfare capability requirements are being addressed by the Force Structure Review. I will be reporting the results of that review in May 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What progress has been made in establishing an offensive mining capability within the Australian Defence Force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The current ADF offensive maritime mining capability consists of a bomb conversion kit for the Mk 80 series bombs. These weapons, in the Royal Australian Air Force inventory, are capable of being delivered by the Flll aircraft. The P3C aircraft are also capable of laying these mines, however, it is unlikely that the P3C would be used for an offensive mining operation due to aircraft survivability.
A capability for the F/A-18 aircraft to deliver these mines is being developed.
The ADF's mining capability requirements are being addressed by the Force Structure Review. I will be reporting the results of that review in May 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: In reference to the answer Question on Notice No 140 of 14 August 1990 (Hansard, p. W2518):
(1) Is the Minister now able to say what the cost of KANGAROO 89 exercise was; if not, when will this information be available.
(2) Why has there been such a delay in costing the exercise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cost of Exercise KANGAROO 89 was $M190.180 comprised of $M188.772 for the Field Training Exercise (FTX) and $M1.408 for the Command Post Exercise (CPX).

(2) The delay in finalizing the costing of KANGAROO 89 was because the exercise costing instruction was not followed in all cases resulting in generally poor reporting of cost capture data. Also, the initial draft of the final cost analysis showed considerable variations between estimates and actual costs. Accordingly, additional time and effort was required to resolve these discrepancies. The costing details were issued as an amendment to the Post Exercise Report in July 1990.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the `provisional' recommendation given by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee for the estraderm patch, which is used as hormone replacement therapy for Australian women:
(1) What is the expected cost of the patch to patients.
(2) Will the price of the Australian patch be comparable to those sold in the United States, United Kingdom and New Zealand.
(3) How will the price for the estraderm patch be set.
(4) Will the patch be listed by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Fund.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Community Services and Health does not become involved in the pricing of a product unless the product is approved for marketing and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) has recommended its listing on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). Otherwise pricing is a matter solely for the manufacturer.

(2) The Australian price is a matter for the manufacturer and, if listed on the PBS, it is subject to negotiation between the Government and the manufacturer. If the product is recommended for listing on the PBS, the proposed price will be compared to that in the United Kingdom and New Zealand, as both countries have similar pharmaceutical schemes to the PBS.

(3) If the product is to be listed on the PBS, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority will recommend a price for the Department to negotiate with the manufacturer. The main factors considered in that recommendation would be the cost of manufacture, the relationship of the product with alternative products listed on the Scheme and any relevant advice from the PBAC.

(4) This will depend on whether the company wishes to list on the Scheme, whether listing is supported by the PBAC, any PBAC advice in relation to relative efficacy/safety, elative cost and the outcome of price negotiations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 13 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many commercial nuclear reactors is Indonesia proposing to construct, and where will they be built.
(2) Did a delegation from the Westinghouse Corporation recently spend ten days in Indonesia to discuss the nuclear power program.

(3) Does Indonesia have any uranium deposits which it plans to mine to provide fuel for its reactors; if not, has Australia approached the Indonesian Government about possible sales of Australian uranium.
(4) What plans does Indonesia have to dispose of nuclear waste from its projected reactor program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Present Indonesian plans envisage the construction of 12 nuclear power reactors to become operational progressively after the year 2003.
Nuclear power is only planned for the island of Java. A first site has been identified on the Muria Peninsula on the central north coast of Java, though this is subject to further evaluation studies.
(2) Yes. In addition to the United States, Indonesia has approached groups in France, Canada and Japan concerning a consultancy arrangement covering a feasibility study and site investigations.
(3) West Kalimantan has been identified as having uranium deposits with potential for development. A decision on whether these deposits can economically be exploited has yet to be made.
The possibility of sales of Australian uranium to Indonesia at an appropriate time in the future has been discussed informally between officials.

(4) No decision has been made regarding final disposal of nuclear waste from the projected reactor program. Current radioactive waste management practice, for sound environmental, technical and economic reasons, is for a lengthy period of storage of the wastes before final disposal. Developments in nuclear waste disposal methods between now and the time when spent fuel after the storage period would require disposal would clearly influence any final decision on nuclear waste disposal taken by the Indonesian authorities.
